fields.headline: Deadly Saqlain turns the screw
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 118 & 97
Surrey 260
Surrey win by an innings and 45 runs
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 118 & 97
Surrey 260
Surrey win by an innings and 45 runs
fields.body:
Derbyshire outplayed Surrey for the majority of yesterday but they were beaten half an hour before tea by an innings and 45 runs. One calamitous hour undid all their earlier good work and left Surrey seemingly untouchable on their way to another County Championship title. It was their seventh win in a row.

In the morning session Derbyshire took the last seven Surrey wickets for 41 runs and after lunch their opening pair suffered few alarms in taking their second-innings score to 68 without loss. But then in 68 minutes of surrender they lost all 10 of their wickets for 29 runs. Saqlain Mushtaq returned the handy figures of seven for 11, the sixth time this season he has taken five or more in an innings.

Eighteen wickets in all fell in the 65 overs of play. There was nothing wrong with the pitch, however. The umpires, Ray Julian and Barrie Leadbeater, confirmed afterwards that they will be commending it, not reporting it. There was pace and bounce from which both bowlers and batsmen could profit and the ball did not turn appreciably.

When play resumed, Derbyshire's cause looked hopeless. Surrey led by 43 runs with eight first-innings wickets in hand. Tim Munton, though, made a breakthrough in the first over, having Nadeem Shahid leg-before for 17. For a while this promised more than it delivered. Adam Hollioake, driving powerfully through extra cover, took Surrey's lead into three figures.

Munton then turned to Kevin Dean, whose 10 overs the previous evening had gone for nearly four an over. To his fourth ball of the day Hollioake obliged by hitting a catch to Michael di Venuto at short mid-wicket. It was a careless stroke and it set the tone for what was to follow. Dean put the ball in the right place and Surrey's batsmen frittered away their wickets.

The nightwatchman Ian Salisbury was bowled playing a loose drive, Alistair Brown, who had been unusually restrained, clipped a catch to Steve Stubbings at forward square leg and Gary Butcher drove to Paul Aldred at point. Dean found two straight deliveries to account for Martin Bicknell and Saqlain and, in 10 overs, he had taken six for 14 to restrict Surrey's first-innings advantage to 142.

Stubbings and the wicketkeeper Luke Sutton - promoted to open in place of Simon Lacey, who twisted his left knee the day before - then suggested that Derbyshire's fightback with the ball would be continued with the bat. Apart from the regular, concerted shout for leg-before - doubtless encouraged by the presence of the bowler's friend, umpire Julian - Bicknell and Alex Tudor struggled to find a way through their defences. Gary Butcher's golden arm also yielded no result.

With the score at 65 for no wicket from 18 overs, Hollioake brought on Salisbury. Sixteen overs later the game was over. Salisbury started with a wide but ended his first over with the wickets of Stubbings and Di Venuto, both caught by Shahid at short leg.

By now the two spinners were bowling in tandem. Saqlain, in his fourth over, found Rob Bailey's outside edge and Brown took the catch at the third attempt. His next over brought three more wickets, including Matthew Cassar, who clearly lacked the patience for the long game. He aimed a big drive at his first ball and was bowled. From there mopping up the tail was barely a challenge.

fields.headline: Stiff Lehmann restores Yorkshire
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 351
Yorkshire 194-5
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 351
Yorkshire 194-5
fields.body:
There is still not a more phlegmatic soul than the English professional cricketer and the news of Surrey's overpowering victory over Derbyshire at the Oval yesterday was greeted with charred smiles and grim shrugs in the Yorkshire dressing room.

For some time now Yorkshire have regarded their next championship match, against Surrey at Scarborough on August 30, as pivotal. It still is.

But now, even if they win that one, they are likely still to trail their London rivals by a handful of points. Surrey, though, are unlikely to find a "bunsen" on Yorkshire's blustery north-east coast.

Having spent most of yesterday battling to avoid the follow-on their chances of a much needed win here are remote. In reply to Leicestershire's 351 they were 194 for five at the end of the second day, still 157 behind.

Leicestershire resumed yesterday on 286 for eight and had a most productive opening hour in which they scored 65 runs in 15 overs.

On a true pitch the overnight pair of Neil Burns and Carl Crowe hit gleefully through the line. Burns scored a skittish 58 from 89 deliveries, with five fours, and Crowe made 30 before both were bowled by Chris Silverwood deliveries of full length. Silverwood was the most successful bowler with four for 60.

Yorkshire's reply faltered as soon as the Leicestershire captain Vince Wells entered the attack. In four overs before lunch he took three wickets without conceding a run.

He had Vic Craven and Anthony McGrath caught at second slip by Ben Smith from gentle, medium-paced away swingers. The catch to dispose of McGrath was a fine effort by Smith, who dived to his right to clutch the ball low and one-handed. Wells then had Matt Wood leg-before and Yorkshire were 24 for three.

At 61 Gary Fellows edged a hostile delivery from James Ormond to the wicketkeeper Burns and, with still no sign of the acting captain Darren Lehmann, who was nursing a stiff back in the dressing room, Yorkshire were close to despair.

All this time, however, the young opener Simon Widdup had batted with great obduracy. He had scored 38 in 52 overs when he pushed forward to the leg-spin of Anil Kumble and presented a simple catch to silly-point: 123 for five.

At this point Lehmann came to the wicket with the gait of a man discharging himself from intensive care. But like Gordon Greenidge and Basil D'Oliveira before him, Lehmann is deadly when he is down.

Reluctant to run, the Australian left-hander decided to hit everything for four instead. He drove, cut and pulled with relish and took 12 from one Kumble over. He reached his half-century with his ninth boundary.

Beside him Gavin Hamilton was restrained, though he too reached his 50 just before the close with a drive to the extra-cover boundary.

Kumble toiled away but he is not running through sides the way he did when he played for Northamptonshire six years ago, when he almost bowled that county to their first championship.

webTitle: Top order make easy targets for smiling assassin

fields.headline: Top order make easy targets for smiling assassin
fields.trailText: Frank Keating Then, all of a sudden, genuine history drenched the old arena. Curtly Ambrose cruelly, noiselessly sliced off the top of the opposition's batting with an assassin's stealth. Somehow one knew England had no chance any more.
fields.body:
Then, all of a sudden, genuine history drenched the old arena. Curtly Ambrose, as has been his custom, cruelly, noiselessly sliced off the top of the opposition's batting with an assassin's stealth - and now for the first time in the game's ancient history two men who have taken 400 wickets apiece were bowling from either end. Somehow one knew England had no chance any more.

Trescothick nicked a wicked climber to slip, tempted by the same impossible-to-read three-card trick that other far more eminent and experienced lefties like Allan Border so often were.

Three hundred and ninety nine down. The famous round figures were not long being posted. The old boy's dander was up and all his colleagues were urging him on. Atherton's fatal nibble, drawn like a fish to the fly on an autumn evening, was simply a divine providence beaming down. Again he was pouched at slip.

Cue the highest, probably, of any high-fives all round - the melon-like smile glistening wide and a particularly fond hug from Courtney Walsh, first West Indian to 400, of course.

At home in Antigua Ambrose's momma would have been "ringin' dat bell" as, from her radio sentry post, she has done every time he has taken a Test wicket. And, if not exactly rising to him physically, the Headingley crowd - often maligned for its churlishness against foreign opposition - applauded with great good-heart and knowing the value of achievement and history.

More than any other fast bowler of the long legend - and Ambrose's place was cemented firmly in that log long before yesterday - the bowler's stealthy patience has been like no other. Most opening bowlers have been volatile and excitable beings - bouncing and headhunting when riled.

That has never really been Ambrose's way - or certainly not in the grandeur of his maturity of the last two or three years. More than anyone, as time has caught up with him, he has reaffirmed the verities of line and length, patience, perseverance and the certain knowledge that, if those are in place, then the wickets will come. And now 400 have - and England yesterday did not really have a chance, did they?

webTitle: Forget the quality, feel the quantity

fields.headline: Forget the quality, feel the quantity
fields.standfirst: Premiership shows no sign of bust, despite England's summer flop
fields.trailText: The Premiership shows no sign of bust, despite England's summer flop, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
Only a scant knowledge of economics is necessary to realise that in the nature of things a boom must eventually go bust. Football, however, appears set on defying economic law for some time yet.

As the new season begins there is no obvious sign that the game in England, with all its shortcomings, is about to loosen its bulldog grip on either the public's affection or the public's purse. When people queue up outside the Manchester United megastore at midnight in order to be the first to buy the latest design in shirts at £48 for adults and £38 for children, it is hard to argue that the game is heading for the rocks.

Certainly the television companies do not share this view, scrambling over one another to pour more millions into club coffers under the latest agreement while said millions are being mortgaged by boardrooms to pay the fees and salaries of costly new signings.

Much of the football may be mundane but financially the game, in general terms, has never had it so good. As well as the latest strike at the TV goldmine, clubs stand to earn extra windfalls through sponsorship and kit deals. And while their supporters may complain about increased admission prices, they have yet to stay away in significant numbers. Miss a match and withdrawal symptoms soon set in.

With a captive and captivated audience, football, it seems, cannot lose. The unknown potential of pay-per-view has yet to be exploited to a serious degree but there is a proliferation of dot-commery to give fans a quick fix. A fully fledged European league is imminent and more new stadiums are planned, with Arsenal set to rebuild barely a mile down the road from Highbury.

Given such an optimistic background, dissenters are apt to be given the sort of bemused glance accorded to those mournful figures who used to parade outside football grounds advising customers to prepare to meet their doom.

At regular intervals financial experts warn that football is dancing on thin ice with heated skates. Yet the waltz continues, with an ever-higher proportion of club turnovers being spent on players' salaries as managers strive to keep their jobs while directors juggle to keep supporters and the banks happy.

Inflation is rife. Students of O-level economics are taught that inflation is the result of too much money chasing too few goods, and when Tottenham feel compelled to spend £5m on a defender, Ben Thatcher, from a relegated team, Wimbledon, the point is surely proved. Everybody, however, seems happy with the way things are.

Only two things, in the main, could upset this sanguine state of affairs. One is a recession of sufficient severity to curtail the public's spending power and leave football with a lot of replica shirts on its hands, but there is no sign of this yet.

The other is a stage at which BSkyB felt its coverage had reached such a point of saturation that no useful purpose would be served by forever upping the ante. If that happened a shudder would run through the game's balance sheets, but the process of soaking the viewers has barely begun.

Fans will always moan about a losing team and few have ever had a good word to say about referees, but in general it seems that football can do no wrong. The England team may have failed in a major tournament under a coach whose only credentials appear to have been his popularity and ability to get on with the media, but England teams have flopped before without diminishing people's enthusiasm for a flawed but invigorating domestic game.

The proliferation of foreign players, some outstanding, most merely competent, makes it easier for supporters to dissociate themselves from the mediocrity of the national team. Why worry about who will follow Alan Shearer in the England attack when your club has signed a talented Ukrainian, Sergei Rebrov, or a goalscoring Dutchman, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink?

Fans are not daft. They know that technically the Premiership is not on a par with the leagues of Italy and Spain, but will insist that for action, incident and excitement it has no equals, an argument supported by the number of foreign countries who take the live TV coverage from English grounds.

"English football is at its best when our teams are playing each other," Ron Greenwood declared many years ago, and the domestic product continues to support this view. Terry Venables was also right when he said that the English game thrived on errors which became an embarrassment when repeated in international tournaments, a point well made by Kevin Keegan's team this summer.

This is why, while Manchester United and Arsenal may be among the European clubs forever threatening to break away and form their own TV-orientated league, fans will take a great deal of persuading that such a competition could ever take precedence over the present scheme of things. In the longer term, domestic rivalries will always have more appeal than international rivalries.

The Premiership remains a lead pencil with a gold top but few fans are complaining. And United will not stay top forever, even though it may take Sir Alex Ferguson's impending retirement to end their present domination. If he actually goes, that is.

webTitle: Review: Swingtime with Harry Allen and Ken Peplowski

fields.headline: No fakes here
fields.standfirst:
Swingtime with Harry Allen and Ken Peplowski
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Swingtime with Harry Allen and Ken Peplowski
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
"This was billed as 'When Harry met Ken,'" said Ken Peplowski. "I just hope they're not expecting one of us to do a fake orgasm."

Actually, Harry Allen and Peplowski are more like Rodney and Del Boy from Only Fools and Horses than heroes of romantic comedy. Allen is the tall, slightly bewildered half of the partnership who plays the saxophone with great concentration, as though he's in the middle of a very difficult sum. Peplowski, once in the bands of Tommy Dorsey and Benny Goodman, is a dab hand at keeping the gags running, the audience laughing and the music pumping.

Pianist Bill Charlap provided a more than able accompaniment, together with Dave Green on double bass and Allan Ganley on drums, and the band's rendition of Lowlife, originally written for the Count Basie Band, allowed Allen to demonstrate his deep, classy tone.

With Jobim's tune No More Blues came a change of pace; Charlap's piano and Peplowski's clarinet introduction was so delicate as to stiffen the hairs on the back of the neck. The clarinet lagged mischievously, backed up by a shuffly drum rhythm, then overtaken by a piano interlude. Allen had less to do, but his lugubrious tone, proceeding down the scale towards the end of the number, cast a melancholy shadow against the jubilant clarinet.

"Here's Peplowski with a ballad," said Allen casually as he walked offstage. And what a ballad. Peplowski's tone on clarinet was luminescent, unrestrained. Its pared-down loveliness was unmarred by a run-up to higher notes, and the neat zigzag ending met with a bewitched hush.

Charlap took over for a Bud Powell number, and then it was Allen's turn to take the stage, with a high-speed chase which cranked up the pace by several notches. Peplowski joined in for the set's last number, The One I Love Belongs to Somebody Else, but his clarinet seemed a little too shrill, too lightweight, for the faster pace. It was down to Allen to bolster it with a more measured, languorous approach.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Theatre: Sholom Aleichem - Now You're Talking

fields.headline: Shtetls and samovars
fields.standfirst:
Sholom Aleichem - Now You're Talking
New End Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Sholom Aleichem - Now You're Talking
New End Theatre, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
A collection of stories by Yiddish literature's most expert and beloved fabulist, Sholom Aleichem, ought, you would suppose, make perfect material for theatrical adaptation. Aleichem, after all, created the character of Tevye the Milkman, and the musical for which Tevye became the central figure, Fiddler on the Roof, became a record-setter on Broadway.

And so, to some extent, it proves. Aleichem's stories, 11 of which are included in Saul Reichlin's one-man show, deal in the grubby, poverty-stricken small change of the Russian shtetls, at the last gasp of pre-Revolution isolation and victimisation. (Aleichem himself emigrated to the US in 1905, and died in New York in 1916.) Historical events intrude occasionally - the Dreyfus affair gets a couple of mentions - but as one of Reichlin's early selections, Dreyfus in Kasrilevkeh, makes clear, newsworthy events are remote and distant, in a wrong-end-of-the-telescope kind of way.

No, Aleichem's world is the eternal shtetl that has been mythologised almost out of history: this is an environment that to all intents and purposes, saw no changes between 1690 and 1890. Aleichem's small-scale, homely narratives - in which a Jewish traveller picks up a tsarist officer's cap by mistake, or a harmless schnorrer (beggar), ironically nicknamed Rothschild, trips over a drunk shoemaker on a feast day - point up this sense of self-containment and self-sufficiency. That's why they make such good nostalgia too; Tevye and his ilk are sentimentalised icons of hopefulness, betterment, and vessels of good fortune - exactly the kind of qualities that have traditionally preoccupied successive Jewish generations, both before and since Aleichem's time.

Reichlin has obvious affection for his material, and exercises considerable skill in giving voice to the multiplicity of characters that the inter-connected stories require. On the other hand, the tales cry out for a strongly visual staging - both in terms of performance and in stage hardware. Director Robert Longden, however, has chosen to go for basic, unchanging lighting; a painted stage, and a single samovar in the corner. Reichlin, despite his ability to spin a yarn, tends to the static, relying on his ability to connect with the audience and verbal dexterity to keep momentum going. Unfortunately, it doesn't always work: by second half, there's not much to distinguish it from a radio play.

 Until September 3. Box office: 020-7794 0022.

webTitle: BT debt rating cut as it spends £4bn

fields.headline: BT debt rating cut as it spends £4bn
fields.standfirst:
Taking control of Viag and cost of mobile phone licences alarms Standard & Poor's

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: BT's increasing debt burden, caused by a spending spree on third generation mobile licences and acquisitions, alarmed rating agency Standard & Poor's yesterday, which said it would slash the company's credit rating.
fields.body:
BT's increasing debt burden, caused by a spending spree on third generation mobile licences and acquisitions, alarmed rating agency Standard & Poor's yesterday, which said it would slash the company's credit rating.

The move by S&P followed BT's announcement that it would spend £4bn doubling its stake in German subsidiary Viag Interkom to 90%.

Viag also won one of the six licences awarded in the third generation mobile phone auction in Germany yesterday - at a cost of £5.3bn.

The cost of converting its minority interest in Viag into a controlling stake could see BT's debt balloon from £20bn to £30bn.

A drop in BT's credit rating could curtail the group's ambition to become a major contender in Europe's telecoms market as it would make it more difficult and expensive to raise debt.

Louis Landeman, associate director at S&P, said BT was on a AA+ rating but likely to be downgraded. "We have had BT under review for downgrade for some time ... Its rating could go down to a single A level," he said.

Michael West, vice-president at Moody's, said it too had BT on review for a downgrade, with it holding the group at AA1 at present.

"Our review does mean there's pressure on that rating," Mr West said.

Analysts say that BT is going to be in need of more cash to buy other third generation mobile phone licences being auctioned across Europe, upgrading networks for those new licences and also expanding its high speed data and internet operations.

BT's shares plunged to 780p initially on the announcement that it would increase its stake in Viag. They ended 11p lower at 812p.

Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, said he expected disposals would be made by the company so debt did not soar to £30bn.

He said: "Our gearing will go up but it's our intention to maintain our A-grade rating. We will make some disposals."

BT has been pursuing a strategy of taking full ownership of minorities, mopping up Esat in Ireland and more recently Telfort in the Netherlands.

BT also has toeholds in France, Spain, Belgium , Italy, Sweden and Switzerland.

BT will not pay E.ON, from who it has agreed to buy the 45% shareholding in Viag, until the middle of next year because of an option agreement.

Telenor, which owns the remaining 10% of Viag, also has an option to sell to BT by the end of the first quarter of next year.

The terms of its sale are understood to be similar to those of E.ON.

BT's acquisition of E.ON stake is valued at about £1,824 per Viag customer. Viag is the third biggest telecoms company in the German market, with a fixed line business, internet service provider and 2m mobile phone customers.

Christian Maher, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, said that the deal represented good value, although the former state monoply's debt levels were somewhat worrying.

He said that BT's increasing debt burden heightened the likelihood of flotations of parts of the operation.

BT does plan to float part of its directory service business Yell later this year.

The company's board is expected to announce by January a potential timetable for the further partial sale of other subsidiaries such as BT Cellnet, OpenWorld and its joint venture with AT&T Concert.

BT is considered to be lagging behind competitors such as Vodafone and Deutsche Telekom in building a pan-European presence.

However, the ratings of other telecoms operators will also come under pressure with the skyrocketing prices being paid for third generation licences.

Some analysts have speculated that BT's weak share price could flush out a potential bidder.

Sir Peter said: "You can't stop somebody else having a go at us. But from a management point of view we are trying to push on with our strategy which we have articulated to generate good value for our shareholders so they will not be seduced by somebody else."

fields.headline: Breaking neutrality
fields.standfirst:
Oslo Philharmonic/Honek
Royal Albert Hall, London/ Radio 3
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Oslo Philharmonic/Honek
Royal Albert Hall, London/ Radio 3
Rating: ****
fields.body:
If many of the audience who turned up or tuned in to hear Mariss Jansons conduct the Oslo Philharmonic and Olga Borodina sing Berlioz's The Death of Cleopatra were initially disappointed - both had withdrawn from the concert - they should have gone away more than satisfied with the replacements. The Austrian-born Manfred Honeck, now the principal guest conductor in Oslo, took over the programme unchanged and the American mezzo Michelle DeYoung tackled the scena that Berlioz produced in 1829 in his third unsuccessful attempt to win the prestigious Prix de Rome

DeYoung has always seemed to me a rather neutral, uninvolved performer before; no one has ever doubted the sumptuous quality of her voice - even, velvety, perfectly controlled - just the extent to which she engages with what she is singing. But Berlioz clearly suits her well; she's to be one of the soloists in Colin Davis's concert performances of The Trojans at the end of the year, and this wracked and touching account of Cleopatra's final throes suggested that will be well worth hearing. Every phrase was loaded with meaning, every syllable savoured, and the tragic grandeur built inexorably. Honeck's alert accompaniment reinforced it all too; he and the Oslo strings made sure that all of Berlioz's rangy, searching melodies had point and the right expressive purpose.

The concert had begun with Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, lithe and purposeful, and never sounding over-loaded despite the size of the orchestral forces. It ended with Ravel's La Valse, which Honeck turned into a nightmarish vision of a society in freefall, always controlled, yet driving through to the final cataclysm with biting rhythms and scary determination. The Oslo Philharmonic's playing was superlative - every section of this great orchestra is very finely tuned indeed, and they showed that they are capable of great refinement as well as extreme virtuosity. There were encores too - a bit of perfectly weighted Grieg (Morning Mood from the Peer Gynt music) to acknowledge the orchestra's homeland, a Johann Strauss waltz (Frühlingsstimmen) to signal the conductor's, who needs to be heard here soon in his own right, not as a replacement.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable
** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Angry, enraged and office rage
fields.standfirst: Seeing red? Then you must have had a falling out at work, our employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Seeing red? Then you must have had a falling out at work, our employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
Well, the heat continues but the smut in my practice has finally diminished. A propos of the heat, I have been considering forming a sort of comic book style vigilante group to be called something catchy like the The Priority Seat Men (The P-Men for short).

This will consist of myself (in my current guise of Pregnant Woman with no Ankles) an older person of each gender, someone on crutches and a person carrying infant triplets. Together we will ride overheated rush hour tubes and stand oppressively near to so-called priority seats occupied by teenagers or able-bodied business folk.

I am not sure what else we'll do, maybe a bit of glaring and possibly some making of pointed remarks. Or fainting. This could be bigger than the X-Men or Pokemon. You will say that this sounds like a sad case of tube rage. I say that at least tube rage is better (or less self-destructive anyway) than office rage which is what my case this week was all about.

My client, Mr Angry, had been sacked after a pushing and shoving style of incident broke out between him and a colleague, Mr Enraged, over whose turn it was to use a photocopier. The star piece of evidence on the employers' side was a blurred photocopy which appeared to show Mr Angry holding Mr Enraged down by his ears.

On side we seemed to have two main lines of attack

1) A petition circulated by Mr Angry amongst his colleagues to demonstrate how out of character the incident was. This said: "We the undersigned have never seen Mr Angry lose his temper or behave in a physically aggressive manner towards anyone in the office."

There followed 22 signatures. Great, except for the notes two of those signing had helpfully appended:

"EXCEPT WHEN PROVOKED BY CIRCUMSTANCES NOT OF HIS OWN MAKING" "Not so as to actually hurt anyone"

Mr Angry took a little persuading that this document was not really going to assist him.

2) (Apparently our better point). Mr Enraged was not sacked as a result of the incident. Mr Angry's view of this was that the difference in treatment amounted to race discrimination because he was black and Mr Enraged was white. The employer was saying there was a difference in treatment because Mr Angry had a history of aggressive behaviour and Mr Enraged did not.

At least I thought that was the issue. Until counsel for the employer asked to have a word before we went into the tribunal.

Counsel for the employer: You do realise that your race discrimination case doesn't make any sense.

Me: Why not? Him: Because Mr Enraged is also black. Me: But Mr Angry says he's white. Him: Well I can get him here after lunch. Me: I guess you'd better.

After a somewhat directionless morning during which Mr Angry insisted that Mr Enraged was white and Counsel for the employers insisted he was black, Mr Enraged turned up. One is a bit wary about jumping to conclusions but he did look black. Counsel for the employer called him to give evidence and asked him his name address and ethnic origin (same as Mr A's) and then offered him for cross-examination.

I turned to Mr A and whispered: "Do you really want me to put to this man that he is white?"

The steam seemed suddenly to seep out of Mr Angry: "I guess not".

I remain baffled. Mr Angry just looked baffled himself when I asked him to explain after we lost the case. Maybe rage is just blinding. I myself did experience a fog of red before the eyes as I straphung over a man in a priority seat on my way back to chambers before I realised he was asleep.

webTitle: Financial news sites merge with web host

fields.headline: Financial news sites merge with web host
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Globalnet, the online financial information firm backed by Freeserve, yesterday announced plans to merge with Telescan, the American internet services company.
fields.body:
Globalnet, the online financial information firm backed by Freeserve, yesterday announced plans to merge with Telescan, the American internet services company.

Nasdaq-listed Telescan develops and hosts corporate websites for financial services and media companies, including American Express and Citigate. Globalnet's websites are designed to generate online trading of securities and other investment products as well as providing news and advice to the investment community.

The new company will trade under the name GlobalnetFinancial. Chief executive Stanley Hollander said the merged company was on schedule to be the biggest of its kind now that it could use Telescan's technical expertise to increase the range of its services.

It will be targeting larger financial institutions whose core business remain offline. The combined companies have offices across Europe, the US and Canada, and hope to add the Far East.

Under the terms of the merger, each Telescan share will be exchanged for 0.5 of a Globalnet share. "The merger will allow Globalnet to leverage an early mover advantage and build its presence within the European internet market," Globalnet said.

The new company will be valued at $332m (£221m). Mr Hollander said it would have around $80m in annual revenue and would be the only financial portal to own the technology behind its websites.

Globalnet recently took a 29.9% stake in British online investment bank EO, which lets retail investors subscribe to flotations over the internet. The firm also provides financial news to the Freeserve, which has a 13.55% stake in the company.

Telescan reported a net loss of $6m last year on revenues of $26m. Globalnet had disappointed the market earlier this month when it announced losses of $21m in the six months to June 31 against a turnover of $1.6m. The losses were attributed to a world-wide expansion programme.

fields.headline: DVD ruling favours studios
fields.trailText: In what the studios have called an historic decision, federal judge Lewis Kaplan yesterday barred Eric Corley from distributing information that allows DVDs to be duplicated and traded over the internet
fields.body:
A US judge has ruled in favour of the movie studios in a landmark case over DVD fraud, reports e! online news.

In what the studios have called an historic decision, federal judge Lewis Kaplan yesterday barred Eric Corley (pictured) from distributing information that allows DVDs to be duplicated and traded over the internet.

Corey, a well known hacker and the webmaster of 2600: The Hacker Quarterly, claimed freedom of speech under the first amendment. The judge, however, ruled that software code is not protected by the first amendment because the code was created with the sole purpose of decoding DVDs.

Hollywood saw this as an extremely important case to win, with eight major film studios (including Universal, Warner Bros and MGM) suing Corley. They were anxious to nip in the bud what they see as the dangerous precedent set by music-swapping sites such as Napster, and feared the spread of illegal DVD-trading.

Jack Valenti, chairman of the Motion Picture Association of American, cheered his industry's latest triumph: "Today's landmark decision nailed down an indispensable constitutional and congressional truth: It's wrong to help others steal creative works. The court's ruling is a victory for consumers and for legimate technology."

A spokesman for Eric Corley claimed they were going to take the case further. "This is what we expected," said defence attorney Martin Garbus, "we understood that this was an issue that has to be resolved in the supreme court."

webTitle: Leader: a web of government deceit on pensions

fields.headline: More than misleading
fields.standfirst:
A web of government deceit on pensions

Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: For a decade after the change in the law, the social security department failed to warn contributors that the pensions of their partners would be halved on their death.
fields.body:
Even the silver-tongued Alistair Darling could not have sounded less persuasive. The social security secretary was on the BBC Today programme defending the indefensible. There would be compensation for people who could show that his department had misinformed them about changes to the state earnings related pensions scheme (serps) made in 1986, and due to come into force this year. But there was no guarantee of redress for anybody else who had suffered.

The numbers involved are huge: there are 20m contributors to the scheme, which provides a second state pension to people who do not have an occupational or personal pension. But that does not affect the principle. For a decade after the change in the law, the department failed to alter its leaflets to warn contributors that the pensions of their partners would be halved on their death. Worse still, people who wrote for information were not told of the change.

Mr Darling suggested there was no precedent for a government compensation on such a large scale. But there have been very few precedents for such a massive Whitehall administrative error. No wonder the bureaucrats have been at their worst in trying to defend it, even suggesting they had not misled people, because advice given between 1986 and 1996 had been "correct at the time".

As private pension specialists noted yesterday, the sin of omission is as serious as that of commission. The department is as guilty of "mis-selling" pensions as the private companies and personal financial advisers who ripped off 2.7m people in the personal pension scandal a decade ago. The department has deferred the change until October 2002, but in a report this week the Commons public accounts committee suggested this should be extended to 2016.

The MPs were unequivocal about the Government's obligation to recompense contributors. Ministers should seize this solution: there is no way they can devise a scheme which can identify people who were misled by a telephone call or leaflet up to a decade ago. Mr Darling complains about the costs: about £13bn - but the private sector has been forced to spend £11bn compensating its victims.

But let us be clear where the real responsibility lies. It should not have been Mr Darling in the dock yesterday, but the succession of Tory ministers running the department between 1986-96 when these shameful errors occurred.

There would be compensation for people who could show that his department had misinformed them about changes to the state earnings related pensions scheme (serps) made in 1986, and due to come into force this year. But there was no guarantee of redress for anybody else who had suffered. The numbers involved are huge: there are 20m contributors to the scheme, which provides a second state pension to people who do not have an occupational or personal pension. But that does not affect the principle. For a decade after the change in the law, the department failed to alter its leaflets to warn contributors that the pensions of their partners would be halved on their death. Worse still, people who wrote for information were not told of the change. Mr Darling suggested there was no precedent for a government compensation on such a large scale. But there have been very few precedents for such a massive Whitehall administrative error. No wonder the bureaucrats have been at their worst in trying to defend it, even suggesting they had not misled people, because advice given between 1986 and 1996 had been "correct at the time". As private pension specialists noted yesterday, the sin of omission is as serious as that of commission. The department is as guilty of "mis-selling" pensions as the private companies and personal financial advisers who ripped off 2.7m people in the personal pension scandal a decade ago. The department has deferred the change until October 2002, but in a report this week the Commons public accounts committee suggested this should be extended to 2016. The MPs were unequivocal about the Government's obligation to recompense contributors. Ministers should seize this solution: there is no way they can devise a scheme which can identify people who were misled by a telephone call or leaflet up to a decade ago. webTitle: Salas signals end of Brazil's superiority

fields.headline: Salas signals end of Brazil's superiority
fields.trailText:
Chile 3 - 0 Brazil
Brazil's coach Wanderley Luxemburgo justified his team's humiliating 3-0 defeat by Chile by saying that the era of Brazil's superiority in South American football was over and that the team was likely to suffer further upsets on the road to the 2002 World Cup finals.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Brazil's coach Wanderley Luxemburgo justified his team's humiliating 3-0 defeat by Chile by saying that the era of Brazil's superiority in South American football was over and that the team was likely to suffer further upsets on the road to the 2002 World Cup finals.

"Brazil has to live with the new reality," he said in Santiago after the match. "Brazilian football doesn't make a difference any more. It's not enough now just to field Brazilians. This change was inevitable at some point. And it is happening under my command."

Chile's Marcelo Salas, the Lazio striker, destroyed the four-time world champions almost single-handedly by setting up the first two goals, for Fabian Estay and Ivan Zamorano, and scoring the last in front of a jubilant 60,000 crowd.

The defeat was only the third ever for Brazil in a World Cup qualifier but it was the second in three games and Brazil lie fourth in the 10-nation group behind Argentina, Colombia and Uruguay.

Luxemburgo said changes in structure of the qualifying stages were partly to blame.

"In the current group we have to play 18 matches," he said. "The total of all other World Cups has been 44. I've got more chances to lose."

The match was the first qualifier between the two countries since 1989, when Chile walked off at the Maracana stadium in Rio de Janeiro after a firecracker landed near their goalkeeper Roberto Rojas. Fifa judged Rojas faked injury, gave him a life ban and banned Chile from the 1994 qualifying competition.

The pressure mounting on Luxemburgo after Brazil's surprise defeat by Paraguay last month has returned with a vengeance after the temporary lull of a 3-1 victory against Argentina.

However, Brazil's thoughts are currently more focused on the Olympic title, which is the only major trophy the country has never won. In two friendlies against Chile in the past week the Olympic team - also coached by Luxemburgo - have won 3-0 and 5-3.

In Wednesday's other qualifying match Colombia beat Uruguay 1-0 in Bogota to move into second place. The first four teams qualify and the fifth faces a two-leg play-off against the winners of the Oceania group.

 Manchester City's new signing Paulo Wanchope scored both Costa Rica's goals in a 2-1 World Cup group win over Guatemala.

fields.headline: Healy's hard work wasted by Irish
fields.standfirst: Healey 45 | Kezman 63, Mijatovic 78
fields.trailText:
Northern Ireland 1 - 2 Yugoslavia
Sammy McIlroy's Northern Ireland found Yugoslavia predictably too strong in this friendly last night, even though the visitors had to fight back in the second half.
fields.body:
Sammy McIlroy's Northern Ireland found Yugoslavia, Euro 2000 quarter-finalists, predictably too strong in this friendly last night, even though the visitors had to fight back in the second half.

The substitute for Savo Milosevic, Mateja Kezman, turned the game with the softest of equalisers, a free header from Ivan Dudic's cross in the 63rd minute.

Yugoslavia then noticeably stepped up the pace with Predrag Mijatovic and Kezman causing problems with their speed and guile. The winner came when Mijatovic finally struck the goal he had threatened all night with an easy tap in from Dudic's cut-back in the 70th minute.

Milosevic, Parma's new £16m signing, displayed little of the potency which saw him finish joint top scorer in Euro 2000. The former Aston Villa striker had a couple of tame shots midway through the first half.

Jim Magilton, playing his first international at Windsor Park for almost three years, sprayed the ball around cleverly in the middle of the field but the poor first touches of the wide men Damien Johnson and Kevin Horlock usually stopped the momentum.

That was until David Healy began to come into the game. The 20-year-old had to accept the role of lone front man, with Philip Mulryne dropping deep. Yet Yugoslavia's three central defenders soon had their hands full.

First Healy was adjudged offside by the referee, if not the linesman, having been put through by Magilton and two minutes later he had a shot saved by Zeljko Cicovic.

Then with 20 seconds remaining in the first half, he struck. Whitley played a lovely ball into space behind the defence and Healy, given the No35 shirt at Old Trafford this season, shot between the goalkeeper's legs. It was his fourth goal in four internationals.

Northern Ireland (4-4-1-1) Taylor; Nolan, Murdock, Williams, Hughes; Johnson, Whitley, Magilton, Horlock; Mulryne; Healy.

Yugoslavia (3-5-2) Cicovic; Grujic, Bunjevcevic, Sakic; Dudic, Djordjevic, Grozdic, Stankovic, Lazetic; Milosevic, Mijatovic

Referee: W Young (Scotland).

fields.headline: No love lost in Manchester 'friendly'
fields.standfirst: Man Utd 2 - 0 Man City
fields.trailText: Denis Irwin limped out of his testimonial last night as Man Utd beat Man City 2-0.
fields.body:
If testimonial matches are supposed to be drab, lightweight affairs in which nobody gets hurt and nobody raises a sweat, somebody forgot to tell Denis Irwin.

Just four minutes into his big night at Old Trafford last night, the 34-year-old Manchester United stalwart was brought down in a tackle by Manchester City's George Weah. Thirty-three minutes later, despite his gamest efforts, he limped reluctantly off.

Testimonial or not, the United manager Alex Ferguson was not taking any risks with his prized asset just three days before the defending champions' real season opener against Newcastle United.

Before the match began Irwin had enjoyed the customary guard of honour and standing ovation from the Old Trafford faithful, and looked none too pleased when Weah, City's new signing from Chelsea, offered him an apologetic hand on the shoulder.

His departure inevitably took some of the gloss off the night, but as far as Manchester derbies go it was not a bad one. Not much can be read into pre-season testimonials, but the Premiership newcomers could take plenty of heart from their 2-0 defeat. They more than held their own for most of the match, but Teddy Sheringham gave United the edge before half-time when he drove home a pass from Andy Cole. More telling battles between these two, one suspects, are yet to come.

fields.headline: Rebrov tuned into Graham's wavelength
fields.standfirst: Ukrainian spurred by title ambition
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin finds Tottenham's Ukrainian striker spurred by title ambition.
fields.body:
The message beneath Sergei Rebrov's amateur radio call-sign on the internet will have Tottenham fans choking on their bagels. "I am an International football player," it reads, "currently playing for a well known UK team. I'am worth millions on paper but... crap on the field."

So the truth is out. The man George Graham paid £11m for in the hope of easing his goalscoring problems is football's answer to Gerald Ratner. Dynamo Kiev must be laughing all the way to the bank. Rebrov, who is due to make his Premiership debut against Ipswich at White Hart Lane on Saturday, is not laughing at all.

"This is the first I have heard about this," the striker says, munching nuts in the bar of his hotel. "It is not my joke and none of my friends can write that stupid message. Somebody who doesn't like me and wants to create problems for me must have done it."

An Arsenal fan, perhaps? "It was probably the same person who wrote all that rubbish about my leg injury. Before I signed a contract with Tottenham someone wrote in a lot of newspapers that I have an injury which will never clear up and it is impossible for me to sign for Spurs. I think it is the same thing. Six years ago I had that injury."

Given Tottenham's reputation for turning away players with as much as a broken nail, it is safe to assume Rebrov is fit. And by all accounts he has looked far from crap on the field so far. The 26-year-old has contributed three goals to an unbeaten pre-season and - Graham might like to look away at this point - is already talking of winning the title.

"I spoke to George Graham about the club and about this season," he says, "and, if Tottenham could not win the Premiership or get a place in the Champions League, I would not have come here.

"I believe anyone can win this title because there are so many strong teams. I am positive we will either get in the Champions League or win the title. I haven't played in the Premier League yet but I can recognise, from how we train and prepare, the quality of the team."

Some wonder, of course, whether much of the quality has disappeared to Aston Villa with David Ginola. Rebrov makes no secret of his disappointment at the departure of the Frenchman, who had looked a natural source of supply for him - of goals as well as L'Oreal.

"The first time I met Ginola was in a game in the Champions League against Paris St-Germain in 1994," Rebrov recalls. "I thought Ginola was the best player in Europe and privately I wanted to play with him. That's why I was disappointed. But that is football. I have seen plenty of good players leave Dynamo Kiev."

Andrei Shevchenko and the Arsenal defender Oleg Luzhny are among them. In his homeland Rebrov is widely regarded as a better player than Shevchenko, and his decision to move to White Hart Lane was guided by his Ukraine international strike partner's experience at Milan as well as by his impressions of Spurs from television, video and meetings with the management.

"There was a mutual respect and understanding," he stresses, "and I saw in Tottenham the same qualities I saw at Dynamo Kiev. I noticed that Andrei had to play a different game at Milan to what he had played at Dynamo Kiev. The coach asked him to fill a different role. I recognised it would be the same for me at Tottenham as I was used to. That was important."

Steffen Freund, in particular, is easing Rebrov into his new surroundings, though not everything in London is to his liking. Tea and toast come a distant second to traditional Ukrainian breakfasts; British beer consumption has shocked a man who shuns vodka for the occasional glass of red wine; and Rebrov is looking to move out of his hotel to a house in the Chigwell area. Only then can he install any radio equipment for a start.

His old system will remain at Dynamo Kiev's training complex, where the players used to sleep for several days before and after matches without their families to prevent anyone stepping out of line. The new freedom is a welcome bonus. In the bar Rebrov is helping his wife with her language: "I am, he is, you are..."

Rebrov's impressive English is the legacy of the radio hobby he picked up from his father in Donetsk, the mining area of eastern Ukraine which also produced the pole vaulter Sergei Bubka.

Rebrov epitomises the team ethic Graham adores. The 121 goals he hit in 260 games for Dynamo Kiev mark him out as an instinctive scorer, yet he is equally effective playing neat passes from deeper positions, prompting Graham to compare him to Dennis Bergkamp. Although he cuts a slight figure at 5ft 7in, the physical demands of the Premiership do not concern him.

"It is not necessary for me to be big and strong as a striker," he says. "I think technique and tactics are more important. Look at Michael Owen, who is a similar build to me and has been very successful."

In other words, whatever those out to get him may write, Rebrov is determined to prove he is worth millions not just on paper but on the pitch as well.

fields.headline: Ferguson flak for Newcastle
fields.trailText: Duncan Ferguson's agent last night turned his frustration over the Scotland striker's aborted move to Everton into a condemnation of Newcastle United's handling of the transfer fiasco.
fields.body:
Duncan Ferguson's agent last night turned his frustration over the Scotland striker's aborted move to Everton into a condemnation of Newcastle United's handling of the transfer fiasco.

As Ferguson resigned himself to getting neither the move to Goodison Park nor the lucrative pay-off he had been craving, Dennis Roach laid the blame squarely at Newcastle's door.

Roach claimed that because Ferguson never asked for the transfer the player was entitled to compensation under the terms of his contract.

"If that had been rounded up to £250,000 that would have been all he wanted," he said. "But we never had the opportunity to ask for that money, and because of that Duncan has decided to dig in his heels and will not be going anywhere. With Duncan, it's a case of a bit of pride being involved.

"I'm getting stick - I'm supposed to have been asking for £1m but that is a nonsense. Everton have behaved well throughout but because of other circumstances the deal is now off. People of Duncan Ferguson's quality should not be treated in this way. He is now in an awkward position.

"It would not make me want to play for Newcastle any more but Duncan wants to put this behind him and he still believes the fans are on his side. Duncan feels he can put anyone out of the side and he has told me he will fight for his place."

Ferguson's relationship with his current employers is now so acrimonious that he will undoubtedly take solace from the fact he has hit his club where it hurts most, in the wallet.

By refusing to complete his transfer back to the Merseyside club Ferguson has, in essence, told Newcastle he is fully prepared to sit tight - possibly in the reserves - for the remaining three years of one of the most lucrative contracts in the history of British football.

Having picked up a £1m bonus after moving between Goodison Park and St James' Park in November 1998, the 28-year-old Ferguson has since been paid around £38,000 a week.

If he were to remain at Newcastle until his current deal expires in 2003, Ferguson would collect almost £6m in wages, possibly without the inconvenience of actually playing senior football.

Everton's patience finally ran out at lunchtime yesterday, some 24 hours after Ferguson had failed to show for a medical which would have paved the way for his £3.75m return to what he has always described as his "spiritual home".

Everton's manager Walter Smith said: "Having agreed a deal with both parties on Friday we were very hopeful of signing Duncan. We are extremely disappointed that the deal will not now proceed."

Although there is still an outside chance that Ferguson could kiss and make up with the two clubs, Smith is resigned to opening the Premiership campaign against Leeds United at Elland Road on Saturday with a strike force of Mark Hughes and Joe Max Moore.

fields.headline: Coventry hail Bellamy coup
fields.trailText: Coventry were proclaiming a coup last night with the immiment £6.5m signing of Craig Bellamy from Norwich.
fields.body:
Coventry were proclaiming a coup last night with the immiment £6.5m signing of Craig Bellamy, a forward the midlands club "fully expect to do as well as Robbie Keane, if not better".

The prediction came from an elated Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson, whose club are capturing a 21-year-old player in Keane's quick, clever mould for half the Italian money received on the young Irishman's startling recent move to Internazionale.

Richardson said: "It is fantastic news for the club - especially considering the calibre of opposition we were up against," claiming three Premiership clubs and one from the First Division had also pursued Bellamy. Tottenham are known to have monitored the Welsh international since he made an impact as a fast, free-scoring forward at Norwich.

Coventry were particularly keen to check Bellamy has fully recovered from the knee injury that kept him out of the Norwich side for most of last season and undoubtedly delayed his move to the Premiership.

The financial side of the deal was completed at 2am yesterday, with Bellamy agreeing a five-year contract, before he drove to the midlands in the afternoon for his medical.

Richardson said his manager Gordon Strachan had spoken to several other people to make sure and they all said, "Go and get him, he's tops."

Coventry will find they have signed a "disciple of the game," according to Bobby Gould, who worked closely with Bellamy while Wales manager. "Craig flies to Belgium and Holland to watch matches and to learn about the game - and that shows in the way he plays.

"On the pitch he is very effervescent, a sharp performer and an excellent finisher. I would certainly put him in the same bracket as Michael Owen and Robbie Keane."

Bradford City's manager Chris Hutchings yesterday contemplated an audacious move for the talented but troublesome Russian striker Vladimir Beschastnykh.

A delegation led by Hutchings flew into Moscow yesterday, where Beschastnykh played for his country before coming off in the 46th minute in the 1-0 win over Israel.

The controversial 26-year-old is eligible to leave Racing Santander on a free transfer next summer and the Spanish club would prefer to sell him now, albeit for a fraction of the £6m that he would usually command. Beschastnykh has fallen out with Santander team-mates and been criticised by the club's president Miguel Angel Diaz.

Leeds are to make David O'Leary the highest-paid manager in the history of English football in the next 48 hours. The club confidently expect him to commit himself until 2006 after accepting a deal worth £2m a year, plus bonuses.

Dominic Matteo's move to Leeds hit a snag yesterday when a medical revealed a knee injury which will keep him out for two months. But Leeds insist that the £4.75m deal with Liverpool will eventually be resurrected.

The prediction came from an elated Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson, whose club are capturing a 21-year-old player in Keane's quick, clever mould for half the Italian money received on the young Irishman's startling recent move to Internazionale. Richardson said: "It is fantastic news for the club - especially considering the calibre of opposition we were up against," claiming three Premiership clubs and one from the First Division had also pursued Bellamy. Tottenham are known to have monitored the Welsh international since he made an impact as a fast, free-scoring forward at Norwich. Coventry were particularly keen to check Bellamy has fully recovered from the knee injury that kept him out of the Norwich side for most of last season and undoubtedly delayed his move to the Premiership. The financial side of the deal was completed at 2am yesterday, with Bellamy agreeing a five-year contract, before he drove to the midlands in the afternoon for his medical. Richardson said his manager Gordon Strachan had spoken to several other people to make sure and they all said, "Go and get him, he's tops." Coventry will find they have signed a "disciple of the game," according to Bobby Gould, who worked closely with Bellamy while Wales manager. "Craig flies to Belgium and Holland to watch matches and to learn about the game - and that shows in the way he plays. "On the pitch he is very effervescent, a sharp performer and an excellent finisher. I would certainly put him in the same bracket as Michael Owen and Robbie Keane." Bradford City's manager Chris Hutchings yesterday contemplated an audacious move for the talented but troublesome Russian striker Vladimir Beschastnykh. A delegation led by Hutchings flew into Moscow yesterday, where Beschastnykh played for his country before coming off in the 46th minute in the 1-0 win over Israel. The controversial 26-year-old is eligible to leave Racing Santander on a free transfer next summer and the Spanish club would prefer to sell him now, albeit for a fraction of the £6m that he would usually command. Beschastnykh has fallen out with Santander team-mates and been criticised by the club's president Miguel Angel Diaz. Leeds are to make David O'Leary the highest-paid manager in the history of English football in the next 48 hours. The club confidently expect him to commit himself until 2006 after accepting a deal worth £2m a year, plus bonuses. Dominic Matteo's move to Leeds hit a snag yesterday when a medical revealed a knee injury which will keep him out for two months. But Leeds insist that the £4.75m deal with Liverpool will eventually be resurrected.

fields.headline: Melbourne stages indoor cricket
fields.trailText: Nobody hit the roof but the first one-day cricket international played indoors had everything else, writes Chris Ryan .
fields.body:
Nobody hit the roof but the first one-day cricket international played indoors had everything else, writes Chris Ryan .

Pop music blared between overs, players strode on to a blackened arena lit up by basketball-style spotlights, 496 runs were scored and Steve Waugh, at his best when history is in the offing, smashed a century at more than a run-a-ball. The game's funkiest version, it would seem, is here to stay.

Australia's 94-run win will linger long for the 25,000 fans who trekked out to Colonial Stadium in Melbourne, the city which witnessed Test cricket's birth 123 years ago. "One-day cricket may at last have found a spiritual home," proclaimed the Age newspaper. "Just as Lord's, with its Long Room and stuffy etiquette, embodies Test cricket, Colonial Stadium, something of a giant TV studio, may be the venue through which one-day cricket carves its destiny."

"It's almost a different form of the game indoors," echoed Waugh, who hit 114 from 103 balls. "Maybe in 100 years they'll look back and say this is when one-day cricket really took off."

Waugh's 222-run stand with Michael Bevan (106) lifted Australia to 295 for five, before Ian Harvey (three for 41) and Shane Warne (two for 38) made their detours from county duty worthwhile.

Sawdust was used regularly as players lost their footing. But the pitch played truly and, while rain lashed the city and snow touched nearby Mount Dandenong, not a ball's play was lost.

The second of the three-game series starts tomorrow, with talk already turning to the prospect of a year-round international season. Cricket under a roof has passed its first big test.

webTitle: Wanted: a new sponsor to get in the groove

fields.headline: Wanted: a new sponsor to get in the groove
fields.trailText: Frank Keating What has inestimably given Lord's powerful muscle in striking a satisfactory new deal is the continuingly slick all-round performance by the innovative Channel 4 broadcast team.
fields.body:
That Cornhill's enduring 23-summer sponsorship of home Test cricket has been generous, cosy and mutually sustaining there can be no doubt. Today begins the penultimate match under the insurance company's banner.

There is no hint yet of a replacement sponsor - the asking price is £5m a year for five years - and the England and Wales Cricket Board is blithely content to say that, "while not close to making a deal, we are certainly hoping to have a sponsor lined up by the end of the year". That is fair enough but when exactly are they going to panic?

If Cornhill were too gentlemanly to spell it out, one of their reasons for not renewing the contract was the England team's sorry shows throughout the 90s. Backing losers became tedious, as well as unsmart business.

So a series victory by Nasser Hussain's men this summer is imperative to strengthen the hand of the Lord's negotiators this autumn. That will prove a hundredfold more enticing to any interested big business than the ECB's potty and misbegotten idea that radical, hardcore, indecipherable and high-decibel reggae music during lunch intervals is proof of the dear old game's new commercial cool and "sexiness".

But credit where it is due. What has inestimably given Lord's powerful muscle in striking a satisfactory new deal is the continuingly slick all-round performance by the innovative Channel 4 broadcast team. We may have to live with the interminable - and monotonously unchanging - adverts but the production has been a triumph, in little more than a year dragging coverage into a different age from the BBC's old laissez-faire approach.

By happy coincidence last weekend Peter West celebrated his 80th birthday. Still full of the joys in cottage content in Gloucestershire, and his chuckle riper than ever, he is the oldest surviving alumnus of the BBC commentary box.

His first televised Test was in 1952. "Old Trafford, young Fred [Trueman, 8.4-2-31-8] downwind from the Stretford End and putting the fear of God into Vijay Hazare and his Indians."

For 35 years West was the BBC's freelance and unflappably safe pair of hands as well as, for good measure, ending up as rugby correspondent of the Times. He retired in 1986, he said, "to garden".

Yesterday the new octogenarian chortled: "Oh, sod that, the garden's a mess this summer. It's been non-stop cricket and rugby on the box, so I've just sat mesmerised on my bottom while Pauline's stuck gins-and-tonic in my hand. First that sumptuous Lord's Test, then four terrific days from Old Trafford and, in between, the live rugger from down under - that Sydney match must have been the finest 80 minutes the game has ever staged, certainly that I've ever seen."

More than most West is aware that a series victory by Hussain's men this summer will "up the ante" for the ECB's sponsorship deal. Until his retirement he was a partner in the promotions company West Nally, and he not only "introduced" Benson & Hedges to Lord's, to found the domestic one-day tournament which has endured since 1972, but "derived much satisfaction from presiding over a low-key but subtly effective campaign to get Cornhill's cricket sponsorship on the road". He has no doubt that Channel 4's "marvellously inventive" coverage will be a vital new selling point.

West's first wireless commentary was Warwickshire v South Africa from Edgbaston in 1947. His new wife Pauline was so excited that she rushed up from their basement flat to announce, "My hubby's on the air!" - to which an ancient neighbour inquired, "Really, where's he flying to?"

The first interview West conducted had taken place the summer before at Taunton, Somerset v Gloucestershire. With trepidation he asked hero and eminence Walter Hammond: "Sir, can you tell me the side for your next fixture?"

"'Fuck off!' the hero replied - and that ended my one and only conversation with him." And the grand old trouper laughs fit to bust at the memory.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

200 -249 runs (1pt);

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.standfirst: County Championship points table
fields.trailText: First-class county cricket may be an anachronism and a frequent contradiction in terms, but at least it has a happy knack of subverting cliches. Revenge, for instance, is held to be a dish best savoured cold, yet one of the delights of the revamped championship is the chance it offers for the piping hot sort, as Sussex will doubtless testify.
fields.body:
First-class county cricket may be an anachronism and a frequent contradiction in terms, but at least it has a happy knack of subverting cliches. Revenge, for instance, is held to be a dish best savoured cold, yet one of the delights of the revamped championship is the chance it offers for the piping hot sort, as Sussex will doubtless testify.

Duffed up by an innings at Northampton last weekend, the Martlets were chirping merrily at Eastbourne as Northamptonshire, the Second Division leaders, opted to bat and folded for 110. A season's best six for 41 for Robert Kirtley made him the second English quick bowler to 50 championship wickets.

Sussex, however, slid to 151 for nine as Paul Taylor and Darren Cousins enjoyed their turn on a seamer's pitch that reduced Jason Brown to mortal status and defied everyone to reach 30, bar Chris Adams. On a day when five captains top-scored, he was the model exemplar, 82 not out off 134 balls to earn a workable profit.

Which brings us to that hoary old saw about time waiting for no man. How that must tickle Cousins. In 1991, he took eight wickets against an Australian Young Cricketers XI boasting Greg Blewett and Adam Gilchrist; that Wisden misspelled his name may have been construed as a hint of impending anonymity.

A victim of glass-back syndrome, he endured three spinal operations in 22 months, lost three seasons and was released by Essex in 1998. Only now, fast approaching 29, has he finally found himself: yesterday's two scalps took his first summer's tally at Wantage Road to 42.

Sharing the new ball with Taylor has presumably helped. Taylor, after all, spent four years in the real world after leaving Derbyshire - working for a TV rental firm was one of the more sobering jobs - yet bounced back with Northants, won two Test caps and is still knocking over reputable chaps at 36.

Steve James and Matthew Maynard both hit Sunset Strips - 77 to those too young to recall the splendours of Efrem Zimbalist Jr and Ed "Cookie" Burns - for Glamorgan against Nottinghamshire whereupon the last seven men fell for 59 on a spinner's track expected to console Robert Croft for being dropped from national service.

At Trent Bridge, England Under-19 proved far more resilient against Sri Lanka, an unbroken sixth-wicket stand of 95 between Kadeer Ali and Peter Trego capping Ian Bell and Gary Pratt's 164 for the second.

While Durham have lost more games - six - than any other county, their batsmen seem to be rallying just when it matters. Collective responsibility certainly told against a depleted Somerset attack.

Australia's Simon Katich, ironically, was alone among the top six in not passing 30 as Paul Collingwood and Nick Speak, the most consistent English-born contributors (averaging 24 and 25 respectively at the start to Katich's 42) added 128 en route to 324 for six. Victory would lift the visitors out of the First Division relegation zone.

Ah well, that is one cliche we will have to grow accustomed to suffering.

fields.headline: Such delivers for Essex
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 278-9 v Essex
Points table
fields.trailText: Gloucestershire 278-9 v Essex
fields.body:
Gloucestershire, the inexplicable two-timers of county cricket - on their way to their fourth Lord's limited-overs final on the trot while languishing at the bottom of the championship - never quite sustained their attempts at pleasant Castle Park yesterday to disprove the theories about lack of versatility in their technique.

They finished on 278 for nine and had hinted they would do better than that. But it was an encouraging start to the Colchester festival for Essex, who are well placed for promotion from their runners-up position in the Second Division.

Success is likely to rest with the spinners, and Essex are playing three of them. Peter Such has already taken four wickets, having been on a hat-trick and ambling through overs with that craft that not long ago appeared to be going into obscurity.

Gloucestershire perhaps are banking on Martyn Ball and Jeremy Snape, who is currently batting well and has to be dislodged this morning.

Gloucestershire like to bat first and crack along. Their acquired one-day confidence seemed in evidence during the morning session, though Dominic Hewson disappeared, caught at second slip, and Tim Hancock, approaching his half-century, was out cutting to Graham Napier at cover. Ronnie Irani was the bowler each time.

Essex persevered and were periodically rewarded. Matt Windows and Kim Barnett, effective against Lancashire on Sunday, in turn moved the score on. But eventually Windows jabbed to short leg and Barnett was caught at gully.

At that point there appeared to be plenty to come. Chris Taylor, in his first season of county cricket and impatient to reinforce the acclaim that accompanied his maiden hundred at Lord's, paraded several glorious shots, through mid wicket off Danny Law and guiding Such through the covers, before top-edging spinner Tim Mason to short fine leg.

Mark Alleyne, shrugging off his back problem benefited from edges wide of slips against Irani. After a settled period and eight boundaries Alleyne played on to Ashley Cowan.

Essex retained the initiative during the evening as Jack Russell was caught at silly point after an obdurate stand. Further, Ball was bowled by Such and Jon Lewis perished first ball to short leg.

fields.headline: Butchers give Derbyshire the chop
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 118
Surrey 161-2
Points table
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 118
Surrey 161-2
fields.body:
Most teams find it tough going playing Surrey these days; they have won six County Championship games in a row. Derbyshire, though, had particular trouble coming to terms with one Surrey family. Like vegetarians, a day dealing with Butchers was too much for them.

Gary Butcher, playing his first game of the season in place of the out-of-form Ben Hollioake, produced late swing to take the last four Derbyshire wickets in four balls; his brother Mark then rubbed it in by scoring 78.

It was a humiliating day for Derbyshire against a team for whom they hold little regard after their acrimonious match at Derby in June. They are still suffering the consequences of the eight-point deduction imposed for a supposed poor pitch but there will be one consolation if, as seems likely, they are relegated from the First Division. They will not have to play Surrey next season.

Gary's feat was the first in the championship since 1972 when another Surrey bowler, Pat Pocock, did it on his way to removing seven Sussex batsman in 11 deliveries. Yesterday's dismissals were spread over two overs.

From the last ball of his seventh he had Paul Aldred caught on the rebound by Mark at second slip after Martin Bicknell at third slip had knocked the ball up. To the first and second balls of his next over Bicknell was more attentive, catching Tim Munton and Kevin Dean. Lian Wharton was then struck on the pad pushing forward and was sent on his way by the umpire Ray Julian.

It was a frenetic passage of play, out of context with what had come before. After winning the toss Derbyshire had crawled along at barely two runs an over while Surrey's over rate was below 13 an hour, not helped by an injury to Simon Lacey.

Promoted to open because Steve Titchard damaged his back before the start, he was taken off on a stretcher after twisting his knee while turning for a second run.

While he was off, Bicknell chipped away at the top order in another sustained spell of accurate seam bowling. Lacey returned with a runner at the fall of the sixth wicket in time to watch Butcher run through the tail.

When Surrey batted, Julian gave his fourth leg-before verdict of the day but not before the departing Ian Ward had shared an untroubled opening stand of 137.

Four overs before the 7.15pm close Mark Butcher top-edged a pull to Steve Stubbings off Aldred but already logic suggests another Surrey victory, quite possibly their fourth by an innings this season.

fields.body:
Yorkshire appear to be travelling incognito, as if their plan is to win the County Championship by sneaking up on opponents unrecognised.

The team second to Surrey are without eight front-line players and look so anonymous that spectators might have thought they had stumbled across a second XI match by mistake.

Darren Gough, Craig White, Michael Vaughan and Matthew Hoggard are in the Test squad at Headingley. This does not worry the county unduly. Gough and White, in particular, have made only token contributions this season.

But the fast bowlers, Ryan Sidebottom (hip) and Paul Hutchison (shoulder), are on the treatment table and the captain David Byas is recovering from a knee operation.

Chris Silverwood is playing but he has an inflamed left knee. Yorkshire's title bid has been undermined all season by the lack of a quality spinner; now they can scarcely find a fast bowler. Like a spluttering formula one car, the question is not so much will they win the championship as will they complete the race.

In view of all this Leicestershire, who still hope to finish in the top three, will feel disappointed with a score of 286 for eight before bad light ended play eight overs early.

After winning the toss and choosing to bat on a good pitch, they failed to capitalise either on the favourable conditions or on Yorkshire's malaise. The ball did swing in the first hour but Silverwood and Gavin Hamilton bowled too erratically to take any advantage.

It was the sort of day that might have produced a century or two. But the four Leicestershire batsmen who established themselves perished when they might have progressed.

Yorkshire made two breakthroughs early on. Chris Elstub, playing in his third championship match, had Iain Sutcliffe caught down the leg side; three overs later Gary Fellows had Ben Smith caught at first slip.

Leicestershire then staged the first of two salvage operations. Darren Maddy, with only three 50s before yesterday, is having a poor season but, perhaps encouraged by his bat-carrying effort in the corresponding match last season, scored 66 and put on 108 for the third wicket with Aftab Habib.

It took the best ball of the day to uproot Maddy, who had hit nine fours. It moved away and lifted sharply and the batsman could only fence at it. Simon Guy took a good catch diving to his right.

Habib was more fluent and reached his 50 by lifting the left-arm spinner Ian Fisher over mid-on for six. But then he drove at Silverwood without moving his feet and was caught at second slip.

The captain Vince Wells (27) and Darren Stevens (49) then added 70. But Wells was bowled by the last ball before tea and Stevens, who with six fours, looked good for his 85-ball 49, played a crooked shot and was leg-before.
