fields.headline: Middlesbrough
fields.trailText: Boro fans do not have an easy time of it. Their club was widely mocked after their stunning departure from the Premiership in 1997, after reaching and losing two Cup finals. When foreign footballing mercenaries come under discussion, Emerson, Fabrizzio Ravanelli, and latterly Alen Boksic are always cited. And that's without mentioning the constant southern sniping about the north-east and the general scepticism spluttered in Bryan Robson's direction. Yes, Boro and their fans have it tough. But I'm still backing them to go down.
fields.body:
Boro fans do not have an easy time of it. Their club was widely mocked after their stunning departure from the Premiership in 1997, after reaching and losing two Cup finals. When foreign footballing mercenaries come under discussion, Emerson, Fabrizzio Ravanelli, and latterly Alen Boksic are always cited. And that's without mentioning the constant southern sniping about the north-east and the general scepticism spluttered in Bryan Robson's direction. Yes, Boro and their fans have it tough. But I'm still backing them to go down.

Let's start with Bryan Robson's transfer policy. It may seem hackneyed to say it but bringing ageing stars into your club, whether foreign or not, is not the best way to build a team. Egos are fully formed for a start (step forward, Pauls Gascoigne and Ince), and injuries are increasingly common (hallo Gary Pallister and Colin Cooper). I would not bank on either Christian Karembeu or particularly Alen Boksic reversing this trend.

Boksic is a particularly big gamble because if he does succumb to injury once more, then Robson will probably look to partner Hamilton Ricard with one of his two other summer signings: Noel Whelan and Joseph Desire Job. Neither of these players are proven goalscorers, indeed Whelan has mainly been playing in midfield for the past couple of seasons. It would be a surprise if they were the strikers to help Boro to a goals total higher than last season's meagre 46 (less than Man Utd scored at home by the way).

Then there's the defence. Pallister, Cooper, Gianluca Festa and Steve Vickers, are all in the twilight of their careers, and new signings Karembeu and Paul Okon are in no way natural centre halves. Meanwhile Jason Gavin, the teenage defender tipped to graduate to the first team, made only six appearances last season. Add in the impending departure of Christian Ziege, and things start looking decidedly creaky, especially for a team that plays with three centre-backs.

Finally a word for Bryan Robson. While he has stuck to one formation, 5-3-2 with occasional bursts of 4-4-2, he has rarely shown the tactical prowess to make it work. He never got the best out of Juninho during last season's loan, and his wing-backs, Ziege aside, fail to provide the side with real width.

Robson's position at the Riverside stadium remains unassailable, with Steve Gibson surely the most patient chairman in history, but this could do the club more harm than good. If Robson fails to get the best from his players once more this season, nobody else will get the chance, and by next summer it could be too late.

In: Christian Karembeu (Real Madrid), Paul Okon (Fiorentina), Mark Crossley (Nottingham Forest), Noel Whelan (Coventry), Joseph-Desire Job (Lens), Alen Boksic (Lazio)

Out: Ben Roberts (Charlton), Paul Gascoigne (Everton).

Odds: 200/1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction: 18th

Agree? Disagree? Want to beat our pundits around the head with a meat pie? Send us your opinion at editor@footballunlimited.co.uk.

fields.headline: Book trade news
fields.standfirst: The e-book revolution gathers momentum; change is in the air for mind, body spirit imprint Element; Penguin faces legal problems over katie.com and Dorling Kindersley;  and Sir Alec Guiness's diaries brought forward
fields.trailText: In the first of an exclusive new column offering the latest news from the book trade, the e-book revolution gathers momentum; change is in the air for mind, body spirit imprint Element; Penguin faces legal problems over katie.com and Dorling Kindersley; and Sir Alec Guiness's diaries brought forward
fields.body:
Has the e-book arrived? This is the question nervous publishers have been asking themselves this week, after Microsoft unveiled the latest version of Microsoft Reader, the software for laptops, PCs and hand-held devices which aims to transfer the experience of reading from the written page to the computer screen.

The move, described by Microsoft as equivalent to the creation of the first mass-produced motorcar, was timed to coincide with the launch of its eBookStore by the US internet bookseller Barnes & Noble.com. "This is a major milestone for the publishing industry and book lovers alike," said Dick Brass, vice president for technology development at Microsoft. "Anyone wondering about electronic reading needs only to spend some time with a good eBook on Microsoft Reader to see what the excitement is all about."

Suggestions that the software could do to publishers what Napster and the MP3 have done to the music industry were rebutted by Microsoft, which said that it had joined up with the Association of American Publishers to fight digital piracy. The computer giant promised to put a "significant financial endowment" into creating new technology to identify illegal content on the net.

In the US a number of publishers have jumped on the e-book bandwagon in recent months, including the giants Random House and Time Warner, both of which have established their own digital imprints. "I believe that the eBook will change the whole notion of how we receive and enjoy information and entertainment," said a bullish Laurence Kirshbaum, chairman and CEO of Time Warner Trade Publishing.

This latest "major milestone" was greeted with typical stiff upper lips in the UK, where publishers have yet to be convinced that the e-book will not go the same way as the ill-fated CD-rom.

However, Microsoft's hyperbole aside, the fact that consumers the world over can now download books such as Michael Crichton's Disclosure or Kathy Reichs's Deadly Decisions for as little as $10 and read them using their preferred e-book software should not go unnoticed for too much longer in the UK. One of the books being heavily promoted by Barnes & Noble.com, Jackie Collins's Lethal Seduction, will not be available in the UK in traditional book form until October. Replace Jackie Collins with JK Rowling and Lethal Seduction with Harry Potter Five and the potential threat is obvious.

One British publisher which has decided to take a chance on e-books is the academic group Taylor & Francis. They recently signed up with a US e-publishing company, Versaware, to publish new digital e-book formats alongside their conventional printed books.

The company, whose imprints include Routledge and Garland, also intends to have an e-book version of its entire back catalogue by 2001. When asked why the group was taking this step now, managing director Roger Horton said "the eBook is here, and the widespread use of the internet makes it much more accessible. We cannot continue to dip our toes into the digital stream... We had to take control of our content, its availability and distribution to position ourselves for the future."

As if this was not enough for publishers, the Bookseller has reported that literary agents are also getting in on the act. According to the trade paper, Richard Gollner of Radala & Associates is to publish The Wisdom of Crocodiles by Paul Hoffman on 29 August under his agency's own imprint, Big Time Press. According to Mr Gollner, the decision to publish was an experiment - but he warned that, with cheaper and easier printing methods now available, it was an experiment that could easily be repeated. In a show of net nous, the book - a section of which has already been made into an eponymous film starring Jude Law - is being promoted by a fiendishly difficult online competition at www.1234.com.

Meanwhile, mind, body and spirit publisher Element, which has been suffering a long period of bad karma, could be about to join Fourth Estate at HarperCollins, Rupert Murdoch's rarely harmonic global publishing empire. The Bookseller reported that newly installed chief executive Victoria Barnsley has been courting the struggling purveyor of all things yin and yang. Ms Barnsley, it seems, would like to put it alongside HarperCollins' very own mind, body, spirit imprint, Thorsons.

The rumour, if it proves to be true, should be of interest to Eileen Campbell, the publisher credited with being the inspiration behind Thorsons. Ms Campbell left HarperCollins earlier this year for Penguin, where her brief was to nurture a mind, body, spirit list. Penguin, which distributes Element's books in the UK, is thought to have backed away from an attempt to acquire Element itself.

But then Penguin has been busy of late, not least in the company of lawyers. Fresh from the David Irving trial, the nation's favourite publisher has received a legal challenge from the owner of the domain name katie.com, after releasing a book in the US with the same title. The original Katie has been forced to take down her site and replace it with an open letter to Penguin, in which she says that the book was originally to have been called girl.com - presumably until someone twigged that it was an address for adult content.

It seems Penguin could face further legal problems arising from the closure of Dorling Kindersley Family Learning (DKFL), the direct-selling arm of the company acquired by Penguin earlier this year. According to a report in Publishing News, a number of DKFL distributors, who feel they have been left high and dry by Penguin's decision to close the unit, are exploring their legal options. The numbers involved were not disclosed, but there were more than 30,000 such distributors when the division was culled.

But it has not been a wholly bad week for Penguin. The publisher has announced that it is bringing forward the publication of Sir Alec Guinness's last volume of diaries, the prophetically titled A Positively Final Appearance. The book was originally scheduled for late September publication, but has been brought forward a month in the wake of the actor's death. Copies could be in bookshops as early as this week.

webTitle: Fans won't be fooled by clubs' charter

fields.headline: Fans won't be fooled by clubs' charter
fields.standfirst: Long-suffering supporters should not get too excited by the Premier League's belated recognition of their rights, warns Gwyn Topham
fields.trailText: Long-suffering supporters should not get too excited by the Premier League's belated recognition of their rights, warns Gwyn Topham.
fields.body:
Football, more than any other business, can pretty much count on its clients' continued support. Today's Premier League charter represents a long-overdue recognition by clubs that their fans' loyalty has been scantly repaid.

Like the cleaning rota pinned inside the doors of toilets in certain pub chains, the important thing is not so much that customers' needs are met but that they are seen to be met. And so while fans may be still be paying inflated prices to watch English football - cruelly exposed during Euro 2000 as not quite what it was cracked up to be - the charter should give us all the warm reassurance of a spotless urinal.

While Premier League clubs have been anxious to portray their new agreement as legislation with teeth - a legally binding document that could incur fines for offenders - the small print is telling by its absence.

The draft charter says that there should be "a broad range of ticket prices"; that "at least 5% of tickets to each game [go] to non-season-ticket holders"; that there should be "support for disabled supporters and their carers". All very honourable, but hardly holding clubs to task.

Other specifications amount to little more than a promise not to rob supporters blind. Few of football's new middle-class fan base might have realised a charter was needed to guarantee reduced admission to replays of abandoned games, including those abandoned before kick off; or to ensure that a club should "offer refunds on merchandise in accordance with its legal obligations".

And under the sections relating to away support, loyalty, customer service and community activity, large chunks carry the proviso "to be decided by the individual club".

It would be churlish to be entirely dismissive. Even the fact that football authorities are registering supporters' grievances at such ongoing abuses as overcharging away fans is progress.

But charters are invariably associated in the public mind with shoddy service - where are they more vaunted than the railways, the only other British institution that could compete in terms of overcharging and customer discomfort?

The very term charter is redolent of the early Major years. Back then, it was already clear to the paying public that clubs were taking liberties with their loyal followers. Until actions follow the fine words, the Premier League's belated move is only likely to be perceived as so much spin.

gwyn.topham@theguardian.com

fields.headline: 'Nasty' Nick evicted
fields.trailText: Big Brother bad boy Nick Bateman's underhand tactics finally caught up with him late this afternoon, as Channel 4 and the show's producers threw him off the programme.
fields.body:
Big Brother bad boy Nick Bateman's underhand tactics finally caught up with him late this afternoon, as Channel 4 and the show's producers threw him off the programme.

Nick was evicted from the Big Brother house at 5pm "for persistent infringement of the Big Brother rules", according to a statement issued by Channel 4. Under the programme's rules, a replacement will be selected to take his place. But the Big Brother producers said the weekly eviction would go ahead as planned tomorrow night, meaning that either Craig or Nichola will be voted out of the house by the public.

The move followed an extraordinary day of drama that went out live on the Big Brother website, as Nick was confronted by the other housemates about his duplicitous behaviour. This followed a search of his suitcase in the early hours, which unearthed pieces of paper on which Nick had written the names of different contestants.

He had been showing different pieces of paper to different housemates, in an attempt to sway their nominations. Mel, Craig and Tom all confessed to having been shown names by Nick.

The show's producers had already issued a verbal and written warning to all the Big Brother contestants stressing that they faced eviction for continuing to contravene the rules about vote-rigging. The rules forbid Big Brother housemates from talking about the weekly nominations for eviction and tactical voting.

webTitle: William secures place at St Andrews

fields.headline: William secures place at St Andrews
fields.trailText: Prince William learnt today that he has secured three A-levels and a place at St Andrews University to study art history.
fields.body:
Prince William learnt today that he has secured three A-levels and a place at St Andrews University to study art history.

William received an A grade in geography, a B in art history and a C in biology. Although he is currently taking part in exercises in the Belize jungle with the Welsh Guards, his former housemaster at Eton told him the news this morning.

He was reportedly "delighted and relieved" at the news. His father, Prince Charles, commented: "I know how hard William worked to achieve these excellent results and I am very proud that he has done so well." He has emailed his congratulations to his son.

A B in history and a C in French were sufficient to give Prince Charles a place at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he achieved a lower second.

The 18-year-old prince will take a gap year before arriving at St Andrews in 2001, including a stint on an educational project this autumn.

His near-contemporary, Peter Phillips - the Princess Royal's son - recently passed a BSc in exercise and sports sciences at Exeter university. His sister, Zara Phillips, apparently wants to study equine physiology.

The 18-year-old prince will take a gap year before arriving at St Andrews in 2001, including a stint on an educational project this autumn. His near-contemporary, Peter Phillips - the Princess Royal's son - recently passed a BSc in exercise and sports sciences at Exeter university. His sister, Zara Phillips, apparently wants to study equine physiology.

fields.headline: Familiarity with A-levels breeds contempt
fields.standfirst: It will take time to set a new gold standard when A-levels are replaced by new qualifications, argues Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor
fields.trailText: It will take time to set a new gold standard when A-levels are replaced by new qualifications, argues Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor.
fields.body:
Is the country full of bright young things clutching a handful of straight As? It would seem so: many more sixth-formers will be celebrating today than 10 years ago.

Nearly nine out of 10 A-levels are now at A-E grade and 17.8% are A grades (and, astonishingly, 25% in Northern Ireland).

Grade inflation, like its economic counterpart, is a troubling subject. A very little of it each year is a healthy sign, but once it begins to rise too sharply, people start to worry. Ruth Lea, policy director of the Institute of Directors, has seized upon the year-on-year rise as "endemic and rampant grade inflation".

She has a point. At the current rate of improvement, everyone will receive straight As by 2122. Each wave of young Britons may appear lazier, more likely to play truant and in most respects inferior to their European neighbours, but for one glorious summer day we hail them as brighter than ever before. Tumbledown schools and insufficient resources are abruptly forgotten.

It's good news. But the education secretary, David Blunkett, who has staked his own job on substantial improvements in numeracy and literacy among younger pupils, just cannot win. If A-level standards fell, he would be vilified; when they rise, doubts are cast on their quality.

In its ceaseless effort to "raise standards" and rate pupils at every stage of their school career, New Labour must exceed expectations every year or lose the confidence of the electorate.

Fortuitously, all this is about to change. Today's candidates are among the last generation to sit A-levels in their present form. The exams are to be split into two levels, AS and A2, and supplemented by the new Advanced Extension Award (similar to the S-level), vocational A-levels (which will replace GNVQs) and Key Skills.

With an array of new standards to attain and acronyms to grasp, it will be a while before the "gold standard" is re-established. It will also take a few years for students to acquire the same familiarity with the demands of A-levels that they have shown this year. Without past papers and model answers to swot from - and, according to reports today, often lacking the necessary books - future candidates may find the new system harder than they expect.

webTitle: Record A-level pass rates lead to row over standards

fields.headline: Record A-level pass rates lead to row over standards
fields.standfirst:
Education special report: A level results 2000
Full table of results
fields.trailText: An argument over exam standards broke out last night as figures released in advance of today's A-level results showed another record pass rate.
fields.body:
An argument over exam standards broke out last night as figures released in advance of today's A-level results showed another record pass rate.

The 18th consecutive rise in pass rates saw 89.1% of A-level entries achieve grades A-E, an increase of 0.6% on 1999. The number of A grades rose by 0.3% to 17.8%.

The increases were powered by girls, who continued to extend their lead over boys, who have stalled. Girls have won a greater proportion of passes at A-level since 1992 but for the first time this year they won more A grades.

Though ministers and teaching unions hailed the rise in grades as a sign of academic progress, the Institute of Directors condemned the improvements as "farcical".

The argument was fuelled by the popularity of subjects such as media, film and television studies. Entries for science, modern languages and geography fell - French by 13.5%. There was an 11.4% rise in those taking computer and information technology.

In the penultimate year for the old-style post-16 curriculum, more A-levels were taken than in 1999 despite a fall in the number of 18 year-olds. About 270,000 candidates will receive their results today.

Since 1990 the proportion of A-E grades has risen from 77% to 89.1% and A grades from 11.6% to 17.8%. In 1982, 68% of candidates achieved A-E grades. If present trends continued, all candidates would achieve grades A-E by 2047.

Ruth Lea, policy director at the IoD, said "endemic grade inflation" was making it harder for employers to discriminate between able and less able students.

Nick Seaton, of the Campaign for Real Education, said universities were complaining that students were not up to the standard of 10 years ago. The Tories called for a review of standards and the introduction of an A-starred A level.

But David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said Miss Lea was "in danger of bordering on the hysterical".

He said: "I think both she and the Campaign for Real Education are undermining the achievements of students and their teachers in a way that I find absolutely disgraceful."

webTitle: Leader: Boys are lagging behind in education

fields.headline: The female factor
fields.standfirst:
Boys are lagging behind in education
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The advance of women continues. Today's A-level results show girls moving ahead of boys for the first time in the proportion of A grades achieved. They have been ahead in the proportion of passes since 1992, but now they are ahead in the top grade too
fields.body:
The advance of women continues. Today's A-level results show girls moving ahead of boys for the first time in the proportion of A grades achieved. They have been ahead in the proportion of passes since 1992, but now they are ahead in the top grade too. The old pattern, in which girls were bunched round the middle with fewer failures but fewer top grades than boys, has changed.

Even more interesting for social historians will be to monitor the way in which this superior female performance has shifted up the age group over time. Four decades ago girls were better than boys at the 11-plus, prompting education administrators to set a lower grammar-school entry point for boys to ensure equal gender numbers. But in those days boys still did better at 16. Now they lag behind at GCSE and A-level. Only the universities remain to be conquered, where still a higher proportion of males than females wins firsts - though this gap too is narrowing.

There is even more good news for women in that all A-level courses will switch to a modular approach from this September - 60% are linear at present, depending on an exam at the end of two years. The modular approach, under which pupils are tested over time, rather than in one big bang at the end, plays to the strength of women, who characteristically work more systematically than men.

Reformers anxious to boost the chances of boys should not resist this change, which is a much better way of educating young people, as the universities have demonstrated in the last three decades. There is no quick fix to the growing gender gap, but it would help boys' performance if more male graduates could be attracted into the profession. Better pay should help.

Today's results mark the 18th consecutive year of an amazing improvement: from 68% achieving a pass in 1982 to 89.l% this year. Cynics will have a field day, not least because the examination boards have made an extrapolation: at this rate no one will fail in 2047 and every candidate obtain an A grade by 2122.

As they rightly emphasised, this was not a projection: failure is not eradicated. One reason for the improvement is that the old system required a 30% failure rate: now, sensibly, those who reach the required standard are awarded the grade. Another is better teaching and monitoring. Like four-minute milers, A-level pupils respond to better preparation and training by raising their game.

webTitle: Scottish qualifications fiasco 'will always place a question mark over this year'

fields.headline: Scottish qualifications fiasco 'will always place a question mark over this year'
fields.standfirst: Education special report: A level results 2000
fields.trailText: The breakdown in the Scottish qualifications authority system has cost one official his job, led to calls for the resignation of the education minister, Sam Galbraith, thrown the university admissions process into chaos, and left thousands of pupils unsure of their future.
fields.body:
Lawrence Broadley opened his school exam results last Thursday to find two blank spaces where his physics and graphics grades should have been.

When the 16-year-old from St Ninian's high school in Giffnock, near Glasgow, called the Scottish qualifications authority to ask for an explanation he was told he had failed the two subjects at which he had previously excelled.

For the Broadleys it was the first inkling that something might have gone wrong with the results for the class of 2000.

"I can't accept the results," said Lawrence, who had scored 86% in his physics prelim. "I want to study aeronautical engineering and I need physics for that."

It was a similar picture across Scotland. More than 6,000 results did not arrive on time, and others were incomplete or made no sense. The breakdown in the qualifications system has cost one official his job, led to calls for the resignation of the education minister, Sam Galbraith, thrown the university admissions process into chaos, and left thousands of pupils unsure of their future.

Lindsay Paterson, professor of education at Edinburgh University, said: "There will always be a question mark over this year. No matter what is done, people are going to have in the back of their mind that there was a problem with the results in the year 2000."

The SQA, whose job it was to collate and distribute the results, said yesterday that management failure was to blame and announced that two members of staff had been suspended.

The SQA chief executive, Ron Tuck, resigned at the weekend and the agency is checking all 147,000 results. It continues to insist the validity of the results is not in question and that the main problem has been incomplete data.

But teachers, parents and educational analysts say the entire system has been compromised and the SQA should have seen it coming. Teachers have been warning for more than a year that there were problems with the new Higher Still, the most radical school qualification system for 50 years; and there have been reports of retired markers with no experience of the system being drafted in to mark the original papers.

Lawrence Broadley's principal, James McVitie, has started his own assessment of the results, checking each pupil's grades against their previous performance. "Last year we had the best exam results in the school's history but this year it looks like there's going to be a gap between what we predicted and what some young people attained," he said.

That gap could have a drastic impact on university admission and careers. All but two UK universities suspended admissions from Scottish pupils pending the results of this week's reassessment of results. Yesterday the university admissions service, Ucas, said it had been advised by the SQA that all complete certificates from Scottish pupils should be considered valid and to proceed with admissions on that basis.

Pupils with incomplete certificates will not know until Friday, however, what their true results are, and there are fears they will lose out in the university clearing process to A-level pupils in England and Wales whose results come out tomorrow.

A spokesman for Ucas, Ross Hayman, said: "We are working hard to make sure that does not happen."

fields.headline: Students shun science and languages
fields.standfirst:
More pupils may be staying on but fewer are choosing subjects from the curriculum favoured by the government
Education special report: A level results 2000
fields.trailText: More pupils may be staying on but fewer are choosing subjects from the curriculum favoured by the government.
fields.body:
More students are staying in education after GCSEs but they do not necessarily study what ministers would like them to, information released last night by the exam boards shows.

A new post-16 curriculum is being introduced from September, with more emphasis on vocational qualifications and encouragement for students to take a greater mix of subjects.

But this year there were significant falls in those completing vocational advanced GNVQ courses - a fall of 10,749 to 80,290, and a change which worries the Confederation of British Industry. Entries at A-level in sciences and modern languages also fell - both key subjects which also fell in 1999.

In their penultimate year, traditional A-levels showed their enduring popularity.

The number of A-level entries was up slightly by 1,298 to 784,990, even though the number of 18-year-olds in Britain has fallen by 7,500 to 606,000.

AS-level entries, which will play a much greater part in the revamped system, increased by 6,600 to 74,950 this year.

A-level French entries fell by nearly 3,000, or 13.5%, to 18,221. German declined by al most 1,000 (8.9%) to 8,692.

In May the Nuffield Languages Inquiry, headed by Sir Trevor McDonald, published a lengthy report warning of the dire implications of Britain's "deplorable monolingualism".

The inquiry's assistant secretary, Alwena Lamping, said last night: "This is very worrying and is a continuation of the trend we foresaw in our inquiry.

"More than 90% of pupils already drop languages at the age of 16 and in a few years there will be a serious lack of specialist linguists in the UK."

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "Students are voting with their feet and dropping French, German, and other traditional subjects. The significant drop in modern language entries is evidence of a European isolationist attitude."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "At a time when the country needs the maximum number of well-qualified modern linguists, it is perverse that A-level entry is decreasing."

Paul Sokoloff, convenor of the Joint Council for General Qualifications, representing the exam boards of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, said he hoped more students would take a modern language as a one of the four or five subjects they take at AS- level in the first year of sixth form.

But Mr Dunford has already reported that pupils going into the sixth form next year seem far more likely to choose subjects like media studies and psychology.

They were among those showing an increase in A-level entries this year, psychology by 5%, and media, film and TV studies by 7.4%. Psychology entries at AS-level rose by 29%.

Mark Reid, of the British Film Institute's education department, said: "The increase in the number of youngsters taking media studies reflects the strong interest in our cultural life.

"It is completely wrong to suggest that this is a subject which is not as challenging as others".

But computing and IT A-level entries rose by nearly 2,000 or 11.4% to 19,099. At AS-level entries rose by 25%.

The most popular subjects were general studies, English, maths, biology and chemistry, with the top three remaining unchanged on last year. But of those, only general studies showed an increase in entries year on year.

Geography was another big loser at A-level, with entries falling by 11.9%.

There were increases in those taking A-levels in art and design, business studies, his tory, religious studies, physical education, technology and Welsh.

But entries fell in classics, communications, economics, expressive arts, home economics, law, physics, politics and sociology.

Nick Seaton, of the Campaign for Real Education, said: "Youngsters need modern languages and geography to make their way in the world. The vast majority of people think media studies a waste of time."

One of the arguments used by independent schools to justify their disproportionate intake to top universities is that more of their candidates take the harder A-level subjects.

But Mr Solokoff said great efforts were made to ensure that A-level subjects were equally demanding.

In a further twist to the gender divide, girls do better than boys in maths and physics but worse in French and Spanish. But more boys take maths and physics and more girls take the two languages, which may to some extent explain the discrepancy.

At advanced GNVQ, 15.4% of candidates won distinctions, compared with 13.5% last year. Entries increased for computing and performing arts and dropped for business and leisure and tourism.

webTitle: Fresh rescue bid fails to reach submarine crew

fields.headline: Fresh rescue bid fails to reach submarine crew
fields.trailText: Underwater rescue capsules again failed to reach the 118 seamen trapped on a Russian nuclear submarine today.
fields.body:
Underwater rescue capsules again failed to reach the 118 seamen trapped on a Russian nuclear submarine today.

But there was renewed hope for the crew of the Kursk when new Russian estimates suggested that there may be up to three weeks of oxygen in the vessel.

Evidence analysed today suggested that the submarine may have been sunk by a massive torpedo explosion which shattered large areas of the vessel, leaving few sailors time to escape. Navy officials said that there were now no signs of life on the vessel, but insisted that some of the crew could still be alive.

Rescue capsules trying to link up with the submarine for the past three days were again driven back today by racing currents and sand on the dark seabed.

The Russian prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, said today that the situation was "close to catastrophic".

A British rescue team was tonight heading towards the scene by ship, but it is not expected to arrive until Sunday.

The Russian navy has given contradictory estimates of how long the Kursk's oxygen could last. It currently suggests that there could be up to three weeks of air trapped inside the hull.

Film of the submarine studied today revealed massive damage from the front of the vessel to the conning tower. The damage would have sent the vessel crashing to the bottom in seconds.

The control room where most of the crew work is below the tower, suggesting many sailors had no time to escape when the submarine went down.

"The accident happened so quickly we can say it was like a flash," said navy spokesman Captain Igor Dygalo.

US submarines monitoring Russian navy exercises at the time when the Kursk was lost detected two explosions, according to Russian press reports. The second explosion was much larger than the first, the reports said.

The Russian navy refused to confirm the reports, but officers have said an explosion in the torpedo compartment at the front of the submarine apparently caused the Kursk to sink. A likely scenario was that one torpedo exploded, setting off a much bigger explosion in the loaded torpedo compartment.

The damage apparently included the submarine's internal escape capsule located in the conning tower, making it impossible to use, Captain Dygalo said.

Defence minister Igor Sergeyev said authorities were still investigating the possibility of a collision.

After insisting for days that western aid was not needed, the Russian government asked Britain and Norway to for help. Two Norwegian ships were today taking divers and the British mini-submarine to the rescue area.

The reversal apparently came after President Vladimir Putin spoke with US President Bill Clinton yesterday before ordering his navy to seek help.

Russian officials refused to say why the Russian plane which flew the British mini-sub to Norway was not flown to a Russian airfield closer to the rescue site.

The rescue capsules currently at the scene are trying to latch onto one of the Kursk's hatches. The effort was being frustrated by the strong currents and almost zero visibility.

Four Russian rescue capsules are taking turns to try to reach the Kursk, each spending up to five hours submerged. Success of the rescue operation is dependent not only on latching on to a hatch, which can only open from the inside, but also on whether any survivors are able to open it.

A British rescue team was tonight heading towards the scene by ship, but it is not expected to arrive until Sunday. The Russian navy has given contradictory estimates of how long the Kursk's oxygen could last. It currently suggests that there could be up to three weeks of air trapped inside the hull. Film of the submarine studied today revealed massive damage from the front of the vessel to the conning tower. The damage would have sent the vessel crashing to the bottom in seconds. The control room where most of the crew work is below the tower, suggesting many sailors had no time to escape when the submarine went down. "The accident happened so quickly we can say it was like a flash," said navy spokesman Captain Igor Dygalo. US submarines monitoring Russian navy exercises at the time when the Kursk was lost detected two explosions, according to Russian press reports. The second explosion was much larger than the first, the reports said. The Russian navy refused to confirm the reports, but officers have said an explosion in the torpedo compartment at the front of the submarine apparently caused the Kursk to sink. A likely scenario was that one torpedo exploded, setting off a much bigger explosion in the loaded torpedo compartment. The damage apparently included the submarine's internal escape capsule located in the conning tower, making it impossible to use, Captain Dygalo said. Defence minister Igor Sergeyev said authorities were still investigating the possibility of a collision. After insisting for days that western aid was not needed, the Russian government asked Britain and Norway to for help. Two Norwegian ships were today taking divers and the British mini-submarine to the rescue area. The reversal apparently came after President Vladimir Putin spoke with US President Bill Clinton yesterday before ordering his navy to seek help. Russian officials refused to say why the Russian plane which flew the British mini-sub to Norway was not flown to a Russian airfield closer to the rescue site. The rescue capsules currently at the scene are trying to latch onto one of the Kursk's hatches. The effort was being frustrated by the strong currents and almost zero visibility. Four Russian rescue capsules are taking turns to try to reach the Kursk, each spending up to five hours submerged. Success of the rescue operation is dependent not only on latching on to a hatch, which can only open from the inside, but also on whether any survivors are able to open it.

fields.headline: Ferguson 'delighted' at Everton return
fields.trailText: Duncan Ferguson admitted he was "delighted to be back" at Everton after finally completing his £3.75m move from Newcastle today.
fields.body:
Duncan Ferguson admitted he was "delighted to be back" at Everton after finally completing his £3.75m move from Newcastle today.

At a Goodison Park news conference this afternoon, he said: "I couldn't imagine it in pre-season. I was, at the time, very happy at Newcastle but since then an opportunity has arisen to come back and I'm delighted. All the fans know how I feel about the club.

"There was never a doubt in my mind once Newcastle had decided they no longer required my services. When I first came here the fans just took to me right away. Everton's in my blood - it has always been there and this opportunity is fantastic for myself."

Ferguson - who has signed a five-year contract - admitted his two seasons at Newcastle had been badly affected by injury but insisted he was now "100% fit".

He said: "I haven't played enough games because of injuries but you just have to get on with it. That's what happened at Newcastle. Now I just want to keep fit for selection. I'll have to do a bit of training but should be ready in a couple of weeks.

"My fitness has been a worry but I've passed a medical today."

The giant Scot washed his hands of the politics of his transfer from Newcastle, which Everton yesterday claimed had broken down. "I don't won't to get dragged into that situation. I never asked for a transfer," he said. "I was happy before at Everton and I am more than happy to come back."

Manager Walter Smith was equally pleased at the return of the striker he had managed both at Goodison Park and Ibrox. "We dropped a few positions at the end of last season when we lost Kevin Campbell," he said. "We needed cover. When it became public knowledge Duncan was available, we were the first club in for him. I was disappointed in the manner we lost him. I think all the supporters are delighted Duncan is coming back."

Yesterday Ferguson had insisted - through his agent Dennis Roach - that he wanted to stay at St James' Park and fight for his place. But the Scottish striker's future at Newcastle began to look increasingly in doubt when manager Bobby Robson launched an astonishing attack on Roach earlier today.

"If this deal does not go through it will not be because of either of the clubs or because of Duncan Ferguson - it will solely be because of the agent," Robson told the Daily Mail. "He has tried to hijack the transfer for his own personal gain, no more, no less. In fact, he has put his own personal gain in front of the interests of his client."

"I have already spoken to my chairman about exposing this issue on the back page of the papers to let people know about the parasites in the game," he added.

Robson also blamed Roach after Newcastle failed to complete the capture of Danish striker Peter Lovenkrands this summer. The former England manager claimed "the deal was as good as done" before Roach "had gone to the player and taken him to Glasgow to sign for Rangers instead".

fields.headline: Kewell signs new Leeds contract
fields.trailText: Harry Kewell has signed a new improved contract that will keep him at Elland Road until 2004. The Australian forward, who scored 17 goals for Leeds last season, has agreed a deal reportedly worth £25,000 a week.
fields.body:
Harry Kewell has signed a new improved contract that will keep him at Elland Road until 2004. The Australian forward, who scored 17 goals for Leeds last season, has agreed a deal reportedly worth £25,000 a week.

Kewell said he was delighted to agree a new contract with the club he has played for since he was a schoolboy. "I'm so pleased with the deal," he said. "As I've said before I love the club and the fans, and I love playing for Leeds United. There was no doubt I wouldn't sign."

Speculation this summer had linked Kewell with a move to Serie A, but the PFA Young Player of the Year insists he can achieve all his aims at Elland Road. "As for other clubs, I never heard anything other than rumours", he said. "All I was concerned about was staying with Leeds because we're going places.

"You can see how far we've come over the last three years - fifth, fourth and last season third - so there's only another two more places left and that's what we will be aiming for. We all feel we can do something this season. We need it to spur us on and if we do, then it will be perfect."

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale announced the deal earlier today. "This proves Harry's committed to Leeds and I'm absolutely delighted," Ridsdale told the club's official website. "I'm thrilled that such an exceptional talent is staying at Elland Road."

Kewell joins fellow first team players Ian Harte, Gary Kelly, Stephen McPhail and England keeper Nigel Martyn in agreeing an extension to his contract.

fields.headline: Manchester United
fields.trailText: Manchester United have won the Premiership six times in the last eight years. They have the best manager, the best squad and an insatiable lust for trophies. Last season they finished 18 points clear of the flailing pack. And now - with the signing of Barthez, and the return of Johnsen, Blomqvist and Brown from injury - they will be even stronger.
fields.body:
Manchester United have won the Premiership six times in the last eight years. They have the best manager, the best squad and an insatiable lust for trophies. Last season they finished 18 points clear of the flailing pack. And now - with the signing of Barthez, and the return of Johnsen, Blomqvist and Brown from injury - they will be even stronger.

So why should this Premiership season be anything other than another United procession?

Hang on a second, splutter the pseudo-statisticians: United have a pattern of winning two championships and then losing one (93 and 94, 96 and 97, then 99 and 00). Surely this year the Gods are due to look favourably on another side? Yeah right. And I suppose United will lose a big-name player for a large part of the season - like they did with Cantona during 95 and Keane in 98 - and finish second by a solitary point - like they did in both those years - too.

And what about their poor defensive record? snipe the more astute critics. Well, what about it? So what if Silvestre is suspect, Irwin is ageing and both Nevilles aren't the players that Kevin Keegan thought they were? And so what if United conceded more goals than most of their immediate rivals last year? Football is often a trade-off between attack and defence, and United prefer to concentrate on attack - and justifiably so. And it's worth pointing out that United's defence is unlikely to be as porous this season in any case, with the addition of Barthez and the return of Johnsen and Brown to complement the formidable Stam.

Yet hopefully United's coronation won't be completed by Easter this year. They will have one eye on regaining the Champions League, and there won't be any mid-season break to Brazil to recharge the batteries while the rest of the Premiership suffers on heavy January pitches either.

But while Liverpool and Chelsea both have good shouts - and Arsenal and Leeds reasonable ones - you can't look beyond the Mighty Reds. Look again at their level of success, their squad, and the way most of the Premiership travels to Old Trafford thinking not whether they can win, but how they can keep the score down, and you'll realise - reluctantly, like the rest of us who would love the title to be shared around - that United are probably going to win it again.

In Fabien Barthez (Monaco), David Fox (Exeter) Out John Curtis (Blackburn), Paul Wheatcroft (Bolton), Danny Higginbotham (Derby County), Nick Culkin (Bristol Rovers), Jordi Cruyff (Alaves)

Odds 8/11

fields.headline: Dunc, Funk and Junk
fields.trailText: BIG DUNC SENDS LOCK-IN ROCKIN'
fields.body:
BIG DUNC SENDS LOCK-IN ROCKIN'

Locked in a bedroom for a considerable period of time without any contact with the outside world, the Fiver was today set a task by Big Mother. Sadly, "Give us your dirty pants and I'll wash them" was not the sort of thing that appealed, and so the Fiver built a telescope instead and turned its powerful viewing facility onto Goodison Park. You'll never guess what we saw

That's right, it was Big ring-kissin' Duncan Ferguson, sitting behind a table festooned with microphones and drinking water. It looked like he was there to announce his £3.75m transfer back to Goodison Park. Indeed it sounded like it too - our telescope has a microphone on it, alright? We even heard Dunc say that he was "delighted to be back" and that "Everton's in my blood - it has always been." But surely that couldn't be true? After all, only yesterday that nice Mr Roach, Big Dunc's agent, had insisted: "Duncan will not be going anywhere."

What's an email update disgusted by the untruths in football to do? Keep hoarding dirty pants for a start. But we must also never shy away from speaking our mind. Just like the venerable Bobby Robson esq. This morning, with the Ferguson deal on the rocks, Mr Robson called Mr Roach a "parasite" in the national press. "[Mr Roach] has tried to hijack the transfer for his own personal gain, no more, no less," Bobby told the Daily Mail. Lo and behold, by lunchtime, the deal was back on. With that sort of rhetoric, Bobby can bunk up in our bedroom any time.

GEORGE: MY WINGER HELL

Arsenal's George Graham, the manager of Tottenham, loves tricky wingers. That's why he's trying to buy Boudewijn Zenden (he's like Aston Villa legend David Ginola except not as good, Spurs fans). But sadly for George, the £8m-rated Barcelona trickster won't be coming to White Hart Lane, because Zenden - the only professional footballer whose name is used in schools as a touch-typing exercise - today got his agent and father Pierre to tell everyone that he's staying at Barca. Unless he joins Lazio, but that's another story.

"A transfer to England is not our priority at the moment," sniffed Zenden senior. "That's the way it is and the situation won't change. Barcelona want Boudewijn to stay. But if he goes anywhere, it will be Rome." Zenden's lack of interest is also bad news for Chelsea, who have been chasing the floppy-fringed Dutchman too. But as they've got a load of other fancy new players to enjoy, we're saving our sympathy for poor George.

Still, at least Graham can still rely upon the magical services of Ruel Fox. The 32-year-old winger looked as though he was moving on to West Brom this morning for a walloping £150,000 fee, but everything fell through when he failed to agree a financial settlement with Spurs. This disagreement was a bit like the one involving Duncan Ferguson, Everton and Newcastle - the only difference being nobody really cared. "I don't want to hear another word about it," insouciant Baggies boss Gary Megson shrugged this afternoon, proving our point.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Vegard Heggem, my regular room-mate, has been replaced by Vidar Riseth, and things just won't be the same without Vegard ha ha! Vidar is a little forgetful, even though he won't admit it himself. We stood outside the door of our hotel room discussing who had the door key. Vidar was 'only' 110 per cent sure that he didn't have the key to the door. While I was 200 per cent certain - if that's at all possible - that I didn't have it. In the end, I had to search him, and guess what I found in the bottom of his sock?" - Another gem from Steffan Iversen's website.

FEELING DOWN

Poor Bryan Robson. He's spent the entire summer heroically dashing around Europe in search of top-quality internationals. And the way the Fiver sees it, he's succeeded. Because if Christian Karembeu, Paul Okon, Alen Boksic, Joseph-Desire Job and Mark Crossley aren't top quality internationals then who is? But - strangely - when we read our papers, do we hear Robbo getting the plaudits his transfer market acumen deserves? Do we heck. Instead all we get is the soft, Southern media - pansies to a man - mocking, mocking and mocking again.

Not that Robbo's been paying the blindest bit of attention. "Our outside aim is to get into Europe.", Robbo revealed today. "At the beginning of last season, I gave our lads the challenge to beat the year they'd had before. In one sense they did that and in another, they didn't," he explained in his own unique way. "We finished with one point more than the previous year, but we dropped three places and instead of finishing ninth, we ended up 12th with 52 points." Ah, we see now. "What we need to do now is beat that."

Almost immediately however doubts began to emerge in Robbo's mind (we blame the Southern media). "You've got people like Liverpool, Chelsea, Aston Villa and Newcastle spending fortunes to get that [a place in Europe]," Robbo admitted. "They want to be in Europe and it shows how difficult that is. I just want the club to keep improving while I'm manager, and I still think that we're achieving that. As long as we can take another step this season, that will be great," he concluded. Just as long as it's not a step down into the First, some would say. But not us.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal may finally be set to sign Sylvain Wiltord after reports suggested Bordeaux have accepted a £11.5m offer for their star striker.

Former Arsenal target Edu will not be joining Borussia Dortmund. The Brazilian midfielder had been reportedly on his way to join the Bundesliga side, but a spokesman for the club denied any move.

Barcelona star Jari Litmanen believes 20 clubs are currently trying to sign him. The Finnish international has been linked with a move to Spurs, but he said today: "I think around 20 clubs have already shown interest in me. The Albania game [Finland's next fixture] is in two weeks and I'm hoping to make a move before that."

Internazionale are believed to be ready to sell Clarence Seedorf less than a year after they paid £14m for the Dutch midfielder. Coach Marcello Lippi wants Brazilian international Vampeta as his replacement.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Harry Kewell has signed a new improved four-year contract which will tie him to Leeds until 2004. "This proves Harry's committed to Leeds and I'm absolutely delighted," chairman Peter Ridsdale told the club's official website. "I'm thrilled that such an exceptional talent is staying at Elland Road."

Wimbledon's £2.5m bid for Everton defender Colin Dunne has collapsed. Everton manager Walter Smith admitted: "The player and his representatives failed to reach an agreement with Wimbledon. From our point of view the transfer is now dead and Richard is back with us training."

Ken Monkou has been transfer listed by Huddersfield, fined two weeks wages, and suspended for two weeks for "a serious breach of club discipline" - although the club are refusing to say what the Dutch defender has done.

Manchester United have been installed as 8-11 to win the Premiership - the shortest odds ever quoted pre-season by bookmakers William Hill.

Aberdeen striker Hicham Zerouali has insisted he wants to stay at Pittodrie despite rumours he was unhappy at the club. The Moroccan through a tantrum during the 1-1 draw with Hearts on Sunday after Robbie Winters failed to pass to him.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Fifa TV (7.30pm)

Sepp 'Burnside' Blatter walks up to Leonnart Johannsen, grabs him by his collar, and calls him a "fat slag".

Sky Sports 1: Football Special (8pm)

If you're suffering from Burnside withdrawal symptoms, you're not alone. Join us tonight in our vigil. Sideburns optional.

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (1am)

And we'll do the same every Thursday at 9pm until Burnside returns, bigger and badder than ever.

Football (2.40pm)

Even a guest appearance in the Bill would do.

Major League Soccer (4.20am)

Kansas Dope Fiends v LA Crackheads.

Sky Sports 1: You're on Sky Sports! (10pm)

We've got extremely bad news... they've replaced McCaff!!! The new geezer is very much of the same school as the great man (ill-fitting shirt, idiotic fixed grin, etc.) but amazingly manages to be worse. Anyone wishing to join our 'Come Back McCaff, All Is Forgiven' campaign should email the.boss@theguardian.com with "I never thought I would say this but..." in the subject field.

webTitle: Should the web create its own money?

fields.headline: Coining it on the internet
fields.standfirst:
The web has created its own culture and its own millionaires. Should it also create its own money? asks Charlotte Denny
Net news
E-finance
Shopping unlimited
fields.trailText: The web has created its own culture and its own millionaires. Should it also create its own money?
fields.body:
Cyberlibertarians who saw the internet as a way of escaping the dead hand of central government must be disappointed. Many believed that the internet offered the ideal testing grounds for one of the most famous predictions of Friedrich Hayek, Mrs Thatcher's favourite economic guru, who suggested 25 years ago that private money would spontaneously arise as a credible alternative to legal tender issued by central banks.

It is nearly five years since the first prototype digital currencies were launched, and a single currency for the internet has yet to emerge, spontaneously or otherwise. Early attempts to solve the money conundrum have not been a success. DigiCash, one of the pioneers in the field, went bankrupt nearly two years ago. Last year Barclays dropped its early experiment in the field, Barclaycoin, based on technology from the US firm Cybercoin, which has also abandoned the e-payments game and gone into payments security.

These early systems were not new currencies - they relied on customers downloading software to install a digital wallet on their PC. The wallet could then be loaded up with transfers from the customer's bank account. Installing the software was a hassle and finding a website enabled to accept payments even more so.

Credit cards have become the default payment system for e-commerce in the absence of a better option, but neither consumers nor merchants are happy. Consumers don't like trusting card details to websites. According to one recent survey, four in 10 UK consumers say they are reluctant to use their credit cards for purchases on the internet, even though security experts promise it is no more risky than giving a credit card number down the telephone or letting a waiter take a card out of sight when paying for a meal. The customer does not bear the major risk for fraudulent transactions whether online or in the real economy.

Fraud is undoubtedly a problem online, but it is e-tailers - not customers - who are paying the heaviest price. Web sites offer would-be fraudsters programmes to download which will automatically generate valid card numbers. Other fraudsters trawl the net picking up credit card details stored on retailers' sites.

Stolen credit numbers were used in 1.2% of US internet sales last year. Some analysts estimate e-tailers are 10 times more likely to be hit by fraud than offline retailers. In the UK, the main banks' clearing house, APCS, estimates online card fraud in 1999 to have equalled £3.7m - or 2% of total card losses.

The real sting for the merchants is that, unlike face to face card sales where the issuing bank bears the risk if the retailer takes reasonable precautions, with any kind of remote card transaction they are fully liable for the cost of the fraud. Not only do they lose the payment, but card companies bill them a $40 "chargeback" for accepting a fraudulent payment.

Credit card issuers already charge web merchants more than real world retailers: 2.5% of sales, plus 30 cents per transaction as opposed to 1.5% plus 30 cents. All of this is cutting into web merchants' already slender profit margins.

Swingeing transaction costs are one reason why cards are hopeless for small purchases - so-called micropayments. They are not much use either if you are trying to pay another individual rather than a retailer - as often happens on internet auction sites.

A bewildering variety of payment systems has emerged as an alternative to credit cards. The sex sites, usually the leading edge for commercial exploitation of the internet, got out of credit card payments some time ago, crippled by fraud. Now they use different systems, including programmes which enable customers to add the cost of visiting the site to their phone bill, or use a third party which holds the customers details to guarantee that credit card payments are genuine. But such sites are themselves vulnerable to hackers.

Paypal promises to take the uncertainty out of person to person transactions - P2P in the jargon. Both parties register their credit card or bank account details, and payments are triggered by sending an email. Paypal will arrange for payments to be taken out of the buyer's account and transferred to the seller's.

If you receive an email with money from Paypal, you have to sign up to the service to get it: a sure fire way of increasing the numbers using the system. But it too has recently fallen victim to fraudsters using false card numbers, and has promised to review its procedures.

Billpoint promises the same advantages for P2P payments on eBay, the web's leading auction site. The big players clearly think there is money to be made from P2P: US bank Wells Fargo has a 35% stake in Billpoint, while Paypal is part owned by Finnish mobile phone giant Nokia.

For micro payments, the choice of payment methods is even more bewildering. Online rewards schemes like Beenz and Flooz which pay people to surf are starting to look more like currencies as they become more widely accepted across the internet.

Other schemes involve variations on the digital wallet: at Y-creds, parents can load pocket money into their offspring's accounts which can then be used to shop at a parent censored selection of online merchants.

ExchangePath, formerly 1Clickcharge, a US site, offers prepaid accounts and P2P payments.

The problem with these substitutes for credit cards is that there are too many of them. Consumers do not want to have to go shopping with a wallet full of dozens of different payment options, but so far there is no accepted standard on which to rely.

David Birch, head of Consult Hyperion, a UK e-payments consultancy, says the race is on in the US and Europe to find secure, convenient solution to internet payments which will unlock the commercial potential of the internet. The ideal system would offer certain features: they would be:
 fraudproof
 private
 exchangeable for a wide range of goods and services
 a reliable store of value, not likely to be eroded by inflation
 downloadable for real economy purchases
 good for small as well as large transactions.

US companies are racing to design software which offers these features, while in Europe the preferred solution is smart cards - where the security information is encoded on a chip rather than in the magnetic strip of the more familiar credit and debit cards. They can store credit card numbers so that the consumer does not need to give the information away over the net or the phone, or they can be loaded up with cash which can be used for small payments.

Birch believes smart cards are the way forward because software solutions will always be vulnerable to hacking. While the security information on magnetic cards can easily be copied and stolen, the security on smart cards means that they have to be literally ripped apart before they give up their identifying information.

With a smart card, users can pay for small and large purchases online without identifying themselves to the merchant - thus offering privacy.

But to become the ubiquitous payment mechanism for the internet, smart cards require extra hardware - readers attached to PCs or set top boxes. M-commerce may well get a headstart over e-commerce simply because some mobile phones already come with readers installed.

But for smart cards to evolve further, the big players have to get together to agree common standards. Brian Gladman, a former security expert for Nato, says the failure to agree common standards so far is because it involves two groups - bankers and technical experts - who don't understand each other.

He believes that although the US hasn't shown much interest so far in smart cards, once they latch on to the technology, they are likely to race ahead of Europe, because their bankers are more technically literate.

If smart cards become the prevailing mechanism for internet payments, it means the end of the dream of private money because the cards will link back to national currencies and to real time payment systems.

True digital money would look very different to the account based systems which are developing as the standard. In an account based money system value is stored in the accounts of a trusted third party like a bank. Money is exchanged by taking from one person's account and transferring to another.

True digital money would be based on a system where electronic tokens - an unforgeable packet of bits - are exchanged. Instead of relying on third party verification or on the banking system as a guarantee of value, in a token system, ownership is all - whoever has the token, has the money.

Oakington, a British company, believes it may have developed the software platform which would allow other players to issue true digital currencies.

The software is still being tested for bugs, but the company says it already has major e-tailers interested in the concept.

Hayek's dream of companies challenging governments for the right to issue money may yet be realised.

Paying your way

e-gold
www.e-gold.com
Number of users 25,000
Spending power Very limited number of sites at present, mostly in the US.
How does it work?
Users buy a chunk of a gold bar which they can then use to make small and large payments on line. The gold is centrally stored and payments are debited from one account and paid into another
Pros and cons
Slightly wacky idea, definitely for the libertarian fringe who have always had an obsession with payments sytems based on gold. Has the advantage of being easily to trade internationally - if you've found another person with an e-gold account. Not widespread enough to be very useful, but hey, who cares about the practicalities? You too can own a chunk of the world's favourite metal.

Surfmiles
www.surfmiles.com
Spending power
Site boasts that it can be used at 140 major e-tailers.
How does it work?
Users earn points for surfing the net. Points can either be spent online or downloaded for real money.
Pros and cons
Free money is always good, but at 30p an hour, you would have to be a pretty dedicated surfer to make your fortune.

Mondex
www.mondex.com
Number of users
One million worldwide, a quarter of whom are in Hong Kong. In the UK, university students are the biggest users
Spending power Online, Mondex is accepted by 3000 merchants.
How does it work?
A smart card with a purse enables users to store money for small transactions, on and off line. In Hong Kong, the cards are used to pay for train tickets
Pros and cons
The granddaddy of smart card systems. It had bad publicity in the UK, when its Swindon based trial failed to catch on. It's proved more successful overseas

ChargitPREPAY
www.glintbill.com
Number of users In development
How does it work?
Users buy a card from a newsagent which can be used to pay for online purchases. Each card has an individual pin concealed behind a scratchpanel. Its value is monitored on the company's website and is debited everytime a purchase is made.
Pros and cons

Cheap way of making micropayments and, because cards can be bought for cash, can be used by people with no bank account or credit card.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
DIY

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: DIY
fields.body:
Good news for anyone planning to catch up on all those little jobs around the house over the bank holiday. www.homebase.co.uk which was launched last week, offers "help, advice and inspiration", and a range of 5,000 products. If you want to perform a Changing Rooms-style transformation on your home, forget Carol Smillie and crew and check out the ideas pages. The how-to guides will take you through the trickier jobs, like laying floors and glazing windows. Orders placed before 12 noon are normally delivered within three working days .

www.screwfix.com has a functional, no-frills feel. It's very straightforward - you can search by category, from screws, bolts and nails, to building accessories and security devices - but the absence of chat or tips, clearly marks it as one for the pro.

Orders processed before 5pm will be delivered next day and you only have to spend £45 for the £4.25 delivery charge to be waived.

www.focusdoitall.co.uk is at the toe-dipping stage of its foray into e-commerce. Perhaps the people behind it are joking when they claim to have a "small selection of products" - there are 25 - "which reflect your needs". To give you a flavour, Travis the Trout, an ornamental, motion-activated, singing trout sits at the top of the list. The more practical DIY-er will find the Black & Decker drills and precision saws more useful.

fields.headline: How much can you pay for
fields.standfirst: ... a jump lead kit
fields.trailText: ... a jump lead kit
fields.body:
There are some things that just aren't meant to sound glamorous. Try seducing a lover with the promise of a new jump lead kit and even the most motor-enthused amour might suffer a twinge of disappointment. They are, after all, intended to start engines, not to arouse passions.

But Connolly, renowned for luxurious leather goods and swanky gadgets, has a way of transforming the everyday into the elegant, and this kit, complete with leather gloves, spanner and wooden wire brush to clean points is no exception. "Housed" in a leather contoured case of racing green, blue/black, black or chocolate brown, it is perfect for those who are passionate about their car, but don't often dirty their hands on its engine. The cream lining of the case and the toning soft trucker gloves in the same shade reveal a disregard for practicality few could afford. Any motoring enthusiast willing to spend £150 on leather driving goggles (also by Connolly), probably wouldn't quake at the £500 price but the serious mechanic is more likely to pop in to Halfords. You do not need it, but may find you have to have it.

Contact Connolly on 020-7235 3883.

fields.headline: Clearing
fields.standfirst: As thousands of students scramble for university places,  Donald MacLeod explains the system that finds the courses with vacancies
fields.trailText: As thousands of students scramble for university places, we explain the system that finds the courses with vacancies
fields.body:
What is Clearing?
It's the service run by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (Ucas) to match students without places with courses that still have vacancies.

Who uses Clearing?
Mostly students who have not gained the A-level or Highers grades they needed to meet conditional offers from their chosen university or college. Clearing can also be used to make a late application.

How many students are involved?
Despite the hullabaloo, numbers have been falling from 54,401 in 1997 to 50,650 in 1998 and 48,239 last year, although this was partly accounted for by an increase in late registrations in the wake of controversy over tuition fees. People, especially mature students, seem to have waited to see what their financial position would be before applying. An increasing number of people apply very late in the day, often directly to one college or university, rather than going through the year-long applications process.

How is it going this year?
By 11am on Thursday morning, 1,347 had found a course compared with around 2,500 at the same time in 1999. The numbers eligible for clearing were also down on last year, at 84,000 compared with 90,080. Far more students have got their first choice - this year conditional offers to a total of 190,793 people were confirmed. Many more will be able to negotiate entry to their first or second choice if they have missed the grades by a small margin. Institutions may well prefer to take a student they already know a bit about from their application.

Who is eligible for Clearing?
Any applicant not holding an offer from a university or college. You must turn down any existing offer before Ucas will allow you into Clearing.

What do applicants need to do?
If you are eligible for Clearing, you don't need to ask Ucas for details. They will send you a Clearing entry form (CEF) and instructions booklet automatically. Then it is up to students to take advice from teachers and career advisers and start contacting the universities and colleges about the courses that interest them. Ucas recommends that you telephone, e-mail or call in person and keep your CEF handy - you will probably be asked for your number and exam results.

Is it a race?
Every year Clearing seems to become more frenetic. Yesterday morning the Ucas website registered 129,613 full searches. Young people hit the phones to universities and colleges as soon as they get their exam results - that is why there has been such a furore in Scotland where delayed Highers results could mean English and Welsh applicants get a head start in chasing the best courses.

Will all the best courses will be snapped up by the first weekend after the A-level results?
Definitely not. A lot of informal offers are made at this stage. Student rings university A. "Would you take me to study X with my grades?" "Yes," says the admissions tutor. Student rings university B, college C - possibly 10 or a dozen institutions to find the best offer. The upshot is that days and weeks pass before the true situation becomes clear.

What do I do when a university or college offers me a place?
If an institution is happy that you meet its requirements, it will probably ask you to send it your CEF. Ucas advises: "Don't be hasty. When someone asks for your CEF, they are, effectively, making you an offer. Make sure they are genuinely interested in your application. If you are sure the course is for you, fill in your CEF and send it off - or better still, take it there yourself. The best way to find out more about a university or college, its accommodation and social life, is to make a visit."

Can I shop around?
Yes, but remember that your CEF can only be sent to one institution at a time. The university or college will insist that you send the original form, not a photocopy or fax. So if you're not convinced its course is for you, politely explain and carry on telephoning.

How do I know if I've got a place?
When it has received your CEF, a university or college will write to you either to offer you a place or send back your form. If you decline the offer, or you do not get one, your CEF will be returned and you can keep looking. If you accept the offer, the university or college will confirm your place to Ucas and it will send you an official letter.

How long does Clearing last?
You can get a place until the start of the academic term in September or even October but the majority of students get sorted out fairly quickly.

Useful links
Special report: Clearing 2000
