But the film's success cut no ice with 38-year-old Snipes, who is a big fan of the original movie. "There's only one Shaft - Richard Rowndtree," Snipes told reporters. "And if you're going to do a remake there's only one person that can do that - Snipes, period." The actor claims that he was Universal studios' first choice for the role, but was put off after reading the script. "I was offered the film and it was terrible, horrible. It was an insult not only to the African-American culture, but an insult to what the icon of Shaft was." Singleton's remake has been accused in some quarters of amounting to little more than a shrewd blaxploitation pastiche, aping the styles of the era but leaving out its radical political overtones. The film was described by J Hoberman in the Village Voice as "basically a posture-fest fuelled by ethnic jive and racist invective." Snipes, who is currently working on Blade 2, is insistent that he has no complaints over Samuel L Jackson's performance. "Sam is my man and we've been talking about this," he said. "Sam knows I ain't dissing him, I'm dissing the movie."

webTitle: Lieberman could be Gore's ticket to the White House

fields.headline: Lieberman could be Gore's ticket to the White House
fields.standfirst: The choice of the relatively unknown Joe Lieberman as a running mate is already giving Al Gore a boost in the US presidential election race, writes Martin Kettle in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: The choice of the relatively unknown Joe Lieberman as a running mate is already giving Al Gore a boost in the US presidential election race, writes Martin Kettle in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Joe Lieberman of Connecticut could be the key that unlocks the 2000 US presidential election for the Democrats.

If that turns out to be true, then it will be one of the more improbable transformations in modern American politics. Less than two weeks ago, Mr Lieberman was a relatively obscure, generally conservative Democrat senator, known to the public mainly because if his prominent criticism of president Bill Clinton during the impeachment crisis, and known to the Washington press corps mainly as an honest and interesting, but marginal, figure within his own party.

Last night, though, thousands of delegates in the Staples Centre greeted the little man from Connecticut as a conquering hero when he delivered a smart, upbeat and generally well-judged acceptance speech to the Democratic Convention in Los Angeles.

It must have been by far the largest audience that Mr Lieberman has ever addressed, and although he still seems stunned by the transformation of the past fortnight, it was an obvious success. He entered to the music from Chariots of Fire, greeted the audience with an improbable clenched fist salute and started his speech with a Jewish mother-in-law joke.

But in contrast to his campaign appearances last week, this time Mr Lieberman dwelled only lightly on religious themes or the significance of his selection to American Jews and immigrants. It was a speech which set out to do four things. First, it had to introduce the still largely unknown Mr Lieberman to the wider national audience in a rare prime-time television opportunity. Second, it had to help promote Al Gore's generally lack-lustre public image - a major theme of this third day of the Democratic convention.

Beyond these core tasks, the speech had to fulfil two potentially contradictory aims. It had to win the support of the black American electorate, a crucial Democratic base, but one which cannot be counted on to support a Jewish candidate. Simultaneously, the speech had to reach out beyond the party, to independent and undecided voters who needed to be given some reasons for preferring Gore-Lieberman to the Republicans' Bush-Cheney ticket.

The first two objectives were easily fulfilled, Americans have no excuse for not knowing the key elements in the Lieberman narrative these days - the modest background in Connecticut, the days in the civil rights movement campaigning to register black voters, the abiding importance of his mother Marcia, the marriage to Hadassah Freilich, a daughter of Holocaust survivors, the assaults on Hollywood's debauched standards, then the attack on Mr Clinton over the Lewinsky affair.

Last night the television audience heard nice stories from and about Joe Lieberman. And no one tuning in to the Democratic convention could doubt that he supports and promotes Mr Gore. After meeting the vice-president on one occasion, Mr Lieberman's young daughter said "He must be a daddy".

Al Gore's virtues as a father were a constant theme of yesterday's sessions. Politically, though, there were other jobs to do. "Let me just speak to those of you at home who haven't made up your mind if you want to build on our prosperity," Mr Lieberman said, before highlighting bi-partisanship and political reform as two key areas tailored to appeal to independents.

"I respectfully say to you that Al Gore and I are the guys who are ready to do the job," he said, At various points in his speech, Mr Lieberman praised Republican leaders like Ronald Reagan. He stressed his senate reputation as an "across the aisle" legislator, who had worked with Republicans in the past and who was happy to do so again.

"Our opponents are decent and likeable men," he said. "I am pleased to call many in their party my friends." He praised "my dear friend John McCain" - the Arizona senator was diagnosed with skin cancer yesterday - and labelled him a great man.

In the coming election, this appeal to the centre and to independents will surely be one of Mr Lieberman's responsibilities. The senator's quirky and unconventional voting record has raised some questions - especially among black leaders - about whether he will win over their support.

In two warm-up speeches congressmen Robert Menendez, a Latino from New Jersey, and the formidable John Lewis of Georgia, who is black, fought to promote Mr Lieberman's anti-racist record. Meanwhile the man himself went out of his way to restate his support for affirmative action, as he had also done earlier at a meeting with the congressional black caucus.

At the end, the Liebermans were bustled off the stage to prepare the way for Karenna Gore and Tommy Lee Jones to nominate Mr Gore for the election, and later for Mr Gore to make a surprise appearance himself, prior to being formally adopted.

But the impact that the senator has made on the polls in just a few days has been good for the Democrats, and yesterday's speech is surely destined to push the party forward still further, as Mr Lieberman road tests his own considerable assets under campaign conditions.

fields.headline: Fans' charter: the draft
fields.trailText:
1. ACCESSIBILITY
1.1 The club continues to strive for wider access to matches by offering:

1.1.1 A broad range of ticket prices. Customers buying more expensive seats or packages enable us to charge other customers less for their tickets.

1.1.2 At least 5% of tickets to each game to non season ticket holders.

1.1.3 Concessions for junior supporters, senior citizens and supporters with a restricted view of the pitch.

1.1.4 An area of the ground for exclusive use of family groups and junior supporters.

1.1.5 Support for disabled supporters and their carers.

1.1.6 Free or reduced admission to replays of abandoned games. If a match is abandoned after spectators are admitted to the ground but before kick off ticket holders are entitled to free admission to the rearranged match. If a match is abandoned after kick off spectators are entitled to half price admission to the rearranged match.
fields.body:
1. ACCESSIBILITY
1.1 The club continues to strive for wider access to matches by offering:

1.1.1 A broad range of ticket prices. Customers buying more expensive seats or packages enable us to charge other customers less for their tickets.

1.1.2 At least 5% of tickets to each game to non season ticket holders.

1.1.3 Concessions for junior supporters, senior citizens and supporters with a restricted view of the pitch.

1.1.4 An area of the ground for exclusive use of family groups and junior supporters.

1.1.5 Support for disabled supporters and their carers.

1.1.6 Free or reduced admission to replays of abandoned games. If a match is abandoned after spectators are admitted to the ground but before kick off ticket holders are entitled to free admission to the rearranged match. If a match is abandoned after kick off spectators are entitled to half price admission to the rearranged match.

2. AWAY SUPPORT

2.1 The Club's supporters are allocated tickets for away matches as follows (Individual club to decide their own strategy). The away club determines the cost of these tickets.

2.2 The Club does not charge admission prices to supporters of a visiting club which are higher than those charged to our own supporters for comparable accommodation. In particular our concessionary rates offered to senior citizens and junior supporters apply to supporters of a visiting club.

2.3 The Club abides by the FA Premier League Rules governing the allocation of tickets to visiting clubs.

3 LOYALTY AND MEMBERSHIP

3.1 The Club runs loyalty and membership schemes. (The benefits to be determined by the individual club).

4 CONSULTATION AND INFORMATION

4.1 The Club consults its supporters on a regular basis through either forums, questionnaires, annual fans' survey or focus groups, or a combination of these.

4.2 The Club publicises its position on major policy issues in an easily digested format (possibly in the Club programme or magazine).

4.3 The Club has and continues to develop ways to consult with shareholders, sponsors, the local authority and other interested parties.

4.4 The Club gives the earliest possible notice of any changes to its ticketing policy and the reasons for the changes.

4.5 The Club undertakes research on the design and number of new strips.

5 COMMUNITY ACTIVITY

To be confirmed by the individual club.

6 MERCHANDISE

6.1 All replica strip designs have a minimum lifespan of two seasons.

6.2 The Club provides swing tickets attached to a replica strip stating its launch date.
6.3 Details of the next intended change of kits are available from the club shop.

6.4 The Club carries out its obligations under the Premier League rulebook to prevent price fixing in relation to the sale of replica strips.

6.5 The Club offers refunds on merchandise in accordance with its legal obligations.

7 STAFF CONDUCT

Anti discrimination policy and customer relations mission statement to be incorporated within the charter.

8 CUSTOMER SERVICE

8.1 The Club responds to any contact from a customer within a minimum number of days to be decided by the individual club.

8.2 The Club responds by either telephone, email, fax or letter. If the customer requests a response in writing, they receive one.

8.3 The Club has overall responsibility for customer service.

webTitle: Courtney and Curtly spare Adams's blushes

fields.headline: Courtney and Curtly spare Adams's blushes
fields.trailText: Tonight Jimmy Adams will have a horrible feeling that he got it wrong - again. At Old Trafford he won the toss and batted, when events suggested that if he'd bowled England would have struggled. And today, on what is traditionally the fast men's favourite pitch, Adams won the toss and batted once more. He almost ended up on the back foot again, after his side were shot out for 172 - the sort of first-innings score in which England have specialised recently - but Courtney Walsh popped up with three wickets near the close to leave things nicely balanced.
fields.body:
Tonight Jimmy Adams will have a horrible feeling that he got it wrong - again. At Old Trafford he won the toss and batted, when events suggested that if he'd bowled England would have struggled. And today, on what is traditionally the fast men's favourite pitch, Adams won the toss and batted once more. He almost ended up on the back foot again, after his side were shot out for 172 - the sort of first-innings score in which England have specialised recently - but Courtney Walsh popped up with three wickets near the close to leave things nicely balanced.

There was a whisper that West Indies wanted to give Curtly Ambrose extra time to recover from a back twinge. He'd hoped to put his feet up for a day and a half - but got only a session and a half. If it hadn't been for Ramnaresh Sarwan's mouthwatering half-century - wrist-full but risk-free - it would have been even less than that.

It wasn't a terror track that did for West Indies - although it was no picnic either - but a high-class England bowling performance. For a while it looked as if Yorkshire (Gough and White) were taking on West Indies on their own, but eventually Dominic Cork nipped in with a couple of wildly-celebrated wickets.

When England batted, it was the same old story. Ambrose and Walsh equals almost unplayable (they conceded only 13 runs off the bat in their first 13 overs together). King and Company equals almost unspeakable. Thorpe relieved the pressure with a four off King's very first ball, and welcomed McLean with a straight-driven four in his second over. Back in 1986 Graham Gooch compared Richard Hadlee's New Zealand support bowling to Ilford 2nd XI's. Those Ilford stalwarts would feel upset if anyone tried a similar line about this West Indian team.

Something else will be bothering Adams. He's got to go to Australia this winter with several batsmen who don't inspire confidence against pace - and more crucially without Ambrose, if he really has had enough, and maybe Walsh, who is umm-ing and ah-ing about his own retirement date. The lure of 500 Test wickets might persuade Walsh into yet another farewell tour, but Ambrose seems determined to go hang up his size 13s. Perhaps a holiday will change his mind. Sandals, the West Indies' co-sponsors, obviously think so: they've shouted him a freebie for reaching 400 wickets, which he did by chopping off Mike Atherton for the 17th time in Tests.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Hooray for Holyrood:  Backing for Scottish film studios

fields.headline: Hooray for Holyrood:  Backing for Scottish film studios
fields.trailText: An arts strategy for Scotland was launched yesterday that could result in a national theatre company within 12 months and a start on construction of a film production studio within two years.
fields.body:
An arts strategy for Scotland was launched yesterday that could result in a national theatre company within 12 months and a start on construction of a film production studio within two years.

Responding to criticism that Scotland has national opera and ballet companies and two national orchestras but no national theatre, the executive committed itself to a feasibility study to be completed early next year. Ministers have indicated that they support the idea in principle, but as yet no money has been pledged to fund the project, likely to approach £3m.

The deputy culture minister, Rhona Brankin, also said yesterday that she would look closely at the practicality of a Scottish equivalent to Pinewood. Two studies have reported positively, and Scottish Screen, an agency that promotes local film-making, has asked the executive to foot the £6m capital costs. A decision is expected next month and, if favourable, construction could begin within two years.

John Archer, director of Scottish Screen, said: "If you look at film studios across the world, with the exception of a couple in Los Angeles they never recoup their capital costs. We think the amount of private money this would bring to Scotland would more than pay off the investment."

Scotland has a strong tradition of successful but low key film-making. A few made it big at the box office, such as Danny Boyle and Andrew Macdonald with Shallow Grave and Trainspotting (pictured); recently, Lynne Ramsay's Ratcatcher was well received at Cannes.

A national theatre company has the backing of the Scottish parliament's education committee. It is unlikely to get its own theatre premises, but would probably work by commissioning artists and companies for a national season.

fields.body:
In I Love Melvin (1953), Donald O'Connor (pictured) on roller skates, sings "Life has its funny little ups and downs", which could serve as an anthem for the film's director, Don Weis, who has died aged 78. The bouncy musical starring O'Connor and Debbie Reynolds, both fresh from Singin' In The Rain, was one of those irresistibly engaging, lightweight pictures that Weis made early in his career. At MGM in the 1950s, the accent was on youth, and Weis, in his early 30s, was given the chance to work with vigorous young performers. He was still aiming at the youth market a decade later - directing "beach party" movies.

Weis entered the film industry as a Warner Bros messenger boy after studying film at the University of Southern California. After wartime service with the US Army Air Force, he worked as scriptwriter, dialogue director and assistant, mostly on Stanley Kramer-produced movies. A greater contrast between Kramer's strained seriousness and Weis's carefree pictures would be hard to find.

His first film as director was Bannerline (1951), a likeable newspaper story starring the forgotten Keefe Brasselle as a cub reporter exposing small-town corruption. Afterwards, Weis was among six other directors on It's A Big Country (1952), an episodic patriotic picture praising the diversity of Americans with hardly a black face in sight. His sketch was a comic one featuring Brasselle and squawking Marjorie Main.

There followed two cute little 1952 comedies starring the charming, but talentless Peter Lawford: Just This Once, with Janet Leigh, and You For Me, with Jane Greer. I Love Melvin, one of Weis's best pictures, had O'Connor as a photographer's assistant who rashly promises star-struck Reynolds the chance to appear on the cover of Look magazine. The film contained winning performances and witty dance routines staged by Robert Alton.

The Affairs of Dobie Gillis (1953) - also starring Reynolds, accompanied by dynamic dancers Bobby Van and Bob Fosse, all as college kids - almost outdid I Love Melvin in exuberance. Debbie sings All I Do Is Dream Of You, as she did in Singin' In The Rain, and there is a number performed by a sextet of middle-aged women calling themselves Happy Stella Kowalski And Her Schottische Five.

His contract up at MGM, Weis kicked off as a freelance with the hugely entertaining The Adventures of Hadji Baba (1954), in which dashingly handsome John Derek rescues a sheik's daughter from a forced marriage.

Weis then disappeared into television, emerging from time to time to make feature films, including Mr Pharaoh And His Cleopatra (1959), made in Cuba and never released. In the same year, he directed The Gene Krupa Story, unaccountably star ring vulnerable, baby-faced Sal Mineo as the great jazz drummer, whose life was more interesting than this biopic suggested.

The stagy Critic's Choice (1963), based on Ira Levin's play and starring Bob Hope and Lucille Ball, revolved around the unlikely event of a theatre critic having to review his wife's play objectively. Looking For Love (1964) had pop singer Connie Francis, as a switchboard operator with showbusiness aspirations, singing seven songs.

Another bubble gum movie was Pajama Party (1964); Martian Tommy Kirk drops in on earth teens and joins in their mindless activities. It was sad to see 69-year-old Buster Keaton running around as Chief Rotten Eagle, just as it was to see 79-year-old Boris Karloff playing a corpse hoping to get into heaven in The Ghost In The Invisible Bikini (1966), the seventh, final beach party movie.

Just as grisly, but less amusing, was Billie (1966), about a tomboyish teenager (Patty Duke) who can outperfom the boys in the high school's athletic team. This embarrasses her father, who is running for mayor on a "male supremacy" platform. The movie's pro-feminism finally yields to male brow-beating.

After the ghastly Did You Hear The One About The Travelling Saleslady? (1968) starring the utterly unfunny Phyllis Diller, Weis returned to television permanently. He redeemed himself, especially by directing more than 40 episodes of M*A*S*H in the 1970s, winning six Directors Guild of America Awards as the year's best television director. He also directed dozens of Twilight Zone, Alfred Hitchcock Presents, Perry Mason, Love Boat and Fantasy Island episodes.

He is survived by his wife, the actress Rebecca Welles; two daughters, a stepdaughter and two grandchildren.

 Don Weis, film and television director; born May 13 1922; died July 26 2000

Afterwards, Weis was among six other directors on It's A Big Country (1952), an episodic patriotic picture praising the diversity of Americans with hardly a black face in sight. His sketch was a comic one featuring Brasselle and squawking Marjorie Main. There followed two cute little 1952 comedies starring the charming, but talentless Peter Lawford: Just This Once, with Janet Leigh, and You For Me, with Jane Greer. I Love Melvin, one of Weis's best pictures, had O'Connor as a photographer's assistant who rashly promises star-struck Reynolds the chance to appear on the cover of Look magazine. The film contained winning performances and witty dance routines staged by Robert Alton. The Affairs of Dobie Gillis (1953) - also starring Reynolds, accompanied by dynamic dancers Bobby Van and Bob Fosse, all as college kids - almost outdid I Love Melvin in exuberance. Debbie sings All I Do Is Dream Of You, as she did in Singin' In The Rain, and there is a number performed by a sextet of middle-aged women calling themselves Happy Stella Kowalski And Her Schottische Five. His contract up at MGM, Weis kicked off as a freelance with the hugely entertaining The Adventures of Hadji Baba (1954), in which dashingly handsome John Derek rescues a sheik's daughter from a forced marriage. Weis then disappeared into television, emerging from time to time to make feature films, including Mr Pharaoh And His Cleopatra (1959), made in Cuba and never released. In the same year, he directed The Gene Krupa Story, unaccountably star ring vulnerable, baby-faced Sal Mineo as the great jazz drummer, whose life was more interesting than this biopic suggested. The stagy Critic's Choice (1963), based on Ira Levin's play and starring Bob Hope and Lucille Ball, revolved around the unlikely event of a theatre critic having to review his wife's play objectively. Looking For Love (1964) had pop singer Connie Francis, as a switchboard operator with showbusiness aspirations, singing seven songs. Another bubble gum movie was Pajama Party (1964); Martian Tommy Kirk drops in on earth teens and joins in their mindless activities. It was sad to see 69-year-old Buster Keaton running around as Chief Rotten Eagle, just as it was to see 79-year-old Boris Karloff playing a corpse hoping to get into heaven in The Ghost In The Invisible Bikini (1966), the seventh, final beach party movie. Just as grisly, but less amusing, was Billie (1966), about a tomboyish teenager (Patty Duke) who can outperfom the boys in the high school's athletic team. This embarrasses her father, who is running for mayor on a "male supremacy" platform. The movie's pro-feminism finally yields to male brow-beating. After the ghastly Did You Hear The One About The Travelling Saleslady? (1968) starring the utterly unfunny Phyllis Diller, Weis returned to television permanently. He redeemed himself, especially by directing more than 40 episodes of M*A*S*H in the 1970s, winning six Directors Guild of America Awards as the year's best television director. He also directed dozens of Twilight Zone, Alfred Hitchcock Presents, Perry Mason, Love Boat and Fantasy Island episodes. He is survived by his wife, the actress Rebecca Welles; two daughters, a stepdaughter and two grandchildren.  Don Weis, film and television director; born May 13 1922; died July 26 2000

webTitle: Black comedy accused of glamorising killer

fields.headline: Black comedy accused of glamorising killer
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Chopper, a gruesomely funny entrant for the Edinburgh film festival, was last night condemned for glamorising a self-confessed "murdering bastard" who claims to have "wiped out" 19 other criminals "for the good of society".
fields.body:
Chopper, a gruesomely funny entrant for the Edinburgh film festival, was last night condemned for glamorising a self-confessed "murdering bastard" who claims to have "wiped out" 19 other criminals "for the good of society".

The low-budget black comedy, based on the nine books the hitman Mark Brandon "the Chopper" Read wrote while in prison in Australia, has taken the film world by surprise, knocking the Mel Gibson blockbuster The Patriot off the top of the box office down under this week despite being dropped by its distributors at the last minute. It is the first adults-only film to have performed so well there.

Chopper Read earned his grisly nickname through the "free pedicures" he administered as a gangland enforcer, slicing off his rivals' toes with a bolt cutter. His notoriety grew while he was in Pentridge prison near Melbourne for attempting to kidnap a judge, where he cut off both his ears with a razor blade as a fashion statement, a trend copied by other hardcore convicts.

But it was his infamous drunken appearance on the McFeast Live TV show when he groped host Lisbeth Gorr and joked about stuffing a victim in a cement mixer ("It took us hours to get him into it, the bastard. He kept climbing out"), that caused widespread revulsion. The series was later pulled and ABC had to issue a public apology.

The film, which Rupert Murdoch's Fox corporation dropped last week, has caused most anger in Tasmania where Read, 45, served his last sentence for shooting a friend, and to where he has now "retired".

The state's cabinet secretary and minister for women, Fran Bladel, yesterday repeated her claim that there was no value in making a film to further glorify a "very sad and dysfunctional person", who had profited from gross violent acts and achieved celebrity by joking about victims on TV. "This film will certainly convey the message that to be cruel and vindictive and to beat women pushes you to hero status with a certain class of people," she said.

Read himself, though happy with his portrayal by stand-up comedian Eric Bana, said he was angry that "while every other bastard is making money out of me I've got nothing". He insists he will donate the £9,000 he got for the film rights to a police benevolent fund.

The film has been a big hit with critics both in Australia and at Edinburgh, where it had a sneak preview yesterday.

Chopper Read comes over in the film as a deluded but personable psychopath who thinks of himself as "a normal bloke who likes a bit of torture," another Australian convict anti-hero in the Ned Kelly mode. But what makes the film both frightening and funny, and which had the audience in Edinburgh yesterday shouting its praises, was how it inhabits the mind of a clearly psychotic criminal like no other movie made before.

The festival's director, Lizzie Francke, said she had no compunction about showing it and said getting its European premiere had been a coup. "We had long and complicated negotiations to get it."

Critic Dougal MacDonald, of the Canberra Times, praised the writer/director Andrew Dominik, who he said had walked a thin line making it clear that Read was "a man devoid of moral worth".

Its British distributors, Metrodome, make no bones about selling it on its mixture of violence and black comedy, a kind of real life antipodean Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels.

webTitle: Hussain set upon staying in firing line

fields.headline: Hussain set upon staying in firing line
fields.standfirst: England captain shrugs off poor form on eve of Test
fields.trailText: David Hopps reports as the England captain shrugs off poor form on the eve of the fourth Test.
fields.body:
The most remarkable aspect of Nasser Hussain's wretched batting form is that his standing has been enhanced in the process. It is as if his worth has become fully appreciated only at the time of his greatest struggle, as if the whole of England has awakened to the realisation that here is a captain to be preserved at all costs.

Hussain, in a dreadful run of form to rival that of any modern England captain, might be leaning, but like the tower at Pisa, no one dares talk of collapse, only considers how best to strengthen the foundations. To imagine Hussain not leading England against the Australians next summer remains inconceivable.

Only Mike Denness and Mike Gatting, in three decades of captaincy, have endured a similar run to Hussain's 10 consecutive Test innings without a fifty. Denness was derided in the mid-1970s, nowhere more so than at Leeds, scene of today's critical fourth Test against West Indies, where his inability to counter the pace of Australia's Dennis Lillee and Jeff Thomson caused Brian Close to scoff: "To dismiss this lad Denness you don't have to bowl fast, you just have to run up fast."

Gatting's popularity at large never dimmed; it was the administrators who plotted his sacking. His batting woes in the mid-80s were symptomatic of a troubled period in which his dispute with the Pakistani umpire Shakoor Rana had grave diplomatic consequences and his late-night dalliance with a Nottingham barmaid encouraged English cricket to new levels of priggishness.

With Hussain, though, even as his failures are listed, they seem somehow illusory. An average this summer barely in double figures just cannot be. This is the batsman who began the millennium by becoming the first Test player to go 1,000 minutes without being dismissed.

Even West Indies, normally so clinical at exposing a weak captain, still voice their respect. Jimmy Adams, their captain, had too many injury concerns over his own support bowlers, Reon King and Franklyn Rose, to play mind games. "We don't just want to dismiss Nasser because he is a captain in poor form but because he is a world-class player," he said.

Quite how much sympathy he will receive from a drier-than-usual Leeds pitch nobody cares to predict. "It is an ugly, rough-looking wicket," said Hussain, as if he expects it to spit in his face if he accidentally catches its eye. The last thing he needs today is to walk out to bat as thick clouds are rolling in over Bill's Mother's.

Hussain undoubtedly has got his first decision right. He will remain at No3, leaving Graeme Hick to fulfil the role of a specialist batsman at No7, ahead of four pace bowlers with above-average batting credentials. Matthew Hoggard looks such a certain 12th man that he must have been kept on yesterday only in case of last-minute injuries.

Had Hussain properly returned from injury at No3 in the final of the NatWest series a month ago (instead Andrew Flintoff batted at No3 and made nought, while Hussain dropped himself to No6 in an ill-advised display of selflessness), it is conceivable this debate would not be happening.

Yesterday he sought to talk up his reputation, recalling how four years ago, against India at Edgbaston, he scored the hundred that finally ended England's humiliating run of failures at first wicket down. The only certainty before Hussain about England's No3 was that, whoever he turned out to be, England's No4, might as well have walked out with him.

"When England were looking for a No3, I came in and did the job," he said. "I intend to carry on doing that. Yes, the captaincy is a tiring job but it goes with the territory. Everybody goes through a lean trot. The important thing is we all pick ourselves up for the last two Tests."

He has sought advice from Graham Gooch, his former England and Essex team-mate and the nearest he possesses to a batting mentor. Gooch is convinced Hussain must play positively. "I remember going through a bad time and meeting Garry Sobers at a dinner," he said. "He reckoned I had stopped going for my strokes, so in the next match against Australia, I played a few."

That was 1993, at Manchester. He made 65 and 133.

"I made the same point to Nasser, emphasising that survival alone is the most natural instinct when things are not going for you but it is not enough to break the sequence."

West Indies (from): Adams (capt), Campbell, Griffith, Hinds, Lara, Gayle, Sarwan, Jacobs (wkt), McLean, Rose, Ambrose, King, Walsh, Collymore.

webTitle: BT takes control of German mobile phone giant

fields.headline: BT takes control of German mobile phone giant
fields.trailText: British Telecommunications plc confirmed it is to take control of the German mobile phone giant Viag Interkom by buying an extra 45 per cent stake in the business.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications plc confirmed it is to take control of the German mobile phone giant Viag Interkom by buying an extra 45 per cent stake in the business.

BT, which already has a 45 per cent stake, will have the option to buy the additional shareholding in Germany's third-biggest telecoms group, from its partner E ON in mid-2001.

BT's 6.65 billion euro move is part of the company's strategy to strengthen its position in Europe.

Telenor AS, which has a 10 per cent stake in Viag Interkom, has given its support to the agreement, BT said.

Telenor AS, which has a 10 per cent stake in Viag Interkom, has given its support to the agreement, BT said.

webTitle: The best bowling of all time?

fields.headline: The best bowling of all time?
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: According to "Wisden Cricket Monthly" the PricewaterhouseCoopers Ratings rate Graham Gooch's 154 not out against West Indies at Headingley in 1991 as the best Test innings of them all. What do they rate as the best Test bowling? asks Andrew Curry
fields.body:
According to "Wisden Cricket Monthly" the PricewaterhouseCoopers Ratings rate Graham Gooch's 154 not out against West Indies at Headingley in 1991 as the best Test innings of them all. What do they rate as the best Test bowling? asks Andrew Curry

We asked Rob Eastaway, one of the compilers of the PwC Ratings, for the official line:

"In the PwC Test Ratings, a bowling performance is adjusted to account for the actual batsmen the bowler dismissed and the level of scoring in the match. If a bowler takes 5 for 100 in a high-scoring match, having dismissed the top batsmen in the order, these figures might be converted to something like 7 for 80. These figures are then combined with the player's previous rating to give him a new one, in the same way as his conventional figures are combined with an old average to make a new one. All this means it is not easy to say for certain whether 7 for 80 would improve a player's rating more than, say, 8 for 100.

"However, I would estimate that the bowling figures that would have been given the highest value would have been Jim Laker's 19 for 90 at Old Trafford in 1956 (surprise, surprise). In more recent times, when the effect of the weather on conditions has not been so pronounced, Michael Holding's 14 for 149 (The Oval, 1976) look like they probably get the highest valuation - the level of runscoring in that match was relatively high, so in context his figures were outstanding.

"Incidentally, it is not quite right to say that Gooch's 154* is the highest-rated Test innings of all time. The PwC Ratings give it the highest value of any played since the last war, but Don Bradman's 270 v England at Melbourne in 1936-37 actually gets rated higher in the context of its match. The other top-rated innings since the war were Garry Sobers's 365* in 1957-58 and Brian Lara's 213 against Australia early last year.

"There's one final point I always like to make when talking about 'best' innings. The Ratings take into account some important factors within a match, but what they can't do is take into account some of the wider context of a performance. Sometimes an innings is great because a batsman is under pressure for other reasons: Mike Atherton's 99 at Headingley in 1994, after the ball-tampering business, and Mark Taylor's century at Edgbaston in 1997 after a long run of low scores spring to mind. So PwC's preference is to say that Gooch's was the 'best-rated' innings since the war, rather than the 'best' one, which would be a very arrogant assertion."

I'm stumped by a quiz question: What was started at the Longwood Cricket Club, which I'm assuming is an English club, or maybe a New Zealand one? asks Ants

Actually it's not an English club or a New Zealand one - and it's not even a cricket question! Longwood Cricket Club is in Boston, in the United States, and its main claim to fame is that the first match in the Davis Cup, tennis's inter-nations competition, was played there, in August 1900. The USA beat the British Isles to become the first winners of the trophy, which was donated by Dwight Davis, one of the successful American team. Cricket was quite popular in North America at the end of the 19th century, which is why there are quite a few places there with "Cricket Club" in the title. Another of them, the Merion Cricket and Golf Club, has played host to golf's US Open on a number of occasions.

I am trying to plan a holiday around the next England tour of the West Indies, specifically the Antigua Test. How can I find out the exact dates? asks Helen Elliott

England's next tour of the West Indies is not due to take place until the winter of 2003-04, and unfortunately the dates won't be finalised until around the middle of 2003. On the last two England tours, the Test series have finished with back-to-back matches in Barbados and Antigua. In 1993-94 the Antigua Test started on April 16, and in 1997-98 it began on March 20 (it was a little earlier because it was followed by six one-day internationals), if that's any help.

Which sides did Jack Pettiford play for? asks Gooch

John "Jack" Pettiford, who was born in Freshwater near Sydney on Nov 29, 1919, was a tall middle-order batsman and a legspin bowler. He played 16 matches for New South Wales, starting in 1946-47. He was a member of the popular Australian Services team which toured England (and later India and Ceylon) in 1945. He also went to India and Pakistan with a strong Commonwealth XI in 1949-50. He played Lancashire League cricket in England for Nelson and Oldham, and then signed up for Kent. In 1954, his first season, he topped their averages, and also made his highest score - 133 v Essex at Blackheath. Pettiford played for Kent until 1959, by which time he had scored 7077 runs (average 25.64) and taken 295 wickets (31.38) in first-class cricket. He returned to Australia, but was only 44 when he died of a heart attack in Sydney on Oct 11, 1964.

During a recent cricket coaching session at Hertfordshire University my son was coached by a Nottinghamshire player whose surname he thinks was Sylvester. Can you tell me anything about him? asks Robin Aley

I think the player your son met was Steven Anthony "Steve" Sylvester. He was a left-arm fast bowler who played a few matches for Middlesex and also spent some time on Nottinghamshire's books. He also played Minor County cricket for Buckinghamshire (he was born there in 1968).

Where will England be touring this winter? I think it should be New Zealand, but I'm not sure, says Joanne Buttler

England have a complicated schedule this winter, but New Zealand aren't actually included in it. After taking part in the ICC Knockout Trophy (or "Mini World Cup") in Kenya in October, England tour Pakistan, for the first time since 1987-88. They play three Tests and three one-day internationals there, finishing early in December, before returning home for a break. In February England go to Sri Lanka, for three more Tests and three more ODIs.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous Q&A session, Memories of the Invincibles and six sixes, click here

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

He also played Minor County cricket for Buckinghamshire (he was born there in 1968). Where will England be touring this winter? I think it should be New Zealand, but I'm not sure, says Joanne Buttler England have a complicated schedule this winter, but New Zealand aren't actually included in it. After taking part in the ICC Knockout Trophy (or "Mini World Cup") in Kenya in October, England tour Pakistan, for the first time since 1987-88. They play three Tests and three one-day internationals there, finishing early in December, before returning home for a break. In February England go to Sri Lanka, for three more Tests and three more ODIs. Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous Q&A session, Memories of the Invincibles and six sixes, click here We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

fields.headline: How to win friends
fields.standfirst: Keep the Jaffa cakes handy, but watch your record collection, warns Hadley Freeman
fields.trailText: As every good material girl and boy knows, possessions speak louder than words. Nowhere is this quick-fix method of equipping yourself with a ready-made identity more necessary than during your first year at university. With only your body and tiny room in halls as your canvas for this self-expression, packing for university requires subtle strategic planning.
fields.body:
As every good material girl and boy knows, possessions speak louder than words. Nowhere is this quick-fix method of equipping yourself with a ready-made identity more necessary than during your first year at university. With only your body and tiny room in halls as your canvas for this self-expression, packing for university requires subtle strategic planning.

Potential minefields await you from the moment your parents drop you off at the gates. Make no mistake, those welcoming and ever-so-helpful second-years, eager to help you with your luggage, are there, quite simply, to hunt for prey. Arrive at university in a low-cut T-shirt and extra-tight trousers and, although you will not have to carry any of your bags up the five flights of stairs to your shoebox room, you will find it difficult to shake off the sadder, lechier elements in the years above for the next few weeks.

Many freshers make the schoolboy error of dressing as A Student. Ripped T-shirts and baggy combats, ethnic trousers and sandals, tight jeans and colourful jumpers are all looks favoured by those carefully cultivating the student look. Forget it - throughout your first year you'll be so busy trying to remember your next door neighbour's name, the time of your lectures and where the decent pubs are, the last thing you need to worry about is how to maintain a particular look.

The one piece of sartorial advice you may need can be summed up in two words: elasticated waists. The combination of social drinking, chip suppers and general slothfulness guarantees a slight expansion of girth during your university career. Americans, bless 'em, even have a term for this - The Freshman Ten, as in the ten pounds you put on during your first year.

But like many clichés, The Student does contain an element of truth. Any first-year boy who does not bring a guitar, ready to impress his new friends with Paranoid Android or a riff from The White Album, may well have his masculinity questioned, and first-year girls are single-handedly responsible for keeping the incense-stick business burning in this country. Speaking of music, do not forget your CD (or, for extra cred, vinyl) collection. But even this needs careful forethought. One generalisation that can be made about students is that they all judge a potential friend by their music collection. The ritual is, they sift through your album collection as you perch nervously on your duvet (attractively patterned or solidly coloured, never decorated with a cartoon animal). Ironic music may still be the dernier cri, but while The Jackson Five and Shirley Bassey are acceptable, Drivetime 5 and Milli Vanilli are not.

But let's get to the basics. The first thing any sensible 18-year-old leaving home thinks about is food. You are what you eat, so the student whose store cupboard houses a stale economy white loaf, an open tin of mouldering sardines and a half-eaten steak and kidney pie will probably not be inundated with offers of intimate friendship. Equally, if the word organic makes an inordinate number of appearances in your cupboard, your food's colour scheme is brown, you make marks on your milk carton to ensure that no one nefariously steals any and you do your weekly shopping at the health food store 15 miles away, you will not be the one to whom people flock for a wild night out. Large ethnic rugs and photos of sunsets hanging on your walls may also deter people from entering your room, fearful of being regaled with tales of your humorous/incredible/ life-altering experiences from your gap year.

Posters are a separate issue. Every student has a poster in their room, if only to differentiate it from the other identikit hovels in their building. But try to restrain yourself from buying any "hilarious" posters: a luridly coloured Bart Simpson, Mona Lisa with a moustache, Einstein sticking his tongue out and "20 Reasons Why a Beer is Better Than a Woman" will not create the impression that you are outrageously wacky and fun, and lose their comedic value after, ooh, five seconds on your wall.

There are certain possessions that will guarantee an endless stream of visitors: an electric kettle, a pile of magazines and a television. Admittedly, a TV is a high-risk item: I once knew a boy who, after months of pursuit, had finally lured the lovely lady back to his room only to be interrupted mid-seduction by friends determined to watch The Eleven O'Clock Show on their mate's TV.

A plentiful supply of biscuits, teabags and alcohol are always welcome, though these may encourage unwanted moochers and spongers taking up residence in your room, as well as hungry rodents. Alongside television sets, many students bring computers, printers, VCRs and, of course, mobile phones, turning their delapidated rooms into glitzy hi-tech caverns. Of all of these, the most useful is probably the phone, as the phone in your hall will always be hogged by that girl down the corridor maintaining a long-term relationship with her boyfriend from home, and no one will ever give you your phone messages anyway.

So don't forget to bring extension leads if you want to feed your technological habit, as your room is certain to have only one plug outlet.

But let's return to romance: how can you make your room appeal to that desired fellow student who stumbles back to your room with you after the bar has shut? Economy sized boxes of Durex placed "casually" on your bookcase will give your room that rather off-putting whiff of virginal desperation. Changing your sheets from time to time will help your lovelife as much as it will improve your sense of personal hygiene.

It might be worth your while to have a bit of a tidy-up beforehand. Having a photo of your parents gazing at you sternly from your bedside table will be as off-putting to you as it will be to your intended beloved.

Flowers are a cheap way of removing any lingering smells of a late-night kebab munched in bed, and a novel placed on your bedside table can be a good conversation starter, should conversation be needed, eg, "Absolutely, Martin Amis is so overrated," etc. A good rule of thumb for a romance-friendly room can be summed up by the word decent: decent smelling, decent looking, decent time had by all.

But no matter how cosy you make your room, there will be those evenings when it's cold, you've run out of food and everyone except you seems to be out. Suddenly, home, with its bountiful supply of heat and comfortable beds, doesn't seem too bad.

There are ways of staving off these unexpected pangs of homesickness, besides needlessly swamping your bed with stuffed animals or decorating your wall with blu-tacked photographs of your family. Contrary to those well-worn, if not exactly well-loved student stereotypes, you will occasionally wash your clothes, and using the washing powder mum uses at home provides a comforting scent of home and normality. An electric kettle is essential for limescale-free and consoling mugs of tea.

But the key thing to remember as you are anxiously packing your duffel bag for Freshers' week is to relax. Everyone, even that really cool guy in your year who already hangs out with the third-years, is as nervous as you. And if all else fails, just offer everyone you meet a jaffa cake and you will never lack for friends.

fields.headline: All work and no play
fields.standfirst: How much paid work can you afford to do while studying? Richard Colebourn reports
fields.trailText: While working during those long holidays has always been a part of student life, increasing numbers find they are forced into employment during term by the rising costs of studying.
fields.body:
While working during those long holidays has always been a part of student life, increasing numbers find they are forced into employment during term by the rising costs of studying. Forty-two per cent of those in higher education work while resident at university, and for many it is not solely to fund an over-active social life. Indeed, 36% report that they are forced to find work in order to meet their basic living costs.

With tuition fees rising to £1,050 from the start of the academic year, and Barclays Bank reporting that the average student graduates £4,497 in debt, the financial pressures on students have never been greater.

But students seeking work shouldn't expect a bulging wage packet. Research by the National Union of Students and the TUC shows that the average student earns £4.37 an hour, but 3% of students earn less than the national minimum wage - just £3.20 an hour for those aged between 18 and 21. This compares unfavourably with the average adult hourly pay of £10.03.

Kath Rothman, vice-president for welfare at Bristol University Students' Union, says that most students work part-time in pubs or clubs, either during the evening or at weekends. "The majority probably work for two or three evenings a week, or all day Saturday or Sunday. But there are a small minority who are really working full-time, for 30 hours or so a week, in offices or shops.

"There is a worrying trend for students to work for longer hours, and some struggle with their academic work. Students are now forced to manage their time and priorities, because of new financial pressures, in a way that was never the case in the past," she comments. She hears of medical and dentistry students who work night shifts as ancillary nurses and do their academic work during the day.

Bristol, like many other universities, has a job centre for students. Rothman suggests there is sometimes a conflict between helping students to find work and advising them on the sensible number of hours to work.

Angela Phillips, a tutor in media and communications at Goldsmith's College in London, says that students working during term are a growing problem. "We find that if we alter the time of a lecture, students may miss them for a whole term because they clash with their shift. Particularly at the end of term, students are under immense financial pressure and the problem is at its worst in the third year, when students find that they have missed a lot of work, especially with practical courses.

"In the past there was the assumption that students were on a full-time course, and you didn't go out and work at the same time. The changes in student finance happened so fast, the university system has not caught up," she says. Phillips says that tutors have always tried to give flexibility to students who have children, but has difficulty seeing how tutors can fit in with the working times of all their students. "In America there has always been work available on campus for students, but we have the problem that this sort of work [in the UK] is done by staff who would obviously resent their jobs being taken away," she comments.

According to the NUS, the average student works for just over 13 hours and puts in six and a half hours overtime. Yet 59% of students claim that their job has slightly affected their studies and 15% claim it has either badly or very badly influenced the quality of their work. Indeed just under half go so far as to say that they would have got higher grades had they not been employed.

But what is the maximum number of hours a student should work, before it starts to impinge on their studies?

John Sander, student employment officer at Sussex University and vice-chair of the National Association of Student Employment Staff, advises students not to work for more than 15 hours a week. Research from the United States suggests that working between 10 and 20 hours has an almost insignificant effect on student's academic progress. Working more that 20 has a negative impact, but interestingly students who do not work at all get worse grades.

Sander explains this by the fact that "a job forces time management and so can improve grades". He highlights studies by Dr Phillip Gardner at the University of Michigan which show that those students who didn't get a job spent more time socialising rather than studying. Sander advises new students at university who want to earn money to do so in their first two years when their academic load is lighter.

He also suggests that they don't limit themselves to what they might perceive as traditional student jobs, such as serving in a bar or working in an office. "Try and develop skills, such as word processing or using the internet, which will help you to increase employment opportunities, and will be of use after you graduate as well," he says. At Sussex, most students work in part-time clerical jobs, but those who have skills valuable to employers have a serious advantage. Sander explains that students who have computer skills and can design web pages can earn £200-300 a week without working many hours, and having a second language allows you to earn good money translating. Students should head straight to their university employment office for advice. "Student employment services are there to provide enough opportunities for students to work reasonable hours at decent pay, although people who really want to work 20 or 30 hours a week can always find work elsewhere," he says.

The NUS study finds that a considerable number of students don't manage to find jobs with responsible employers. One-third report health and safety problems in the work place, and 27% claim work has affected their health. They also don't always get a fair deal when it comes down to their pay. Two-thirds do the same job as permanently paid staff, but of these 29% are paid less than full-time employees.

"Check out the pay of other employees. If students are part-time workers then they should not receive less pay than full-time members of staff," says Bharti Patel, director of the Low Pay Unit. If a job lasts for more than 13 weeks then the employee is entitled to holidays, and after four weeks they can demand a written contract.

Students can get advice on their rights at work from their student union welfare advisers, their university employment office or the TUC's advice line on 0870 600 4882 or its website, www.tuc.org.uk/rights/know_ your_rights

fields.headline: Net gain
fields.standfirst: Easy access to the net can put you streets ahead in the clearing race - which helps the middle classes maintain their lead. John Crace reports
fields.trailText: The digital age has arrived. Almost every university now has its own website with an admissions' application only a click away, and the government's higher education online dream is well on the way to fruition. It should be the cause for loud celebrations, and yet the applause so far has been distinctly muted.
fields.body:
The digital age has arrived. Almost every university now has its own website with an admissions' application only a click away, and the government's higher education online dream is well on the way to fruition. It should be the cause for loud celebrations, and yet the applause so far has been distinctly muted.

To find out why, you need look no further than Digital Decisions, a new report from Dr Anthony Hesketh of Lancaster University Management School into the role of the internet in shaping the higher-education choices of applicants. The research was commissioned by Teletext, which was investigating an idea for its own student dot.com, and its findings make sober reading for both policy makers and the universities.

Stephen Byers, the secretary of state for trade and industry, said recently that familiarity with the new digital world is a "key enabler of a modern, knowledge-driven economy", and the government has pledged itself to widening participation for disadvantaged communities through greater access to modern information and communication technologies. To help achieve this, it has established the National Grid for Learning, which aims to get all schools and colleges online by 2002, and Tony Blair has said everyone should have their own email address by 2005.

It all sounds great. But some things are easier said than done. There was anecdotal evidence last year that some better-off students were able to secure a significant advantage for themselves by emailing in their clearing applications, while the rest of the student population was left to struggle with constantly engaged telephones, and Hesketh's research suggests that this socio-economic digital divide is very much a reality when it comes to students' higher- education choices.

Ninety-five per cent of the research sample of 1,300 sixth-form students and 200 mature entrants from FE colleges said they had access to the internet, but the quality of the connectivity varied greatly, and Hesketh divided the group into those with real access, quasi access and the disconnected.

Real access meant that students either had their own PC at home or access to their parents' PC, while quasi-access implied that students could get online through schools, cyber-cafes or libraries with all the attendant restrictions of time, travel and queueing.

Predictably, those from the high socio-economic groups were more than twice as likely to be found in the real-access group, while the converse was true for quasi-access. Professor Paul Foley of De Montfort University has conducted research that paints a bleaker picture still. His finding that "the relative wealth of internet users has been decreasing in recent years" initially suggests a widening participation in IT, but his observations on the different ways the internet is used are cause for deep concern.

Although relatively less wealthy households have an increasing presence on the net, the same households are also more likely to disconnect from it. Moreover, the lower the relative wealth of a household, the less time it spends connected to the internet. Foley concludes that households that have been connected to the net for over two years are, on average, households with twice the wealth of those who disconnect from the net within 10 days.

"It suggests that lower- income households are attracted to the idea of the internet and get connected," says Hesketh, "but feel that the hype does not live up to their expectations. So they switch off." The effects are likely to be catastrophic. Hard as it may be to get someone to try out the internet for the first time, it is nothing in comparison to the difficulty of persuading them to reconnect to something they have already experienced and rejected.

A large part of the problem, though, is the quality of the information that is accessible online; and it is here that higher-education institutions must shoulder their share of responsibility. "Many universities think that all they have to do to create a website is to upload their prospectus," says Hesketh. "That is just not good enough."

The information students want from universities is not some polished sales pitch sandwiched between a couple of bland photos, but a warts-and-all picture of university life - from the academic to the social. The comments Hesketh collected from his focus groups about university websites were almost unanimously condemnatory. "They are all very boring. Once you've seen one, you've seen them all" was a typical example, and suggested improvements varying from a webcam in a lecture to show what actually goes on, to emailing students already at the university to get the inside information.

One student reckoned that it was "almost as if universities don't want to let the cat out of the bag in the fear that we won't turn up and pay their extortionate tuition fees". This last point gets to the heart of the matter. Not so long ago students received higher-education grants that covered tuition and sometimes went a long way to covering their living expenses; moreover the hierarchical divisions between institutions were made more explicit through the university and polytechnic sectors. So students not only had a fair idea of what they were getting by way of an education, they also had no - or little - personal financial investment in their decision.

How things change. Most university students now finish their education with a debt of roughly £1,000, and with the former polys rebranded as universities there has been a deliberate blurring of the distinctions between higher-education institutions. "The universities probably divide into four distinct divisions," says Hesketh, "and each university will have a fairly good idea of where it stands in the pecking order. However, everyone will try to make out to prospective students that they are either as good as or better than the others."

This may not be such a problem for those from higher socio-economic groups whose parents might have been to university and can point them in the right direction of, say, a university league table. But widening participation also means people from families with no experience of higher education are now going to university and the same informal channels of information are not open to them.

fields.bodyText: The digital age has arrived. Almost every university now has its own website with an admissions' application only a click away, and the government's higher education online dream is well on the way to fruition. It should be the cause for loud celebrations, and yet the applause so far has been distinctly muted. To find out why, you need look no further than Digital Decisions, a new report from Dr Anthony Hesketh of Lancaster University Management School into the role of the internet in shaping the higher-education choices of applicants. The research was commissioned by Teletext, which was investigating an idea for its own student dot.com, and its findings make sober reading for both policy makers and the universities. Stephen Byers, the secretary of state for trade and industry, said recently that familiarity with the new digital world is a "key enabler of a modern, knowledge-driven economy", and the government has pledged itself to widening participation for disadvantaged communities through greater access to modern information and communication technologies. To help achieve this, it has established the National Grid for Learning, which aims to get all schools and colleges online by 2002, and Tony Blair has said everyone should have their own email address by 2005. It all sounds great. But some things are easier said than done. There was anecdotal evidence last year that some better-off students were able to secure a significant advantage for themselves by emailing in their clearing applications, while the rest of the student population was left to struggle with constantly engaged telephones, and Hesketh's research suggests that this socio-economic digital divide is very much a reality when it comes to students' higher- education choices. Ninety-five per cent of the research sample of 1,300 sixth-form students and 200 mature entrants from FE colleges said they had access to the internet, but the quality of the connectivity varied greatly, and Hesketh divided the group into those with real access, quasi access and the disconnected. Real access meant that students either had their own PC at home or access to their parents' PC, while quasi-access implied that students could get online through schools, cyber-cafes or libraries with all the attendant restrictions of time, travel and queueing. Predictably, those from the high socio-economic groups were more than twice as likely to be found in the real-access group, while the converse was true for quasi-access. Although relatively less wealthy households have an increasing presence on the net, the same households are also more likely to disconnect from it. Moreover, the lower the relative wealth of a household, the less time it spends connected to the internet. So they switch off." The effects are likely to be catastrophic. Hard as it may be to get someone to try out the internet for the first time, it is nothing in comparison to the difficulty of persuading them to reconnect to something they have already experienced and rejected. fields.headline: Debt alert
fields.standfirst: Being stoney broke is a fact of life for students. Ian Wylie has some tips on how to manage your money, and where to get your hands on some more
fields.trailText: Good A-level results are a gateway to a new world of learning, but with as many as nine out of 10 graduates leaving university this summer in debt - and many expected to spend the next few years firmly in the red - a university education can be a painful lesson in managing on a tight budget.
fields.body:
Good A-level results are a gateway to a new world of learning, but with as many as nine out of 10 graduates leaving university this summer in debt - and many expected to spend the next few years firmly in the red - a university education can be a painful lesson in managing on a tight budget.

According to a survey by Barclays Bank, students left university in 1999 with an average of £5,286 of debt, up 18% from the previous year. This year debts are expected to be even higher - even though the full effect of the introduction of tuition fees has yet to feed through. And if the leading vice-chancellors who make up the Russell Group, an elite committee of the 19 top UK universities, have their way, in future students could be facing US-style fees of up to £6,000 a year. This will be in addition to other costs associated with college life, everything from accommodation, food and books to other living expenses.

As it is, the National Union of Students estimates that the average student in London, Oxford and Cambridge spends around £7,192 a year on essential items, and £5,581 if at a provincial university. Your first priority will be to pay your tuition fees. Universities will usually stop people graduating if fees are unpaid. However, the maximum tuition-fee contribution expected from students in 2000/2001 is £1,050 and around a third of all students - those whose family income is below £17,805 - will not be required to pay tuition fees.

There are also courses, or certain years of some courses, where your college will charge fees of £520 instead of £1,050. And if you are a student on a full-time or part-time course of initial teacher training (other than a first degree course), you should receive free tuition whatever your and your family's income. In any case, most students are entitled to a grant towards their fees. This grant is based on an assessment by your local education authority of your income and that of your family.

Your local authority will want details of your parents' residual income. It does this by taking their gross income, for income-tax purposes, and subtracting certain allowances. Then the local authority decides the parental contribution according to the following calculation: no contribution if their income is less than £17,805; £45 if their residual income is at least £17,805; plus £1 for every £13 of residual income between £17,806 and £22,754; plus £1 for every £9.20 between £22,755 and £33,449; plus £1 for every £7.50 for £33,450 and over. The maximum contribution is £6,437.

However, the actual parental contribution cannot be more than the maximum fee contribution of £1,050. Different rules also apply if you have a brother or sister who is also receiving student support from the local authority. Your parents' total contribution will be worked out before it is shared between yourself and your siblings. In normal circumstances, it will be shared out equally.

But for all your other expenditure - rent, books, food, going out - you'll need to consider alternative sources of finance, such as a student loan. The maximum amount of loan that you can get depends on where you live and study; which course you study; which year of your course you are on; how much you and your family are expected to contribute, and the length of your academic year.

Three-quarters of the maximum loan available does not depend on your or your family's income. For the 2000/ 2001 academic year, all students should qualify for a loan of £2,795 (£3,445 in London) per annum. Some, from less well-off backgrounds, will be eligible for the maximum loan of £3,725 (£4,590 in London). If you're intending to live at home with your parents, you will be eligible for a loan of £2,215 to £2,950, depending on income. You don't have to borrow the full entitlement, but most students do as you cannot apply for a top-up later. The loan can be paid either in three equal instalments or in one lump sum. The latter course is suitable for students with willpower as they can earn interest on the sum advanced until it is needed. If you cannot resist the urge to spend, you should opt to receive an equal portion of your entitlement each term.

Tell your parents to dig deep. Calculations from the National Union of Students suggest that even after loans, students will still face a shortfall of more than £3,000 in each undergraduate year.

Some parents are better prepared than others. The most prudent will have been setting money aside for five years and more in a Tessa, PEP, ISA or endowment policy. Parents with less than a few months to prepare will have little option but to divert money from funds saved for retirement, or to borrow.

Revolving credit or "draw-down" loans secured on a home are a cheaper and more flexible form of borrowing than personal loans or overdrafts, allowing parents to draw down cash each term. Parents should also remember that most banks offer preferential rates to students - your parents may have reservations about letting you loose with an interest-free overdraft, but it makes sound financial sense to take advantage of cheap credit where available.

Students are also increasingly likely to take part-time jobs, though universities - and the NUS - tend to advise against it. The job market depends on the area, of course, but several sources of student earnings are not taken into consideration by your local authority when calculating grants. Wages from casual or part-time vacation and term-time jobs, the first £820 of their unearned income, £1,000 of any scholarship and £1,855 of any trust income are all ignored. Sums above these figures reduce the student's support £1 for £1.

Access funds and hardship loans are available to help students who are in financial difficulty. They can be used to help with living expenses and course costs including childcare costs, travel, accommodation, household expenses, books and course equipment. You will usually need to wait until you have started your course before you can apply for either a hardship loan or an access funds payment. However, if you think you may need additional financial help to complete your course, you should talk to your college before you start the course, about how these two schemes might be able to help you.

Colleges decide which students will receive payments and how much each payment will be. Student support or student services staff at your college will be able to advise you which scheme will best suit your needs.They will tell you how to apply. In some cases you may be able to have an access fund payment and a hardship loan at the same time.

There are a few charitable trusts and organisations that can assist students. Many of the payments may be small, to help assist with the purchase of books and equipment; others can be quite substantial. Schools or libraries should have details of local educational trusts and charities. The Educational Grants Advisory Service, part of the Family Welfare Association, also has a comprehensive database of charities and trusts.

Details of the scales, allowances and additional payments can be found in the Department for Education and Employment's booklet, Financial Support for Higher Education Students in 2000/2001. To obtain a copy telephone 0800-731 9133
