fields.headline: Out of the ashes
fields.standfirst:
Even if Concorde could be patched up, would anyone really want to fly on it? Well, yes actually - if the history of technology and disasters is anything to go by. Jonathan Glancey reports

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Even if Concorde could be patched up, would anyone really want to fly on it? Well, yes actually - if the history of technology and disasters is anything to go by.  Jonathan Glancey  reports.
fields.body:
It was the rough equivalent of printing the obituary as soon as the patient was admitted to hospital. Scarcely had British Airways announced that it was grounding its Concorde fleet than the scribblers and assorted experts were predicting that the exotic bird would never fly again. It wasn't long before the "I told you so" brigade was in full song, pointing out that it had been a silly idea from the start - a commercial failure, a dubious display of propagandist technology and plain hubris.

The predictions of Concorde's demise had little to do with the specific nature of the technical flaws discovered by French crash investigators - after all, fixing a wheel can't be rocket science. Instead it had everything to do with the aircraft's apparently fatal loss of a crucial and often elusive commodity: public confidence. Put simply, however thoroughly Concorde is patched up, however many guarantees of its safety are issued, it seems unlikely that anyone will feel confident enough to fly in it. Or at least that enough people will to make it economically viable.

But if history is any judge, reports of Concorde's death could be, to misquote Mark Twain, greatly exaggerated. Accidents and disasters happen. A bridge collapses, a fire breaks out in a tunnel, some foodstuff - eggs, beef - is found to make us ill, a new car with a high centre of gravity topples over at high speed, a medical drug causes an unforeseen outbreak of some nameless dread, and yet we go on to cross and recross bridges, drive through tunnels, boil eggs, roast beef, change lanes erratically on wind-lashed motorways at 100mph and swallow pills of uncertain provenance and dubious effect.

It took three fatal crashes between May 1953 and April 1954 for BOAC to withdraw its depleted fleet of Comet airliners. The De Havilland Comet was the world's first jet airliner, a winged wonder to those who witnessed its first fare-paying flight on May 2 1952 from Heathrow to Johannesburg just as much as Concorde was when it took commercial wing some 24 years later. Unfortunately it also suffered metal fatigue: the fuselage expanded as the futuristic 500mph aircraft climbed into the stratosphere, cracks appeared and it fell apart.

Yet four years later, the Comet 4, a similar aircraft, took to the air on the London to New York run. Passengers appeared to have had no fear of this stretched Comet, but what it had lost on the way to production was the confidence of airlines. Only 74 were sold worldwide: De Havilland had expected orders of up to 1,000. Just as well perhaps as, in all, 20 Comets crashed, killing nearly 500 people. The British jet was killed off in any case by the all-conquering Boeing 707, which set out from New York to London just a month after the Comet 4. Knowing the Comet's reputation, one of the first flights I paid for with my own money was on board a bucket-shop Dan Air Comet 4B at the tail end of its working life. We put accidents and disasters behind us, otherwise we would never fly, cross a bridge or dive into a tunnel.

"In terms of Concorde," says Dr Peter Marsh, psychologist and co-director of the Social Issues Research Centre, "it comes down to the public's perception of risk. A plane crash is obviously seen as a disaster, but people are very aware that planes in general are a safe way of travelling [the risk of your plane crashing this year is approximately a million to one]. Even people who have a fear of flying are prepared to get on planes after crashes. The same applied to Concorde after the Paris crash. In fact, I think people will become very nostalgic if Concorde is grounded for ever; this is quite rational behaviour because people can work out the extent of their individual risk. Concorde is very unlikely to cause their death."

The fire that broke out in 1996 has not discouraged millions of motorists, lorry drivers and Eurostar passengers (19 million last year) from travelling through the Channel tunnel; it is by far the most convenient link for most people between England and France. Passenger numbers were back up to pre-fire levels just a few weeks later.

Similarly, many will remember the Herald of Free Enterprise, the roll-on, roll-off ferry that set sail from Zeebrugge in 1987, bow doors resolutely open. The car decks filled with water and it sank three quarters of a mile outside the harbour. Seven years later the bow doors were ripped off the Estonia as it sailed off the Finnish coast in a storm: 834 people died. It shouldn't have been on the high sea in a storm, just as there had been no excuse for the Herald of Free Enterprise to set sail with its bow doors open. Yet these incidents are rare and have not stopped many millions of people from sailing with their cars and loved ones across waters that can be every bit as treacherous.

"What these accidents do tend to encourage," says Neil Brown, of the Science Museum in London, "is greater care and safety in the future. The reason the Forth Railway bridge was so hugely over-engineered was, in part, a response to the spectacular collapse of the Tay bridge a few years earlier. The Tay bridge was the longest in the world at the time of its construction in 1878; its loss [along with a locomotive, six carriages and 75 lives], was a blow to national prestige. This was the single greatest structural failure in these islands. It couldn't happen again."

It didn't. Today's great bridges are nearly all held up by suspension cables. Forth, Severn and Humber road bridges all sway in the wind, yet we trust them not to give way to gravity as the Tacoma Narrows bridge, in Washington state, did in 1940. "Gallopin' Gertie", just 19 months old and so named because of her sick-making vertical oscillations, got herself into a mother of a twist that November. Twisting and shaking for 45 minutes, one sidewalk rose 28ft above the other before the cables snapped and Gertie gave up the ghost. A freak occurrence we say, and put it down to that.

Entire technologies can be almost completely obliterated by major accidents - recall the fires that destroyed the R101 and Hindenburg airships in the 1930s - but in most cases, the spirit of opti mism triumphs over the dark angel of experience. In 1990 traces of benzene were found in Perrier at the height of the water's success in restaurants worldwide. One hundred and sixty million green bottles were recalled from the shelves of bistros, hotels and grocery stores. An investigation kept the sparkling water off the market for several months. This should have been time enough for Perrier's rivals, such as Evian and San Pellegrino, to sparkle. But no one had become ill and no one had died. "Helleau," said the posters that June. The benzene incident has been forgotten.

"Perrier," says Peter Marsh, "was a temporary accident. With effective PR it was easy to get public confidence back. But when people start believing that a certain food is truly toxic then you'll find an almost religious fervour against it. Evidence for the product will be misread. Unreason rules the roost." As, of course, it did in 1989 when a salmonella scare - real enough, but overegged - scrambled British brains. In our millions we took against the humble egg and with it Edwina Currie, a junior agriculture minister, who was duly sacrificed. A few years later came BSE and the unedifying sight of John Gummer, John Major's secretary of state for the environment, force-feeding his unfortunate daughter with a burger to prove to the press that she would not suffer from eating British beef.

"We've seen people becoming increasingly fearful of food because of BSE and GM scares", says Marsh. "Today there are influential organisations virtually dedicated to driving these fears."

Much the same applies to the continuing debate over the mumps, measles and rubella (MMR) vaccine. This began in 1996 when an article in the British Medical Journal linked it to autism. It caused a national scare among parents that has yet to abate. "The article was based on a study of just 25 children," a department of health spokesperson wearily points out. "No causal link was established between autism and the vaccine. Every single bit of research that has been done on the topic since then has shown results to the contrary of the original study, but people still go on about it and parents are still worried." Our reaction to technologies that we believe to have failed or to be dangerous is undoubtedly confused. Concorde lets us down fatally for the first time in almost 25 years and it is promptly consigned to the scrapyard of history. And yet we may well rue its passing. Scares come and go. Has the Channel tunnel led to a plague of foreign rats and rabies in Little Britain? No. Has John Gummer's unfortunate daughter succumbed to BSE? No. Was anyone in a power suit poisoned by a bottle of Perrier? Again, no.

Not long ago I got to drive a Chevrolet Corvair. (This was the car that made Ralph Nader's name as a champion of consumer rights in the 60s. Nader's book Unsafe at Any Speed did an effective j'accuse job on the rear-engined American sedan.)

"You're not going to drive one really, are you?" asked an American friend. "You're crazy. You'll kill yourself." I didn't because the car I drove was a '68 model; its rear suspension, the source of the car's troubles between 1960 and 1963, had been well and truly sorted out. The car drove safely, just as transatlantic liners sailed more safely after the sinking of the Titanic, as railway bridges were made safer after the Tay Bridge disaster, as suspension bridges were after the Tacoma Narrows incident.

Sometimes our faith in progress is dented, but although you might not want to travel on one, airships are still blimping through the air 63 years on from the Hindenburg fire. And Concorde - the magnificent flying machine that fell to earth - might yet defy the obituarists.

A few years later came BSE and the unedifying sight of John Gummer, John Major's secretary of state for the environment, force-feeding his unfortunate daughter with a burger to prove to the press that she would not suffer from eating British beef. "We've seen people becoming increasingly fearful of food because of BSE and GM scares", says Marsh. "Today there are influential organisations virtually dedicated to driving these fears." Much the same applies to the continuing debate over the mumps, measles and rubella (MMR) vaccine. This began in 1996 when an article in the British Medical Journal linked it to autism. It caused a national scare among parents that has yet to abate. "The article was based on a study of just 25 children," a department of health spokesperson wearily points out. "No causal link was established between autism and the vaccine. Every single bit of research that has been done on the topic since then has shown results to the contrary of the original study, but people still go on about it and parents are still worried." Our reaction to technologies that we believe to have failed or to be dangerous is undoubtedly confused. Concorde lets us down fatally for the first time in almost 25 years and it is promptly consigned to the scrapyard of history. And yet we may well rue its passing. Scares come and go. Has the Channel tunnel led to a plague of foreign rats and rabies in Little Britain? No. Has John Gummer's unfortunate daughter succumbed to BSE? No. Was anyone in a power suit poisoned by a bottle of Perrier? Again, no. Not long ago I got to drive a Chevrolet Corvair. (This was the car that made Ralph Nader's name as a champion of consumer rights in the 60s. Nader's book Unsafe at Any Speed did an effective j'accuse job on the rear-engined American sedan.) "You're not going to drive one really, are you?" asked an American friend. "You're crazy. You'll kill yourself." I didn't because the car I drove was a '68 model; its rear suspension, the source of the car's troubles between 1960 and 1963, had been well and truly sorted out. The car drove safely, just as transatlantic liners sailed more safely after the sinking of the Titanic, as railway bridges were made safer after the Tay Bridge disaster, as suspension bridges were after the Tacoma Narrows incident. Sometimes our faith in progress is dented, but although you might not want to travel on one, airships are still blimping through the air 63 years on from the Hindenburg fire. And Concorde - the magnificent flying machine that fell to earth - might yet defy the obituarists.

fields.headline: Freeserve in slow lane
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Freeserve looks to be the latest internet service provider to suffer problems implementing an unmetered internet access package.
fields.body:
Freeserve looks to be the latest internet service provider to suffer problems implementing an unmetered internet access package.

Reportedly, users of its unmetered off-peak access offering are experiencing a slow service and in some cases are failing to make a connection at all.

A statement on the Freeserve website said that it was making significant progress in restoring standards of service during evenings and weekends to their "usual high levels".

Freeserve also said that it expects the service to be back to normal by mid-September.

While Freeserve is not alone in suffering problems with an unmetered internet access offering - both Telewest and NTL have been hit by difficulties and LineOne has ended its service - the news could unsettle the shares today.

Freeserve shares closed at 267.75p, up 0.25p.

fields.headline: It's a jungle out there
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Coronation Street/Starstruck/Cousins
fields.body:
'H ave you no pride?" Blanche Hunt asked Deirdre in Coronation Street (ITV), evidently unaware of how her daughter has behaved over the years. Asking Deirdre Hunt Langford Barlow Rachid, the Weatherfield One, such a question is like asking Imelda Marcos if she has any shoes.

"After all you've achieved and the way you've bettered yourself", Blanche moaned when Deirdre was considering taking a job in a corner shop. After all she's achieved? Is that in a Bart Simpson kind of way? Admittedly, there was the stint as a local councillor, but her messy divorce from Ken (after her affair with Mike and ordeals with Ray) and allegations of sleaze put paid to that. And what with a couple of suicide attempts, involvements with Phil the dodgy businessman, a Moroccan waiter and Jon the Fake Pilot, achievements is maybe the wrong word. She couldn't even escape from HMP Weatherfield; her glasses were too big for her to squeeze through the bars. And in the been-around-the-block-to-Rosamund-Street-and-back poll of Corrie's women, Elsie Tanner may top the list with 21, but Deirdre comes in third - after Bet - with, at the last count, 14. That makes her the biggest strumpet in the Street. Sticky-out tendons, she has. Pride, not an iota. Deirdre knows her place. And that is serving. Coronation Street as a device to keep the working-class down. Discuss.

After all, anyone in Weatherfield who tries to climb the social ladder gets a smack on the head for their hubris. Deirdre got banged up - with Margi Clarke, no less - for trying to buy a £100,000 house, after all. Maxine will surely be next as she inveigles her way into the golf club. They should put a sign up outside the Rovers: "Don't get ideas above your station. You're no better than you should be."

Which is a sign they could also hang on the Hollywood Hills. For every aspiring star, luxuriant hair, good boobs, sparkling eyes and legs up to your armpits are useless in Hollywood unless you have thick skin. Without thick skin to protect you against the daily psychological battering you have to take when directors dismiss you as too fat, too ugly, too unbeddable, you'd become a crazed self-loathing husk of your former self. The subject matter of Starstruck (C4) may have been a bit obvious (Hollywood is a fascistic place where only the perceived-to-be-beautiful prosper) but it was so well-made, it became instantly engaging.

It wasn't just the line-up of impressive interviewees - Anjelica Huston, Pam Grier, Bruce Robinson, Fay Ripley - and their honesty about their own self-image; the stories of Renee Simone, a wannabe Hollywood starlet, and Ella Kenion, a British "character actress" were enthralling.

At eight stones, Renee was a big chubster. The rest of America may be populated by lardy folks but LA is the land of the thin. And Hollywood is home to stick insect people. For Renee to make it, she had to lose another stone on top of the 55lbs she'd already lost. And get her eyebrows and hair done, and get a push-up bra. Oh, and she had to get her self-esteem removed too. Unsurprisingly, Renee often seemed on the verge of tears.

Ella, meanwhile, acknowledged she had a big bum and big boobs (what a freak!) and knew she'd never be cast as a leading lady. Best friends, wives and maids were her bag. She accepted that, albeit grudgingly, and poured herself a large vodka tonic. Ella was great.

Renee's "management" were not. They thought she should go for freaks'n'geeks roles and leave the ingénue roles to someone who could stomach two fingers and a saucer of salty water for dinner. Renee is now seeking new management.

Starstruck's conclusions - everyone is typecast, fortune favours the fanciable - aren't huge revelations, but pointing up our complicity in the whole conspiracy was like a dose of cod liver oil. Good for you but it leaves a bad taste.

Darwinian theory was also on display in Cousins (BBC1). As Charlotte Uhlenbroek trekked through jungles with her torch, it looked a bit like a deodorant advert, but then it became apparent: she was about to climb our family tree. In doing so she met gorillas, chimps and lemurs from whom we are descended.

There was a lemur with toxic saliva (an ancestor of Lynda Lee Potter, perhaps), one with a fat tail (the Danny Baker lemur) and a lemur whose eyes weigh more than its brain. The Deirdre Rachid lemur, we can only presume.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Guys And Dolls/Manon Des Sources/Austin Powers: International Man Of Mystery/Cold Water
fields.body:
Guys And Dolls

(Joseph L Mankiewicz, 1955)

8.45am, Carlton Cinema

A scintillating all-American musical experience, bubbling over with vivid New York energy. Feisty playing too, with Marlon Brando's Sky Masterson betting Frank Sinatra's Nathan Detroit he can charm Salvation Army girl Jean Simmons.

Manon Des Sources

(Claude Berri, 1986)

6pm, FilmFour

This picks up the story of Berri's masterly Jean De Florette 10 years on. Manon (Emmanuelle Béart), daughter of the now dead Jean, is a beautiful young shepherdess seeking revenge on Soubeyran (Yves Montand) and his nephew Ugolin (Daniel Auteuil) for appropriating her father's farm. She blocks the spring that supplies the village, and unexpected emotions and events well up.

Austin Powers: International Man Of Mystery

(Jay Roach, 1997)

8pm, FilmFour

The original adventures of Austin Powers, the secret agent cryogenically frozen in his 60s heyday and reactivated in the seriously dull 90s to do battle with nemesis Dr Evil: funny-man Mike Myers is inspired in both roles in this hilariously high-camp spoof. The hey-man-groovy lingo, Jason King clothes and general psychedelic silliness are right on, even if the joke is exhausted before the end. Elizabeth Hurley makes a thoroughly modern sidekick called Vanessa Kensington.

Cold Water

(Olivier Assayas, 1994)

1.40am, FilmFour

Made as part of a French series, Boys And Girls Of Their Time, in which directors revisited their childhoods, Assayas' film is set just outside Paris in 1972. It's the story of two 16-year-olds, Gilles (Cyprien Fouquet) and Christine (Virginie Ledoyen), both of whom are in increasingly serious trouble - with the police, their families, and at school. Ledoyen and Fouquet give astonishingly natural performances embodying anarchic, painful teendom - this is no cosy tale where good wins out. In spare, terse scenes we see the emotional brittleness of their families, and how this makes them all the more reliant on each other. Clothes, cars and a Janis Joplin/Creedence Clearwater soundtrack evoke the early 70s perfectly.

webTitle: Scientists fear nuclear meltdown on seabed

fields.headline: Scientists fear nuclear meltdown on seabed
fields.standfirst:
Safety: Reactor damage could lead to chain reaction

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: An uncontrolled chain reaction in the engine compartment of the stricken Russian nuclear submarine Kursk was "the worst case scenario" being contemplated by Russian experts yesterday.
fields.body:
An uncontrolled chain reaction in the engine compartment of the stricken Russian nuclear submarine Kursk was "the worst case scenario" being contemplated by Russian experts yesterday.

If that happened the fuel would heat up to 1800 to 2000C, enough to melt the engine compartment and outer casing, releasing molten fuel onto the seabed.

Mils Bohmer, a Russian nuclear physicist, said this would release fission products like plutonium, caesium and uranium into the fertile fishing grounds of the Barents sea. However, the true state of the reactors is not yet known.

"We were told that the first stage of shutting the reactors down had been completed, but there is no word on what happened after that," he said. "If the crew managed to shut them down completely then they should remain safe, but if not then the fuel elements may start to heat up and begin an uncontrolled chain reaction."

Mr Bohmer was speaking in Oslo, where he has been helping the Norwegian environmental group the Bellona Foundation in its efforts to get the derelict submarines of the Russian fleet made safe.

He said because there had been an explosion in the forward area it was not possible to know the effect on the crew in the engine compartment at the rear had been or how much time they may have had to act.

The reactor in the submarine was of a new design with a "natural" cooling system which works even if there is no electrical power, but it might not be effective if there was damage or the reactor had not been fully shut down.

William Peden, a Greenpeace disarmament campaigner, said that the automatic cooling system worked on convection and its efficiency would be badly affected because the stricken vessel was lying on its side.

"There is also concern because the explosion would have caused a breach in the hull part of the containment if the radioactivity begins to leak out," he said. "There is a real fear of a meltdown if the cooling system does work properly. To protect the area from serious radioactive pollution the Russians have no alternative but to raise the sub."

Mr Bohmer believed the Russians would want to raise the sub anyway because it was in relatively shallow water - 108 metres (353ft) - and, as a relatively new boat it contains military secrets the Russians would be keen to protect from other powers.

In one sense the sea is the best place for damaged nuclear equipment because of the dilution and cooling effect of vast quantities of sea water.

However, the Kursk has gone down in one of the most productive fisheries in the world, where Norwegians catch large quantities of cod, some of which is exported for English fish and chips.

The Russians have suffered nuclear accidents there before. However, the Komsomolets, which sunk in April 1989, rests in 1,850 metres (6,069ft) of water and although it is leaking slightly is not contaminating fishing grounds.

Yesterday the news from the area of the Kursk was good. Tests of water and air samples by the Norwegian Nuclear Protection Authority said five water samples and two air samples gathered through large filters on Tuesday showed no trace of abnormal radiation. The samples were gathered by Norwegian military vessels monitoring the site.

The authority said it will continue to monitor radiation levels through a network of permanent monitoring stations in northern Norway.

webTitle: British minisub in last-ditch rescue attempt

fields.headline: British minisub in last-ditch rescue attempt
fields.standfirst:
Mission: Team heads for Barents Sea fearing plea for help is too late

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: A British rescue team equipped with a unique minisub is due to leave the Norwegian port of Trondheim today in what may be the last hope for Russian sailors trapped aboard the Kursk.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor,  and  Ian Traynor  in Moscow
fields.body:
A British rescue team equipped with a unique minisub is due to leave the Norwegian port of Trondheim today in what may be the last hope for Russian sailors trapped aboard the Kursk.

The minisub, the LR5 rescue vehicle, is not expected to arrive at the site of the accident in the Barents Sea until Saturday. It has never before been used in a real emergency.

The LR5 can attach a "mating wedge" to the escape hatch of a submarine listing at an angle of 60 degrees, the bow-down position in which defence officials believe the Kursk has been resting over 100 metres down.

A raging Arctic storm whipped up high waves all day yesterday, defeating repeated Russian navy attempts to get rescue capsules to dock with the huge stricken vessel.

No signs of life were detected from the Kursk for the first time in five days, fuelling fears that it was too late for the British attempt to succeed where the Russians had failed.

The deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov, said the fact that the crew had stopped making SOS signals by tapping on the hull of the submarine might not mean "anything terrible", but northern fleet officers in Murmansk said it could augur "something sad".

The Russian navy chief has said repeatedly that oxygen supplies on the submarine will last only until tomorrow, while others fear that the oxygen might have run out already.

Using two rescue capsules sent down from a surface ship, the Russians tried at least five times yesterday to lock on to the submarine's main escape hatch on the upper stern. But the stormy weather, the strong underwater currents, and the lack of visibility all frustrated attempts to lock on to the listing submarine.

The Russian rescue craft, manned by crews of three, ran out of oxygen and one was damaged while surfacing.

The chief designer of the rescue craft said the vessels had not been used for years and that few Russian sailors had any training in how to use them.

The British LR5 also has a crew of three, and acts as an underwater lifeboat for up to 16 people at a time. A "transfer skirt" fixed to the escape hatch of the submarine equalises pressure by pumping out water, creating an airlock. The hatches of the submarine and the LR5 are then opened to enable the sailors to be transferred.

The LR5 would then be steered to the surface, releasing the sailors, and return to collect others from the stricken submarine.

The 34-strong rescue party includes navy divers, doctors, and interpreters. As well as the LR5, they will be equipped with a remote operated vehicle, the Scorpio, which will make an initial reconnaissance and clear any obstructions.

The equipment was flown yesterday in a Russian Antonov to Trondheim from Prestwick airport near Glasgow. It is usually based at Faslane on the Clyde, Britain's nuclear submarine base, where it is kept by the owners, Global Marine, under an exclusive contract with the ministry of defence.

It was being transferred last night onto the Normand Pioneer, a chartered vessel which will act as the mother ship for the operation. Decompression chambers were flown on ahead in RAF Hercules aircraft.

Norway said yesterday it had agreed to a Russian request to send divers and possibly ships to help rescue the Kursk's crew.

The Norwegian foreign ministry said a divers' mother ship now in the Haltenbanken area off north Norway was heading for the area of the Barents Sea above the crippled Kursk nuclear submarine.

"The vessel is starting to move north," foreign minister Thorbjoern Jagland said in a television interview. "These are professional divers who can contribute in many ways. It is our understanding that they will help get the crew out."

Foreign Ministry spokesman Kartsen Klepsvik said the vessel and divers, who had been working in Norway's offshore oil fields, could reach the downed submarine within two days.

The LR5 has been used in five exercises but had never before been used "in anger", Roger Chapman of Rumic, the vessel's operating company, said yesterday. He added that the Russians had asked for help "a bit late".

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, said British and Russian teams would work together "because, as sailors, they will all understand the plight of their colleagues and fellow mariners on the seabed".

He added: "We are delighted to be able to assist in trying to save sailors from an awful fate and one that is of concern to all right thinking people all around the world."

An MoD spokeswoman said last night: "We don't know how far into this the Russians are, what the state of the crew is or the vessel. There are so many things we don't know."

She added: "We see the media coverage of the sailors and the dire situation they're in. Nobody here would like to be in the position they're in. There's a lot of feeling for them in the mariner community."

The Norwegian foreign ministry said a divers' mother ship now in the Haltenbanken area off north Norway was heading for the area of the Barents Sea above the crippled Kursk nuclear submarine. "The vessel is starting to move north," foreign minister Thorbjoern Jagland said in a television interview. "These are professional divers who can contribute in many ways. It is our understanding that they will help get the crew out." Foreign Ministry spokesman Kartsen Klepsvik said the vessel and divers, who had been working in Norway's offshore oil fields, could reach the downed submarine within two days. The LR5 has been used in five exercises but had never before been used "in anger", Roger Chapman of Rumic, the vessel's operating company, said yesterday. He added that the Russians had asked for help "a bit late". John Spellar, the armed forces minister, said British and Russian teams would work together "because, as sailors, they will all understand the plight of their colleagues and fellow mariners on the seabed". He added: "We are delighted to be able to assist in trying to save sailors from an awful fate and one that is of concern to all right thinking people all around the world." An MoD spokeswoman said last night: "We don't know how far into this the Russians are, what the state of the crew is or the vessel. There are so many things we don't know." She added: "We see the media coverage of the sailors and the dire situation they're in. Nobody here would like to be in the position they're in. There's a lot of feeling for them in the mariner community." fields.headline: Tantalising dream of drug-free cure
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: On Tuesday, scientists in Philadelphia and New Jersey managed to produce nerve cells in the laboratory by using stem cells from bone marrow.
fields.body:
On Tuesday, scientists in Philadelphia and New Jersey managed to produce nerve cells in the laboratory by using stem cells from bone marrow.

If they could do that in people, they could treat Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. The research was funded by the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation and clearly, if it worked in humans, these stem cells could repair injured spinal cords. If they could do that, the actor who once played Superman might walk again.

Tomorrow's doctors might take cells from an adult's bone marrow, turn them into nerve cells and then inject them into patients' brains and spinal cords. They would not be rejected, and there would be no immunosuppressive drugs. People who would once have faltered and died would grow whole again.

The first such successes could be more than a decade away: it takes 10 years to get a drug from the idea stage through all the medical trials and into the doctor's surgery. But one day stem cell tissues could be used to treat not just Parkinson's or Alzheimer's, but stroke, spinal cord injury and multiple sclerosis as well.

Heart muscle cells could be used to repair damage by heart attack, or congestive heart disease. Insulin-producing cells could be implanted once every six months, sparing the diabetic the daily horror of direct injections.

Skin cells could be used to repair damage from burns, and liver cells could repair the ravages of hepatitis or cirrhosis. Retinal cells could turn back the tide of macular degeneration, and skeletal muscle cells could treat muscular dystrophy.

In the very long run, once they understand how genetic commands are issued, doctors might be able to grow whole "personalised" organs for transplant.

All these hopes, however, remain just that - hopes. Most of the achievements so far have been more tantalising than successful.

The dream is that scientists will one day understand the mysterious process by which a fertilised egg becomes a complicated creature with lots of different tissues - and from that understanding, "reprogramme" adult cells directly.

Researchers argue that unless they start at the beginning of the chain - the all-purpose stem cells made by the embryo in its first days of life - they will get nowhere.

But, many say, the cures of tomorrow cannot depend on a "production line" of embryos. There could never be enough fertilised eggs to meet the demand for new tissues to fight eye degeneration, or neuromuscular diseases, or diabetes, or osteoporosis, of skin diseases, or leukaemia or dozens of other conditions. The embryo research is a necessary stage to the making of new hope for sick people.

webTitle: Lines to repair the old divisions

fields.headline: Lines to repair the old divisions
fields.standfirst:
Shared grief for a dead mother brings hope of reconciliation to Korean brothers separated by ideology and a border
Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: The North Korean poet Oh Yong-jae knew he would not meet his mother yesterday, but that did not diminish the pain.
fields.body:
The North Korean poet Oh Yong-jae knew he would not meet his mother yesterday, but that did not diminish the pain.

The divided families chosen for the North-South exchange were at last able to meet individually after the emotional mass reunion of the previous day.

Mr Oh's two younger brothers were there to welcome him in his hotel room on the second day. They brought him watches and clothes to take back to the poverty-stricken North.

Mr Oh had brought a photo of his parents printed on a thin black slice of stone. He put it in the window and bowed deeply three times. Then with trembling hands he began to read a set of poems - Song for the Dead - dedicated to his mother.

The tale of the people's poet Oh Yong-jae in a Korea divided for 50 years, and the grief which he and his brothers feel, sums up the experience of several million Koreans - even if they cannot all express it in verse.

Mr Oh "went North" to become a volunteer soldier shortly before the Korean war in 1950. It was a time of intense partisan feelings in a country divided by the 1945 intervention of the US and the Soviet Union.

A large number of southerners who "went North" are in the group of 100 people who are now meeting their long lost families in Seoul. Many young people were fleeing the brutal purges and the repressive society of the US-backed Syngman Rhee regime in the South.

But once the Korean war began, far more Koreans "went South", many fleeing from communism, others simply displaced by the fighting. Relatives were left behind or simply lost in the chaos.

According to the South's statistics, 1m people crossed to the South during the three years' war. About 100,000 went in the other direction or were captured and stayed there.

Mr Oh stayed in the North and soon began to distinguish himself as a poet. He wrote patriotic verses, including Tower of Juche, now inscribed on the monument which celebrates Mr Kim's famous doctrine of self-reliance.

Though shattered by the war, North Korea industrialised rapidly under Kim Il-sung's fiercely nationalistic leadership, taking help from China and the Soviet Union.

South Korea began its own economic advance in the 1970s under the dictator Park Chung-hee, modelled partly on Japan - Korea's former colonial ruler.

Mr Oh's younger brother Oh Hyong-jae graduated from a South Korean military academy, then studied mathematics and computer science in the US. Before the brothers were reunited, Hyong-jae expressed some worries about the meeting. "My brother might be a complete leftist," he said. "I am an anti-communist who graduated from an army school and studied in the US. Maybe we have to be cautious." But yesterday all was forgotten as they remembered their parents.

Their mother died in 1995. Direct communication between North and South is banned, so a Southern poet sent news of her death via a third country.

Mr Oh then sat down to write his sequence of poems, starting with a bitter reflection on divided Korea, Heartlessness (see below). Pyongyang's 100 include other famous names: painters, scientists, doctors and actors.

Seoul's list has a much broader social mix, chosen mainly by computer.

Pyongyang is anxious to correct the South's image of the North as backward. The South's economic growth in the past 20 years, although now flagging, has been phenomenal.

North Korea lags desperately behind the South, suffering industrial stagnation and years of acute food shortage in the countryside.

In spite of the euphoria created by the June summit between the two leaders, the gap between the societies is vast. "We will start exchanging our feelings [about our mother]", says younger brother Hyong-jae, "and gradually, if possible, move into the subject of politics and economics."

Similarly, North and South Korea are moving ahead with the process of detente by focusing on common ground. They are tackling the problem of divided families, rebuilding communications and railways severed by the Korean war, and expanding tourism.

But as Mr Oh and the other relatives prepare to return home tomorrow in different directions, there is more optimism across Korea than at any time in the past 50 years.

Heartless by Oh Yong-jae

Are you gone

Are you really gone?

Mother, mother, I don't want to believe it!

You promised to stay alive till we met again;

You said my letters and pictures had brought happiness.

You are not the kind of mother who breaks her promises;

I am not the kind of son who won't believe in them.

But promises and trust cannot conquer time;

Our family separation lasted too long.

Our country's division is too heartless.

Division has no feelings.

webTitle: Concorde will never fly again, experts predict

fields.headline: Concorde will never fly again, experts predict
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Aviation experts were last night writing Concorde's obituary as safety officials warned that modifications to the supersonic jet could take "months not weeks" to implement.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Aviation experts were last night writing Concorde's obituary as safety officials warned that modifications to the supersonic jet could take "months not weeks" to implement.

Airline industry observers said the extensive costs of ensuring that the ageing model could fly once more might render it commercially unviable.

The civil aviation authority confirmed that it was withdrawing the plane's certificate of airworthiness because of a "freak" tyre burst that caused last month's crash of an Air France Concorde in Paris, which cost 113 lives.

British Airways responded by insisting that it would resume operations as soon as possible, had only cancelled services until early September, and could restart them with just 24 hours' notice.

But such optimism was dampened by analysts who said it would rapidly become cheaper to allow the 30-year-old plane, which brings in just £20m profit a year for BA but costs £50m to maintain, to die. And even if Concorde does fly again, there is no guarantee that it would be supersonic.

The sombre prediction of the end of Concorde's commercial flying history came as questions were asked as to why the CAA and BA had taken almost three weeks to ground the seven British planes after the Paris crash, despite knowing almost from the start that a tyre burst had occurred. Air France indefinitely grounded its five-strong fleet on July 25, the day of the disaster.

Yesterday, both BA and the CAA said they had stuck by the letter of the law, with the regulatory body emphasising that it could not suspend certificates of airworthiness with no firm information. "We have acted in a responsible, prudent way," the CAA chairman, Sir Malcolm Field, said.

But the authority admitted that 70 tyre bursts had taken place since Concorde started flying in 1976, with seven causing fuel tanks to rupture.

This awareness of the problem, but failure to act on it, was criticised by experts. "The vulnerability has been known since 1979," said Frank Taylor, director of the aviation safety centre at Cranfield University.

The CAA has only banned an aircraft from flying once before, in 1979, when public confidence in the DC-10 plunged after two serious accidents.

fields.headline: No: 1701
fields.standfirst: The Togo Olympic team
fields.trailText: The Togo Olympic team
fields.body:
Appearance? None. They've disappeared.

Who have? The Togo party.

Isn't that something Ivy League students host in their frat houses? No, I'm talking about the team representing the small West African state of Togo, which was due to arrive in Adelaide on August 4.

Adelaide on August 4? I thought the Olympics were in Sydney in September? Yes, but some African representatives were offered the use of Australian training facilities. The invitation was in return for - how shall we put this - looking favourably on Sydney's bid when casting their votes for an Olympic venue.

Ah, a touch of the old five-ringed corruption. You might say that, but Princess Anne and chums on the IOC couldn't possibly comment.

So why haven't the Togo team taken advantage of the bribe? No one's sure. Faxes, phone calls and emails have not been answered. As far as Australian officials can work out, the team left Togo some time ago, but nobody knows where they went. There is a thought they might be training in France.

France? What, something to do with World Cup votes? Don't be flippant.

Still, their absence means more medals for us, doesn't it? Not really. Neither of the team's two athletes has achieved Olympic qualification standard. They have been invited as a goodwill gesture.

Embarrassing for the Aussies to lose a whole team; after all, everything seemed to be going so smoothly. What, you mean apart from the shark fished out of the triathlon course, the deadly spiders on the rowing lake and the wholesale corruption which has seen the children of Aussie officials carrying the Olympic flame across the country. Not to mention unfinished stadia, too-short running tracks and the transport infrastructure being at a standstill.

Do say: The invitation to the Togo team was part of a programme to enlarge the Olympic family.

Don't say: The Manchester bid was always the better organised.

webTitle: A little added extra in your ice cream

fields.headline: A little added extra in your ice cream
fields.trailText: Time was when you could savour your Phish Food in the certainty that, even if you were doing your cholesterol levels no favours, at least you were eating some of the healthiest ice-cream going.
fields.body:
Time was when you could savour your Phish Food in the certainty that, even if you were doing your cholesterol levels no favours, at least you were eating some of the healthiest ice-cream going.

But suddenly aspersions are being cast: a tub of Ben & Jerry's is alleged to contain many times more dioxins than are permitted in industrial waste water pumped into San Francisco Bay.

At a conference called Dioxins 2000, in Monterey, California, two scientists revealed that a serving of Vanilla Like It Oughta Be (known in the US as World's Best Vanilla), contains 80 picograms of dioxin - a tiny amount, but one which far exceeds the 0.14 picograms of dioxin that is the upper limit imposed by the US environmental protection agency (EPA) for a litre of effluent discharged from a petrol refinery in the Bay area.

However, the aim of the report, authored by Steve Milloy and Michael Gough, is not to discredit the Vermont ice-cream maker, but to ridicule EPA limits on dioxins, a hot topic for environmentalists.

Mr Milloy, who runs a website called Junkscience.com, which takes a pro-industry, anti-green stance, said: "If dioxin is as dangerous as Ben & Jerry's and Greenpeace think, then why do they continue to sell their ice-cream? It can't be unsafe or why would you want to expose your child to 74 times the level the EPA says is safe?"

A spokeswoman for Ben & Jerry's, which is noted for its environmentally friendly policies, was unfazed by the attack. She said the company welcomed the dialogue about dioxins: "They are saying these EPA-recommended accepted levels are ridiculous. We don't happen to agree."

There are no recommended levels for dioxins in food, she added, because it would be impossible to test for them; they are in everything.

fields.headline: Besieged Putin blames weather
fields.standfirst:
Home front: Criticism grows over handling of crisis

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: After days of maintaining that no foreign assistance was required, President Vladimir Putin yesterday ordered that all offers of help be accepted, as domestic criticism mounted over his handling of the crisis.
fields.body:
After days of maintaining that no foreign assistance was required, President Vladimir Putin yesterday ordered that all offers of help be accepted, as domestic criticism mounted over his handling of the crisis.

Mr Putin talked to President Bill Clinton by phone from his holiday in Sochi on the Black sea. "President Clinton expressed concern over the situation involving the Russian submarine and renewed his offer to help," a White House spokesman said. The US navy has two deep submersible rescue vessels based in California.

Mr Putin ordered the navy chief, Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, "to accept any help wherever it comes from", a navy spokesman said. The leader's first intervention in the Arctic crisis followed his conversation with Mr Clinton. It was not clear last night whether the order meant US assistance was on its way.

The u-turn came after days of delay. After issuing the order, President Putin appeared on Russian TV in his shirtsleeves to make his first public comments defending the rescue effort.

There had been no delay in responding to the emergency, he insisted, and he had been assured by his admirals that the navy had the equipment and expertise to perform the rescue.

"From the moment it became clear that something had happened, all necessary and possible efforts to save the craft and its crew have been carried out," he said. "Unfortunately the weather is very bad. A storm has raged for two days, and sailors could not use all the means at their disposal."

The intervention came as the Moscow media turned on the president, accusing him of having badly mishandled the crisis. The influential and normally supportive Nezavisimaya Gazeta paper said his first year in power had been "generously soaked in the blood of Russians".

But there was no sign of Mr Putin cutting short his holiday to take charge of the rescue mission.

webTitle: MPs to get free vote on embryo cures

fields.headline: MPs to get free vote on embryo cures
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The government has confirmed that it will allow MPs a free vote on one of medical science's most complex issues - research into human embryos to provide new cures for disease.
fields.body:
The government has confirmed that it will allow MPs a free vote on one of medical science's most complex issues - research into human embryos to provide new cures for disease.

But the issue of "therapeutic cloning", which was recommended by a government-appointed expert committee yesterday, could become a political football anyway.

The Tory health spokesman, Liam Fox, said he would vote against it on principle. Evan Harris, the Liberal Democrats' science spokesman, criticised the government for not launching the debate months ago. The government left its chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, to introduce his long-awaited report without ministerial support, and issued its preprinted response with the report.

Human embryos up to 14 days old are already used for fertility research, under tight supervision. Reproductive cloning of humans will be banned. The Donaldson expert group proposes that scientists can use stem cells from unwanted human embryos for research into new treatments for disease.

Supporters of the research believe that it will lead to undreamed-of treatments for once incurable diseases. Dr Harris described the research as "very pro-life". The "life" of a clump of cells smaller than a pinhead deserved some respect. "But the lives of people with cancer who could be saved by the development of stem cells deserve to be given a higher value," he said.

Dr Fox argued that scientific advances had raced ahead of human ability to deal with the issues they raised.

But the issue of "therapeutic cloning", which was recommended by a government-appointed expert committee yesterday, could become a political football anyway. The Tory health spokesman, Liam Fox, said he would vote against it on principle. Evan Harris, the Liberal Democrats' science spokesman, criticised the government for not launching the debate months ago. The government left its chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, to introduce his long-awaited report without ministerial support, and issued its preprinted response with the report. Human embryos up to 14 days old are already used for fertility research, under tight supervision. Reproductive cloning of humans will be banned. The Donaldson expert group proposes that scientists can use stem cells from unwanted human embryos for research into new treatments for disease. Supporters of the research believe that it will lead to undreamed-of treatments for once incurable diseases. Dr Harris described the research as "very pro-life". The "life" of a clump of cells smaller than a pinhead deserved some respect. "But the lives of people with cancer who could be saved by the development of stem cells deserve to be given a higher value," he said. Dr Fox argued that scientific advances had raced ahead of human ability to deal with the issues they raised.

webTitle: Medical science at a new frontier

fields.headline: Medical science at a new frontier
fields.standfirst:
Government's decision to allow stem cell research sparks furore
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Government experts yesterday made the historic decision to allow cells to be taken from human embryos less than 14 days old; this could have "enormous potential" to create new kinds of treatment for now incurable diseases.
fields.body:
Government experts yesterday made the historic decision to allow cells to be taken from human embryos less than 14 days old; this could have "enormous potential" to create new kinds of treatment for now incurable diseases.

The announcement was greeted with delight by biomedical scientists, who see stem cells as a new weapon against cancer, spinal injury, diabetes and Parkinson's Disease, and biotechnology companies who are anxious to begin the long process of turning theoretical possibilities into practical treatments.

But that was countered by horror from religious and ethical groups who see the possibilities of human embryos being turned into tools to keep alive people who have already enjoyed a lifespan.

A Catholic archbishop called it "the production line approach to human lives". Liam Fox, the Conservative shadow health secretary, said there was "a genuine deep-rooted political unease about the medical techniques we can now employ". Others raised fears that the decision could open the door to reproductive cloning.

Embryo stem cell research is a new field: it is only two years since these unusual cells were first isolated in the US. Their discovery offers a future in which failed organs could be made to rebuild themselves and fractured spinal cords persuaded to grow again. But the research also raises huge ethical questions.

Embryos are already used - under strictly controlled conditions - for fertility research. After more than a year of deliberation, a committee led by Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, yesterday recommended that surplus embryos could also be used for research into new medical treatments.

The committee also gave the all-clear for limited experiments in so-called "therapeutic cloning". This would make possible the transfer of genes from one person into the nucleus of a cell taken from another.

Humans start life as one fertilised egg and end it as a collection of trillions of specialised cells of more than 200 kinds. Embryos which are a few days old, are a collection of 100 or 200 cells, any one of which could turn into any part of a human. These are embryo stem cells.

Researchers have already used adult stem cells to renew bone marrow tissue . But, the Donaldson report says, embryo stem cells could be used to repair nerve damage in stroke victims, make insulin for diabetics or treat inherited disorders.

Ideally, scientists want to learn how to "reprogramme" adult cells and use them to make new organ tissues. But research on embryo stem cells could be the only way to learn how to do this.

Dr Donaldson's expert panel of scientists, lawyers, surgeons and ethicists recommended that research on embryos either created by cell nuclear replacement - the technique that made Dolly the cloned sheep - or by in vitro fertilisation, should be permitted. But this research would be subject to control by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority. Before the HFEA licensed the use of any cloned embryos, it would have to be satisfied there was no other way to proceed.

Between 1991 and 1998, fertility researchers handled more than 48,000 embryos not needed for in vitro fertilisation, all of them less than 14 days old.

The committee said that the individuals whose eggs or sperm were used to create the embryos should give specific consent. The mixing of animal eggs and human cells would be forbidden and it would remain a criminal offence to implant an embryo created by cell nuclear replacement into the uterus of a woman.

The committee also recommended possible legislation to govern the use of embryo cells in any future treatments for disease - and suggested creating a "library" of stem cells for researchers to use.

But the committee said that any real healthcare benefits were years away. The embryo research might only be a stage on the way to a medical "holy grail" - in which scientists learned to switch on early stem cells from patients, grow them in the laboratory, and then implant them.

"It would also result in tissue that was genetically compatible. You wouldn't have the problems of rejection," Prof Donaldson said. "The technique isn't currently feasible, it is a theoretical idea that scientists believe one day may be possible. They believe that the phase of a better understanding of research into embryonic stem cells is vital to getting the breakthrough."

The report conceded that some people would argue that the research was unethical, others that the embryo required no moral attention whatsoever, and a third group that there was an ethical issue which had to be weighed against the benefits of any such research.

The decision drew fire yesterday. A spokesman for the anti-abortion group Life said: "Therapeutic cloning _ is a further trivialisation of human life. It exploits human beings at the most vulnerable stage of their lives - it is neo-cannibalism."

Destruction

Cardinal Winning, the Catholic archbishop of Glasgow, said "Obtaining stem cells from a human embryo is morally wrong, because it involves the destruction of a human life. Human life is inviolably sacred, both before and after any arbitrary 14-day deadline."

The Campaign Against Human Genetic Engineering called for the government to lobby for an enforceable international treaty against reproductive cloning. "The government must not allow us to be railroaded into crossing fundamental ethical barriers by over-enthusiastic scientists and companies," said David King, the group's co-ordinator.

But the Genetics Interest Group - an alliance of 100 groups of families affected by inherited disorders - said the research offered new hope. "The possibility of undertaking research in this area and choosing not to do it, is not ethically neutral," said Alastair Kent, the groups' director.

"Such a decision would leave families to be affected by disease or disability that might otherwise have been treated."

The case against: 'Cherish life, don't consume it'

"Spare part" cloning creates human embryos so as to harvest their cells. As the cells are extracted, the clone is killed, having served the purpose for which it was made. A human life has been created for destruction. This is morally unconscionable.

Everyone wants to see treatments developed for Parkinson's disease, and similar distressing conditions. Stem cell therapy may prove useful, although it is too early to say.

The point is that stem cell therapy need not involve cells from embryos. Using adult stem cells would not pose any ethical problem in principle, for the simple reason that the adult would survive the extraction.

There is, of course, nothing new in using embryos as laboratory material. IVF embryos are used in this way by the thousand. Clones, however, have no genetic parents in the normal sense of the term. The person providing the cell from which the nucleus is taken is neither the mother nor the father, but a twin sibling. The woman providing the ovum is the "mother" only in a very partial sense, since the ovum has been gutted of most of her genes. Parental feelings towards clone embryos do not seem to be envisaged.

There is of course a problem in getting eggs: women are understandably reluctant to donate their ova. The Donaldson report discreetly raised the possibility of using ova from female aborted foetuses. This would be a lavish source of ova from females who will not be disputing their use.

But we should not use an embryo as a mere source of cells. An embryo is an individual at the start of its life. It has interests in its welfare and survival: in the marvellous unfolding of its human powers. Human offspring are something to be cherished and protected. They are not to be consumed in research.

 Helen Watt, research fellow at the Catholic-funded Linacre Centre for Healthcare Ethics

The case for: 'This could stop Parkinson's in its tracks'

Therapeutic cloning could provide the biggest breakthrough in Parkinson's disease research for 30 years. The Parkinson's Disease Society wholly supports Liam Donaldson's finding that cloning research should go ahead, with safeguards.

If stem cell research is allowed, in 10 to15 years we may be able to provide effective treatment which could lead to a cure for Parkinson's.

There are 120,000 people with Parkinson's in the UK, and 1m are affected by the disease as carers or partners. The three key symptoms of the progressive neurological disorder are debilitating tremors in the hands, arms and legs, rigidity, and slowness of movement. These are caused by the loss of brain cells that produce the chemical dopamine.

If cloned stem cell research is allowed, scientists may be able to find a way to reprogramme stem cells to become dopamine-producing cells. These could be implanted into the brains of people with Parkinson's and halt the progress of the condition. Scientists do not understand how this process works, which is why cloned embryo research is so crucial.

Therapeutic cloning clearly raises ethical, moral and religious concerns, and we welcome a full debate before parliament determines the issue. But its potential to improve the lives of people with Parkinson's justifies embryo research, within Prof Donaldson's guidelines. At the moment 40,000 embryos are being stored for IVF treatment. Rather than throw them away, we hope that embryos up to 14 days old can be used for research.

The argument that adult stem cells can now be used fails to recognise that they offer limited potential. Work with embryonic stem cells can be seen as the first step to understanding how we reprogramme cells which, in time, may lead us to work with adult stem cells.

 Robert Meadowcroft, director of policy and research, the Parkinson's Disease Society

fields.headline: Gore goes back to basics
fields.standfirst:
Appeal to core supporters will break with Clinton agenda
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore will go back to basics when he makes the most important speech of his political career to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles tonight.
fields.body:
Al Gore will go back to basics when he makes the most important speech of his political career to the Democratic convention in Los Angeles tonight.

The party's US presidential challenger will offer tax cuts for average Americans, extra spending on education, and improved health care for the young and elderly as the centrepieces of his bid to succeed Bill Clinton in the White House.

Mr Gore's acceptance speech will be strong on specific pledges, and is being crafted as a deliberately policy-rich contrast to what he sees as the wordy and vague appeal of his Republican opponent George W Bush at the Republican convention two weeks ago.

But the speech is also emerging as a significant contrast with the Clinton agenda. Mr Gore believes that he needs to energise his party to combat Mr Bush's current opinion poll lead, and the promises in tonight's speech confirm that he is much more ready than his predecessor to offer a bread-and-butter appeal to traditional Democratic voters.

Mr Gore flew in to Los Angeles yesterday, accompanied by his wife Tipper, in time for the proud parents to watch television coverage of the debut convention speech of his daughter Karenna Schiff.

The convention was due to formally nominate Mr Gore as the Democratic challenger after the time-honoured roll-call of states and following a series of tributes which ranged from the British scientist Professor Stephen Hawking to one from Mr Gore's Harvard contemporary, the actor Tommy Lee Jones.

Mr Gore entered Los Angeles as "the standard-bearer of the party representing the new-guard generation", his spokesman Chris Lehane told reporters.

Earlier, before leaving the campaign trail in Michigan, Mr Gore underscored his efforts to mobilise core groups of supporters by chatting to teachers in Detroit.

Mr Gore also took time out to praise his former rival Bill Bradley for his barnstorming pro-Gore speech to the convention on Tuesday. "I thought he did a fabulous job. I really appreciated it," Mr Gore said.

Mr Bradley was one of a succession of party icons, mostly to the left of Mr Gore, who revved up the Democratic convention with a series of emotional and populist speeches.

The speakers included Caroline Kennedy, the only surviving member of President John Kennedy's family, giving her first address to a convention in the city where her father was nominated in 1960. Senator Edward Kennedy and the Rev Jesse Jackson also spoke.

After an awkward start dominated by the party's farewells to Mr Clinton, the Los Angeles convention has moved into gear as a vehicle for the promotion of Mr Gore and running mate Joe Lieberman, who was making his own acceptance speech last night.

Mr Lieberman was preceded at yesterday's session by a succession of Democratic heavyweights from all wings of the party, ranging from the former Treasury secretary Robert Rubin to the Democrats' congressional leader Dick Gephardt. There was music from Mary Chapin Carpenter and Stevie Wonder.

Mr Lieberman said yesterday that his speech was an opportunity "to speak to the country about who I am", but since his arrival in Los Angeles on Tuesday the Democrats' vice-presidential nominee has also moved decisively to mend fences with the party's black activists and with the entertainment industry, two key groups of Democratic supporters who have been the most wary about embracing the Connecticut senator.

On Tuesday night Mr Lieberman met privately with the Democratic black caucus and, in what was reported as a well-received speech, assured them that he was a committed supporter of affirmative action.

"I have supported affirmative action, I do support affirmative action, and I will support affirmative action," Mr Lieberman told the meeting. "Why? Because history and current reality make it necessary."

"It clears the air," the influential Los Angeles congresswoman Maxine Waters, previously a leading sceptic about the choice of Mr Lieberman, said afterwards. "I feel comfortable in campaigning for him."

Mr Lieberman also made a priority of attending a Beverly Hills reception hosted by the film producer David Salzman.

The visit was part of an effort to calm Hollywood fears that Mr Lieberman would continue his high-profile anti-obscenity campaign against the entertainment industry if elected.

webTitle: Getting plane airborne again may prove too intricate and costly

fields.headline: Getting plane airborne again may prove too intricate and costly
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Devising modifications to ensure that Concorde can take to the skies once more will be such a lengthy and intricate process that it could prove too expensive, aviation specialists and financial analysts said yesterday.
fields.body:
Devising modifications to ensure that Concorde can take to the skies once more will be such a lengthy and intricate process that it could prove too expensive, aviation specialists and financial analysts said yesterday.

Changes are expected to be made to the tyres, the material covering the wings, and possibly the hydraulic and electric systems.

But improvements to the engine intakes - where air enters before causing fuel in the engine to ignite - could prove so complex that British Airways and Air France may decide it is no longer commercially viable to pursue them, while any change to the plane's weight could render it incapable of completing a transatlantic flight.

The first issue that Concorde's manufacturers, BAE Systems, Airbus UK and Aerospatiale in France, will have to address is how to strengthen the tyres to prevent another blowout, the fault finally identified yesterday as the "primary cause of the accident".

But "however strong you make them, no tyre is guaranteed not to burst, especially if there are hot pieces of metal around," said David Learmont of Flight International magazine. And if stronger tyres burst "the bits that fly off them will fly away with greater energy, because they're heavier".

A more viable option would be to strengthen the metal around the part of the wing incorporating the fuel tank.

Frank Taylor, director of the Aviation Safety Centre at Cranfield University, said: "At present an aluminium alloy is used, but there are thousands of these, and since Concorde was developed there may well be one less liable to have a hole punched in it."

There is the further problem of how to prevent debris from getting into the engines, as happened - the air accident investigations branch admitted yesterday - in the Paris disaster.

"It's fair to say there's more chance of tyre debris going into Concorde's engines than those of other aircraft," said Frank Taylor, "but there's no way the position of the engine can be altered."

Ultimately BA and Air France are likely to be driven by two issues in deciding how far they should go to get Concorde airborne: the public's perception of its safety and money.

For an ageing plane that costs £50m a year to maintain yet returns estimated profits of only £7m for Air France and £20m-£40m for BA, there may be little point in making changes.

fields.headline: Spread of swine fever feared
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Three suspected further outbreaks of swine fever have raised the possibility of a devastating spread of the disease outside East Anglia.
fields.byline: Paul Brown  and  Andrew Osborne  in Brussels
fields.body:
Three suspected further outbreaks of swine fever have raised the possibility of a devastating spread of the disease outside East Anglia.

Three farmers, in Cheshire, Derbyshire and Lincolnshire, two of whom had taken piglets from British Quality Pigs, the Norfolk farm that was the source of the swine fever outbreak, contacted the Ministry of Agriculture after animals on their farms became ill.

Tests were ordered immediately but last night there were still no results.

Both the United States and Canada yesterday banned the import of pigs and meat yesterday in response to the confirmed outbreak on five farms, though the trade across the Atlantic is small compared with Europe. Exports of pigs and products total £126m, of which £22m comes from outside the European Union.

Officials of the ministry and the Department of Trade and Industry were in Brussels yesterday, meeting representatives of the European commission and agriculturalists from Germany and the Netherlands who have recent experience of tackling classic swine fever.

In 1997, an outbreak hit the relatively large Dutch pig population. More than 400 farms were affected and millions of pigs slaughtered in an epidemic that took more than a year to bring under control.

Germany suffered several cases in 1997 and 1998. Hundreds of thousands of pigs were slaughtered and export restrictions were applied to some lande (states). The virus in East Anglia looks likely to be the same as that which devastated the German industry. The source was never established but was believed to be a wild boar or an import from eastern Europe.

Commission sources indicated yesterday that it had been likely that the Europe-wide ban on English pig exports would be reduced to only East Anglia next week, provided no new cases had been confirmed. But one source said: "If it is confirmed that swine fever has spread to other parts of the country, they will probably vote to prolong the ban beyond August 31 or extend it to the rest of the UK."

An EC spokeswoman admitted that there was a chance that the herd of pigs where the disease was first discovered might have passed swine fever on to some 48 herds all over England owned by the same company.

Blood tests on the 48 herds are expected to resolve the matter within a few days. "Tests are still going on and so far we stay with five confirmed cases," said spokeswoman Andrea Dahman.

webTitle: Middle East peace talks move on

fields.headline: Middle East peace talks move on
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's new foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, held his first talks with Palestinian officials yesterday amid signals that both sides are reaching towards a peace deal.
fields.body:
Israel's new foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, held his first talks with Palestinian officials yesterday amid signals that both sides are reaching towards a peace deal.

The talks were at the highest level held since the Camp David summit broke down without an agreement three weeks ago, and will intensify speculation that a second encounter could be held next month to clinch a final settlement.

Despite the summit's failure, Israel and the Palestinians insist that progress was made at Camp David.

In the weeks since then, Yasser Arafat and Israeli envoys have circumnavigated the globe, seeking international support for their respective positions, but they have also telegraphed to say that they are ready for a resumption of talks.

The US envoy, Dennis Ross, arrives in the region today to ensure both sides agree on where progress at Camp David was made - none of the offers were put in writing - and to coax Israel and the Palestinians on.

But convening a second summit would first require reconciliation over Haram al-Sharif - or as the Israelis call it, Temple Mount - which both sides are resolved to control. The site is holy to Judaism and Islam.

Israeli officials have drafted new proposals for the Temple Mount, which were presented to Palestinian officials visiting Egypt on Tuesday.

In return, during a visit to Jakarta, Mr Arafat suggested for the second time that he would be flexible on the September 13 deadline for declaring a Palestinian state.

fields.headline: PPL teams up with Bayer
fields.trailText: PPL Therapeutics, Britain's leading animal cloning company, has taken a big step towards establishing itself as a commercial drugs company by signing up Bayer, the German pharmaceuticals group, as a partner for its lead product.
fields.body:
PPL Therapeutics, Britain's leading animal cloning company, has taken a big step towards establishing itself as a commercial drugs company by signing up Bayer, the German pharmaceuticals group, as a partner for its lead product.

Bayer has agreed a deal worth up to $40m (£27m), under which it will take on the development and marketing of AAT, a protein which PPL produces in the milk of genetically altered sheep. AAT helps keep the lungs healthy - a deficiency of the substance can cause fatal emphysema.

The agreement is a significant endorsement of PPL's controversial technology of producing human proteins and organs in animals. It is also a crucial financial lifeline for the company, which announced a £5.9m first-half loss and is rapidly running out of cash.

Chief executive Ron James said: "This puts PPL in a position where there's a very clear path to getting our products on the market."

The development of AAT goes back to 1991, when PPL produced the world's first transgenic sheep, called Tracy. Scientists added an extra gene to the egg which produced Tracy, so that she made AAT in her milk.

Tracy has since died, although her body is preserved in the Science Museum.

PPL has been carrying out clinical trials of AAT ever since, although the company has attracted more attention for its work on cloning - a more advanced technique of copying animal cells.

PPL produced the first cloned sheep, Dolly, in 1996, followed by a litter of cloned piglets earlier this year.

Under the terms of yesterday's agreement, Bayer will pay an immediate $15m for a 9% stake in PPL. The Leverkusen-based group will fund phase three clinical trials, involving hundreds of patients, later this year and make milestone payments of up to $25m depending on the product's success.

The two companies hope to launch AAT by 2004, initially targeted at the estimated 200,000 people worldwide who have a genetic deficiency of the substance in their lungs, although this is rarely diagnosed.

Further ahead, the two firms will sell AAT for the treatment of cystic fibrosis.

Bayer already makes a version of AAT distilled from human blood donations, but there is a chronic shortage of supply - the company says it only has enough to treat 5,000 patients.

Bayer said that yesterday's deal "unlocks the possibility of producing unlimited quantities".

PPL has nearly 1,000 transgenic sheep, most of which are kept on a high-security farm in New Zealand.

The company said that it intends to expand its flock to around 2,000.

PPL is building a factory in Scotland to extract AAT from the milk of its sheep.

Analysts said AAT sales could peak at £100m annually. PPL is likely to get about 20% of the proceeds. The shares closed 7.5p higher at 164p.

Earlier this week, PPL's shares slumped amid concerns about health risks in xenotransplantation, under which the company alters pigs so they grow hearts, lungs and livers suitable for human transplant.

Mr James insisted yesterday that he was unaware of any new health risks, adding that PPL was in talks with commercial partners and venture capital groups interested in investing in the technology.

Sheepish admission on modified wool

The woolly sweaters frequently favoured by environmental activists could contain material from PPL Therapeutics' genetically-modified sheep, it emerged yesterday.

PPL's chief executive, Ron James, said the company makes £5,000 a year by selling wool from its flock to the Wool Board, which distributes it to textiles companies throughout the country.

Concern
The sideline is a useful earner for the company, which alters sheep so that they produce therapeutic proteins in their milk. The animals' carcasses are destroyed and PPL does not allow their meat to be eaten.

Mr James insisted that genetically-modified wool offered no cause for alarm. "We don't want people thinking their clothes are going to glow in the dark or anything," he said.

Greenpeace expressed concern, nonetheless. A spokesman for the environmental group said: "There are lots of moral issues involved here.

"We think that people should know if products are genetically modified, so that they can make decisions themselves about what to buy."
