The shortage of skilled computer programmers and web designers has prompted a new internet jobs site to resort to bribery. Grandinyourhand.com is offering individuals £1,000 if they refer someone who is appointed to one of its permanent or contract job vacancies.

 Local call Mobile telephone operator Virgin Mobile said that it would be the first large customer of Britain's first fully fledged mobile phone maker Sendo . The company that started operations last year, will make both a low-price "fun phone" and a medium-range handset that have been modelled to Virgin's requirements.

webTitle: What should you do if a man is about to rape you?

fields.headline: What should you do if a man is about to rape you?
fields.standfirst: This month's Cosmopolitan tells women to fight back, which sounds perfectly reasonable advice ... until you find yourself facing a rapist.  Sue Lees reports
fields.trailText: This month's Cosmopolitan tells women to fight back, which sounds perfectly reasonable advice ... until you find yourself facing a rapist.  Sue Lees reports.
fields.body:
Resisting rape, according to an article in this month's Cosmopolitan, is worthwhile and does not lead to further injury. The article cites a US study of 1.5m rape convictions over a decade which found that women who fought back tripled their chances of escape. How on earth this was calculated is not disclosed. One wonders whether resisting also trebled the chances of being killed. An analysis of the homicide statistics might be helpful here.

Crime prevention is all the rage at present and Scott Lindquist, author of The Date Rape Prevention Book (Sourcebooks, £10.99), prescribes the perfect no-cost strategy: women should defend themselves. He tells women to "outsmart" their attacker, to "take a risk and fight him off", to "trust your instincts - if one tactic isn't working, try another".

"Make the most of the first precious minutes," he advises. "At this time the rapist isn't in total control, so your chances are highest." The problem is that you won't be in control, either: studies of both men and women who are attacked show they are often "frozen" in the first few minutes and cannot then resist.

Other advice is equally simplistic. Call the police and a trusted friend who can be with you immediately. However distressed you are, don't have a bath. Call Rape Crisis. Such advice is all very well, but not very helpful. Calling Rape Crisis is unlikely to get a response when few services are funded sufficiently to be on call more than a few hours a day and many women do not feel up to speaking about the assault to anyone, let alone the police.

Generalising about resistance is also dangerous and distorting. It can be successful but it can also be life-threatening. In the 100 cases I studied for my book, Carnal Knowledge, I discovered that where women failed to escape, resistance often led to an escalation of violence, so could sometimes be a risky strategy. In such circumstances, surviving is more important than avoiding rape.

Such prescriptions also reinforce a common myth: that most rapes are by strangers. All the case studies quoted in Cosmopolitan involved such attacks - including a victim of the serial rapist Clive Barwell, who is said to have fought so hard that he ran off. Yet according to the most recent Home Office report, published last year, only 12% of reported rapes are by strangers; the other 88% are by acquaintances or partners which can make avoiding rape even more problematic. Contrary to popular belief, women attacked by partners or ex-partners suffer no less serious injuries and are more likely to be killed than women attacked by strangers. One woman I interviewed described how she had to have hospital treatment for concussion, a fractured cheekbone, black eyes and bruising. Another had passed out while being strangled by her ex-husband.

Some men who raped acquaintances did not need to use violence because the threat was sufficient. "He got a kettle of boiling water and threatened to throw it over me if I didn't get undressed"; "He threatened to wake my children and rape me in front of them."

Most women, when attacked by strangers, do resist when they can. In my survey, I found women did this in all sorts of ways: by screaming, fighting and biting, running away, refusing to cooperate, pretending they were pregnant or had Aids and by attempting to reason.

At times resisting worked, at times it didn't. Much depended on where the assault took place. Most rapes are planned and rapists are careful to isolate their victim first. Resisting may be effective where there is an escape route but in an underground car park or deserted spot, or where faced with an assailant much stronger than oneself, it may not be practicable or sensible.

Rita described the effect her resistance had after she was dragged by a stranger from a bus stop. "I remember thinking what people say you should do if you are attacked. 'I'd punch and kick him in the balls.' So I punched him there and he grabbed my head and slammed it into the wall and called me a fucking bitch. I started to cry ... he said if I didn't climb over the gate before he counted to 10 he would kill me, then he started counting ... He put his penis in my mouth and said that if I bit it, I was dead."

Advising women to resist also implies that women need to be told what to do. It holds them responsible. Women are often blamed and blame themselves for rape. If a woman physically resists and is severely hurt, she is told she should have acted more passively. If she does not resist, she is seen as accepting the violence. It is a no-win situation.

It is surely time men stopped writing books about how women can resist rape and concentrated on how to stop rape. With a conviction rate in England and Wales at an all-time low (a mere 6% of reported rapes now result in conviction), and with women still subjected to demeaning and humiliating cross-examination in court, a first step would be to reform the court process.

Sue Lees is the author of Carnal Knowledge: Rape on Trial (Penguin).

fields.headline: Reunited (and it feels so good)
fields.standfirst: New research says old love revisited is the real thing.  Susannah Conway considers first love the second time around
fields.trailText: New research says old love revisited is the real thing.  Susannah Conway considers first love the second time around.
fields.body:
In most relationships, the end comes when you fall out of love. But what if you are forced apart, a partner moves away, or your parents split you up because they think you are unsuited or, worse, too young? That passionate unripe love can stay with a person for a long time, colouring the way they see future partners. Can anyone ever live up to a first love?

What if, like Camilla and Charles, you find that lost love again, years later? Will the man who was once the boy of your dreams turn out truly to have been your partner for life? It may sound like a Mills & Boon storyline but according to Professor Nancy Kalish at the California State University, first love the second time around is often the one to defy the rising divorce statistics.

Kalish's research says old flames who meet again have a better chance of a happy marriage. In her survey of 1,000 people, 11% said they had been too young for marriage; none said the romance had ended through falling out of love and all were happily back together, many resentful of past parental interference.

Sarah and Ed White met in the sixth form and were together for two years, until they accepted university places at opposite ends of the country. After five years without contact, they bumped into each other at Hammersmith station and found they lived a few minutes from each other. "We'd been so in love before that meeting again felt natural," Sarah says. Two years later they were married.

First loves, when experienced in adolescence, do not get the chance to go sour as a more mature relationship might. When they end, it often takes a final blow to severe the ties, infidelity being the biggest killer. But a rekindled love won't recall the irritating way he cleans his teeth or how she leaves nail clippings in the sink. Essentially the other person is the same but their experiences have rounded off the jagged edges to create a partner who fits you perfectly today.

But do many of us carry a torch for our first loves? And if we met them tomorrow, would it really be all hearts and flowers - or would it be as it was for Ally McBeal, reunited with her first love at work, only to meet his wife a moment later? The jury may still be out on Charles and Camilla's amour, but its rekindling after years on the backburner proves something that seemed impossible all those years ago can be successfully revamped into something new.

Reunited first loves hark back to lost childhoods as the lovers relive that first rush of adolescent excitement - the sexually inept, spotty teenager, one would hope, having been replaced by a confident lover. But as you yearn for the salad days of your youth, beware: reminiscing about a former love can threaten a current relationship. Kalish warns married couples against attempting to contact their first loves, lest they be tempted to break up families.

Yet, in our increasingly hectic lives, we're all searching for that special someone. A recent report found nearly two million Britons are on the books of dating agencies, while some psychologists believe people are becoming more promiscuous in their workplaces as they have less time to socialise outside the office. We are all hunting for sex, for love. Perhaps it is only the lucky few who recover lost loves and find they really were meant for each other as they had once so passionately believed.

Pam Johnson, now in her 80s, married her first love, Eric, during the war, only to divorce him seven years later following an adulterous affair. "He'd hurt me so much, I was adamant that I wouldn't see him again. But three years later, on Valentine's Day, he saw me on a bus and asked me to a dance. That evening, he proposed to me again." The couple remarried; Eric died three days before their golden wedding anniversary.

Samuel Beckett ends his novella, First Love, with these words: "I could have done with other loves perhaps. But there it is, either you love or you don't." It is what we are all searching for, but maybe some of us found it when we were too young to know we were looking for it.

Pam Johnson, now in her 80s, married her first love, Eric, during the war, only to divorce him seven years later following an adulterous affair. "He'd hurt me so much, I was adamant that I wouldn't see him again. But three years later, on Valentine's Day, he saw me on a bus and asked me to a dance. That evening, he proposed to me again." The couple remarried; Eric died three days before their golden wedding anniversary. Samuel Beckett ends his novella, First Love, with these words: "I could have done with other loves perhaps. But there it is, either you love or you don't." It is what we are all searching for, but maybe some of us found it when we were too young to know we were looking for it.

fields.headline: Sex and sin
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: James Joyce, a Catholic priest, says his church is still failing its abused children
fields.body:
I am surprised by the attempts by spokesmen for the Roman Catholic church to defend the church's actions against priest paedophiles (Abuse: how the churches are responding, Letters, August 14).

As child protection officer for the Catholic diocese of Portsmouth for five years, I met victims of abuse and their families - and my experience is different.

Most were in shock, stunned not only by what had happened and its effect on them, but also by the silence and denial by the church. Many victims of abuse had their lives destroyed. They found relationships with their families and friends distorted, their sexuality confused and their whole being affected. They couldn't understand why it had happened to them.

As I listened to their stories, I experienced a sense of shock and a turning upside-down of my own view of the church. Like the victims, I couldn't understand why priest paedophiles were moved around and why victims' complaints were ignored or played down.

It is not easy for victims to speak about the abuse perpetrated on them to their families and friends, let alone to priests and bishops who sometimes find it difficult to talk about sexual matters. As a church too, we are not comfortable with complaints, and it is not easy for vulnerable people to approach figures of power and authority.

The climate in the church is changing, even if slowly. Of course, we did not always know what we know now. But we have known for years the effect of abuse on victims. My own experience is recent - and it shows that the church, although better than in the past, still does not always act properly.

We are told that there are good procedures in every diocese. There are, but they are not always implemented and there is no one who monitors whether they are.

I know of one archbishop who appointed a child protection team and forbade the three priests appointed to tell anyone about their appointment. Isn't that encouraging an atmosphere of cover-up and a hope that the issue will go away if we pretend it isn't there?

Then there was the priest headteacher of a private school who told me that the boy victims of abuse "soon get over it". Isn't this a culpable level of ignorance? Was in-service training about sexual abuse compulsory? If not, isn't this a denial of the significance of sexual abuse?

In similar vein, a bishop to whom I passed on a complaint concerning a priest's fascination with boy altar servers replied: "This priest is not like that. He is heterosexual." Isn't this to misunderstand the complexity of paedophilia? Is such a misunderstanding acceptable today in a church leader?

In another case, a self-confessed paedophile was retired but with no restrictions placed on his pastoral work. Within a a few weeks he was found to be working with young people. Is the thinking here that paedophiles can be trusted? I also know of one case in which the vicar-general was sent to warn a priest about his behaviour after a complaint had been made - and the complaint was not referred to the child protection team. Yet again, a cover-up.

More generally, the church consistently refused to accept psychiatric evidence of paedophile tendencies on the grounds that "we know better". There is also widespread suspicion that the amount spent on those receiving treatment for paedophilia is greater that that spent on victims. No diocese has even gone public on this.

Why aren't the procedures always applied? Most child protection officers are priests or deacons who at their ordination have made a promise of obedience to their bishop. It is psychologically and spiritually difficult for them to argue with a bishop or to try to convince a bishop to act. In the case of a priest, the bishop decides where he lives, what work he does and therefore what salary he has. Can't the church see that it is asking too much to expect a priest to take on his bishop? I couldn't do it, which is why I resigned from child protection work.

The climate in the church is still one of denying abuse and minimising its effect, because to accept it is to open up issues about power. Parishes and dioceses can still be run on the whim of a priest or a bishop, and there is no appeal or grievance procedure in the law of the church.

Victims and those who work with them and on their behalf are all too often seen as troublemakers and angry people. They can easily be marginalised.

More generally, the church's teaching on many sexual issues - birth control, homosexuality and so on - is in turmoil, and paedophilia touches on some of the most troubling aspects of sexuality. It can be scary to open this up. It is certainly easier to pretend that there is nothing wrong.

More generally still, the priesthood in the western world is in crisis, with a dwindling number of vocations and a consequent battening down of the hatches and an unwillingness to look at the reality of priesthood. The question of compulsory celibacy is not being addressed, with all that goes with it, such as the infantilising of sexuality, emotions and needs. This is a vast area and, although some of the church's spokesmen deny it vehemently, it is linked to sexual abuse.

I think all this helps explain why the procedures are not always implemented. The way forward is to set up an independent body of experts, not subject to the bishops' authority, which would investigate all allegations about sexual abuse in the church and would have the power to suspend and remove priests. Victims would be able to approach this body confident of its expertise, knowing there would be no denial and covering-up and that appropriate action would be taken.

The alternative is to trust the system, and surely there are few who do that?

 Monsignor James Joyce was child protection officer for the Catholic diocese of Portsmouth from 1994-99. He is currently parish priest at St James in Reading.

Of course, knowing men, they'll leave me to do all the (expletive deleted) work"

Yasmin Alibhai-Brown sympathises with some of Norman Mailer's recent complaints about women's liberation, Independent

webTitle: Hospital doctors reject ban on private work

fields.headline: Hospital doctors reject ban on private work
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Hospital doctors set themselves on a collision course with the government yesterday when they rejected plans to ban them from working in the private sector for seven years after they finish their training.
fields.body:
Hospital doctors set themselves on a collision course with the government yesterday when they rejected plans to ban them from working in the private sector for seven years after they finish their training.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the British Medical Association's consultants committee, said his colleagues regarded the proposal as "irrelevant and insulting", while two organisations representing trainee surgeons warned of a brain drain if ministers did not abandon the idea.

The proposal to make consultants repay the NHS for the high cost of their training by forbidding them from private work for seven years came out of the blue as part of the government's national plan for the NHS. It was one of the few radical ideas, and was applauded by those who feel the NHS is not getting value for money from a small minority of consultants who spend most of their time in the lucrative private hospitals and consulting rooms.

But consultants and junior doctors now in training to become consultants are furious, not least because the proposal has not been raised by ministers during the negotiations on a new NHS contract for consultants that have been going on for about a year.

"In the two weeks since the NHS plan was published we have had hundreds of angry telephone calls and emails from trainee surgeons," said David O'Regan, co-president of the Association of Surgeons in Training, which issued a joint statement with the British Orthopaedic Trainees Association.

"They find the government's attitude towards their professional commitment completely insulting," the statement said. "They are actively discussing an alternative way of pursuing their careers, either by moving abroad or by setting up in consortia outside the NHS."

The two organisations represent most of the 4,000 registrars in training to become consultant surgeons.

They argue that by the time they have qualified they have spent 10 years working for the NHS, including many thousands of hours at night and weekends.

"They regard the idea that they must 'repay the state' by holding an exclusive contract with the NHS as insulting and contemptible," said the statement.

With a swipe at the NHS, Mr O'Regan added: "Many consultants feel that they can only practise to the very best of their ability in the private sector where they are not hampered by bureaucracy and poor funding.

"As consultants of the future we look forward to a working day that is not punctuated with apologies, excuses, delays, poor management and poor equipment. We are committed to providing an excellent surgical service and we expect the NHS to treat us fairly by providing a working environment that is clean, efficient, modern and dependable, with the time, facilities and money to enable us to use our skills appropriately."

Dr Hawker of the BMA said the government seemed to have forgotten its commitment to joined-up thinking on public policy. "It wants the private sector to work in harness with the NHS to reduce waiting lists. NHS trusts are themselves major providers of private care, and yet it seeks to tie new consultants to an exclusive contract with the NHS.

"Consultants regard this proposal as irrelevant and insulting. They work extremely long hours for the NHS and there is no evidence that the new generation of consultants currently in training will behave differently."

The BMA is seeking a meeting with ministers on the issue which could be explosive and could wreck the negotiations that have taken place over changes to consultants' contracts.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
PC jailed for theft of gun
A policeman who gave away a pistol handed in during a guns amnesty in March 1997 was jailed for six months at Sheffield crown court yesterday.
fields.body:
PC jailed for theft of gun
A policeman who gave away a pistol handed in during a guns amnesty in March 1997 was jailed for six months at Sheffield crown court yesterday. Desmond Pearson, 53, of Rossington, Doncaster, a firearms licensing officer in South Yorkshire, had been found guilty at an earlier trial of theft. He was also convicted of stealing two other guns and cash, and false accounting. The court heard Pearson stole money taken from people renewing firearms certificates.

Cat killer's sentence cut
A man who was jailed for beating to death his girlfriend's cat with a candlestick before taking it to a country lane and running it over has had his sentence halved at Bristol crown court. Philip Giles, 53, of Clifton, Bristol, who also smashed items at his girlfriend's flat in Bath after a row, was sentenced to four months jail for animal cruelty, criminal damage and theft at Bath magistrates court earlier this year.

Detective quits over punch
A detective constable has been forced to quit after a punching a driver during a scuffle in Brixton, south London, six years ago, the police complaints authority said yesterday. Darren Harber, 34, continued serving with the Metropolitan police until a disciplinary hearing found him guilty of abuse of authority last month.

St John's Wort research hope
Britain's 2m users of the herbal antidepressant St John's Wort, could be offered a side-effect free version. Doctors believe it diminishes the effectiveness of a range of drugs, including birth control pills and antibiotics. Now scientists are looking at how to eliminate the problems in a study of the complementary medicine, said to be gaining users at a rate of 2000% a year.

Taggart gains Asian fans
A fan club has been formed in honour of Scottish detective series Taggart - in the former Soviet state of Kazakhstan. The 30 members watch the series on a Russian cable TV channel.

webTitle: Tsar's flagship pays homage to Harwich

fields.headline: Tsar's flagship pays homage to Harwich
fields.standfirst: New replica of great vessel restores Russian pride
fields.trailText: If Vladimir Martous and his Russian crew had been able to afford charts and a radio for weather forecasts, their tiny replica ship would not have beached ignominiously at Harwich in a force 11 gale eight years ago.
fields.body:
If Vladimir Martous and his Russian crew had been able to afford charts and a radio for weather forecasts, their tiny replica ship would not have beached ignominiously at Harwich in a force 11 gale eight years ago.

But if that had not happened he could never have managed to return to the Essex seaport in such resplendent style yesterday.

Captain Martous came back in a re-creation of one of the great vessels of maritime history, a new, precisely-built copy of the Shtandart, flagship of the Russian emperor Peter the Great, a vessel 100ft long with a 100ft high main mast made from a single St Petersburg pine tree.

It dominated Harwich harbour with an elegant and savage beauty, drawing tourists in swarms. The £1m replica's mission is to help to "bring Russia back among the great countries of the world".

Tsar Peter designed his original in 1703, using British naval architecture as his model.

Anyone walking into the captain's cabin, with its angled honeycomb of windows, at once steps back into the 18th century world of Captain Hornblower and Captain Bligh.

But the figurehead on the prow is a raging sabre-toothed lion, a reminder of the emperor who used to whip chief ministers who displeased him in his impatience to make Russia a force in the world.

There is, however, one key sentimental difference on the new Shtandart. On its port forecastle, carved in limewood in the style of a Russian cathedral ikon, is the grey-bearded face of a modern Harwich historian and sailor, the late Greg Palmer. This is Capt Martous's homage to the Englishman who befriended him in near disaster and became the Shtandart project's unlikely father.

Today Mr Palmer's widow, Ann, will sail to Rotterdam as an officer and the only non-Russian among the crew of 29 men and nine women. Yesterday she said Harwich was captivated by the force of personality of the young Russians who went aground in 1992.

"The town took them into their hearts", she said. "Mrs Good in the fishmongers kept sending them boxes of fish. Fishermen gave them ropes."

The most captivated was Greg Palmer. "At that stage he needed something in his life and he found it," Mrs Palmer said. "This became his life for the next few years. He was prouder of the Shtandart project than of anything except his son."

Capt Martous, a marine architect who was sad because St Petersburg - a city of 4m people - had not one tall ship left, built the 1992 replica as his first project.

When the repaired vessel left, Mr Palmer sailed with it to St Petersburg, fell in love with the way of life and learned to speak the language.

"The Shtandart could not have begun without his deep knowledge and remarkable advice," Capt Martous said. "I was then 26 and could not think so deeply."

In 1997 Greg Palmer died of a stroke. Prayers were said for him in Russian churches. He was buried in a coffin of the same St Petersburg oak used for the Shtandart's frame.

By then the scheme had won Prince Andrew as sponsor and funds from sponsors including the Dutch national lottery and the Livanos shipowning family in Greece.

Last September 40,000 people watched as a crane lifted and launched the replica on the river Neva.

It came to Harwich on its maiden voyage as a thank-you to the town and to honour its bond with the Palmers. It will be used for research on the sailing characteristics of historic vessels and as a goodwill ship.

But its main role will be as a sail training ship on which young Russians can work alongside contemporaries from other nations.

Ann Palmer said: "Its prime purpose is to give young Russians a chance of their own future - and a belief that they can take their future in their own hands.

"It's no longer all bad news from Russia."

fields.headline: Fuad Sirageddin Pasha
fields.standfirst: Symbol of Egypt's old order, he survived the Nasser years and returned to politics as opposition leader
fields.trailText: Fuad Sirageddin, who has died aged 89, epitomised the landed aristocracy of the old order of Egypt that was swept away by the young army officers revolt of July 1952. The last surviving pasha - the highest title after the monarch - he was overweight, cigar and water-pipe smoking and had little or no patience with commoners.
fields.body:
Fuad Sirageddin, who has died aged 89, epitomised the landed aristocracy of the old order of Egypt that was swept away by the young army officers revolt of July 1952. The last surviving pasha - the highest title after the monarch - he was overweight, cigar and water-pipe smoking and had little or no patience with commoners.

He remained in politics all his life, but his world was shattered when those officers, of poor or fellahin background, dissolved political parties, deposed the king, abolished all titles - including pasha - confiscated the land, nationalised industries and, in turning Egyptian politics and society upside down, sent reverberations throughout the region.

When the coup took place, Sirageddin was deputy leader of the then 30-year-old Wafd party, which had so dominated the scene that in the 1950 elections it fielded 296 candidates and won 226 seats. Some of its objectives were quite progressive. It insisted on national unity between Muslims and Copts, with the slogan "Religion is for God, the homeland is for all."

It advocated equal pay for equal work for men and women, full franchise for women and independence of the judiciary. The king was "to reign; but not rule", while his power was to derive from parliament not religious authority. Despite confrontation and friction with Britain as the occupying colonial power and over its policies in Palestine and Sudan, the Wafd party supported the allies during the second world war.

Sirageddin was born into a land-owning family from Kafr Aggraidah, near Cairo. He graduated in law from Fuad University in 1930. His first job was in the attorney general's office, in 1932.

Four years later he joined the Wafd party and in 1942 was appointed minister of agriculture and minister of social affairs, initiating a landmark law for anti-illiteracy in Egypt; in 1946 he was minister of communications. By 1950 he was holder of the finance and interior portfolios: and was clearly earmarked for the leadership of the party.

In 1952 he won national acclaim when, as minister of the interior, he supported the Egyptian position in the clash between Egyptian police and a British battalion over a dispute about British access to police premises in Ismailia, the headquarters for the British Suez Canal forces. The occasion is still commemorated as National Police Day in Egypt.

Fuad Sirageddin opposed Nasser's policies. He was arrested on charges of opposing the policies of the revolution, tried and sentenced to 15 years in prison (but spent only three years in jail). When Nasser died in 1970 and President Anwar Sadat restored a restricted degree of democratisation in 1978, Sirageddin re-emerged and founded the New Wafd party, which quickly became the main opposition party, somewhat more rightwing than the old grouping and gaining support mainly from the middle classes. He supported Sadat's economic liberalisation policy and rapprochement with the west.

He remained a robust leader of the party until his death - but did not stand for parliament. The new party was moderately successful, but now has only five MPs in parliament, although it would probably gain more if free and fair elections were to be held.

Fuad Sirageddin was a very determined and resourceful leader. After the confiscation of his property he turned his aristocratic hobbies into jobs, offering his services as a consultant in jewellery, interior design and antiques to many (including the nouveau rich of the one-party order).

He is survived by his two daughters; one grandson is already competing for the leadership of the New Wafd party.

 Fuad Sirageddin Pasha, politician, born November 2 1910; died August 9 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Neo-Nazis honour Hess
fields.body:
Neo-Nazis honour Hess

Hundreds of posters honouring Adolf Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Hess, appeared overnight yesterday in east Germany on the eve of the 13th anniversary of his death.

Police in Rostock said the campaign was probably the work of neo-Nazis who claim that Hess, found hanged in prison in Berlin, did not commit suicide but was killed by his British captors.
Berlin, Reuters

Kenya train crash kills 10

A train derailment in western Kenya killed at least 10 people, injured 38 others and left many trapped, police said yesterday.

The train, which was travelling between Butere and Kisumu, derailed near the town of Lela on Tuesday evening.
Reuters, Nairobi

Rebels among Kashmir dead

Eight people, including four separatist rebels, have been killed and 18 injured in gunbattles and a grenade attack in Indian Kashmir, police said yesterday.
Reuters, Srinagar

fields.headline: Kennedys deliver family values
fields.standfirst:
Dynastic liberals plead for gun control and health care

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Democrats have been trying hard recently to represent themselves as the party of family values, so what better way to illustrate the point than to have two members of the same family issue the rallying call for action?
fields.body:
The Democrats have been trying hard recently to represent themselves as the party of family values, so what better way to illustrate the point than to have two members of the same family issue the rallying call for action?

Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, the daughter of the man who was nominated in the same city 40 years ago, and Ted Kennedy, the late president's brother and now the patriarch of America's best-known political family, both won standing ovations.

Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, making a rare political appearance, used the occasion to paint some of the ways in which the Democrats can distinguish themselves from what the Republicans are offering the country, most specifically on gun control.

"I thank all Americans for making me and John and all of our family a part of your families, for reaching out and sustaining us through the good times and the difficult ones and for helping us to dream our father's dreams," she told the delegates.

She said that, as she and her brother were growing up, hardly a day had gone by without someone telling them how their father had drawn them into public service. Among their number, she said, was Joseph Lieberman, the Democrats' vice-presidential candidate. "Now it is our turn to prove that the New Frontier was not a place in time but a timeless call," she said.

She also became one of the few main speakers to raise the delicate issue of gun control, which is seen, along with abortion and health care, as one of the key grounds of difference between the two parties.

"If we believe that we have seen enough gun violence in our land and in our lifetimes, that guns should no longer take the lives of those we love" - said the woman whose father was assassinated in 1963 and whose uncle Robert was shot dead in 1968 not far from the spot where she was speaking after he had won the party's primary - "then it is up to us. It is up to us to elect Al Gore and Joe Lieberman."

Introduced by his niece with an affectionate tribute and a hug, Ted Kennedy went through his paces like someone who has been best man at enough weddings to make the necessary speech without stretching himself too far.

The days when he dreamed that he might have been the person saying Al Gore's lines may be long gone but the old political instincts clearly remain intact.

He chose to highlight the "life and death issue" of health care, promoting Mr Gore as "the only candidate committed to moving this country forward step by step, starting with covering every child by the year 2004".

Earlier the Rev Jesse Jackson became one of the few platform speakers to look immediately outward when he told delegates that they should embrace the protesters who have been camped, as it were, at the gate of the citadel since the convention started.

The enormously heavy police presence, which sometimes makes the city look as though it is experiencing a coup d'etat rather than a democratic convention, has meant that many delegates bussed in from nearby hotels are unaware of the thousands of protesters raising issues which they claim are ignored inside the Staples Centre.

Yesterday 45 animal rights protesters were arrested after a protest outside a fur shop.

A further 30 protesters were arrested as the American Civil Liberties Union announced that it would be suing the Los Angeles police department for its action against demonstrators at the end of a rally and concert on Monday night.

A legal observer who was video-taping an arrest was also arrested on a conspiracy charge.

There was another voice from the past, too, albeit the more recent past. Bill Bradley, the unsuccessful candidate who was beaten by Mr Gore in the primaries, made a rueful but supportive speech.

He, too, played on the theme that the Democrats alone truly reflected the nation's diversity.

"We don't declare ourselves compassionate, we've been acting compassionately for decades," he said. We don't just talk about prosperity, we make it happen."

Democratic party pieces

Ghost from the past
Oliver North broadcasting for a radio station from the convention centre

Conscience of the convention
Senator Russell Feingold: "I cannot stand before you without mentioning my concern and dismay that soft money fundraising [backdoor election funding] has become so much a part of this convention"

Number of donors who have given the party $100,000 or more
142

Most in need of either soft or hard money
Thirty cycling protesters from Critical Mass arrested downtown and held on $20,000 bail for unspecified offences

Hello?
Pacific Bell reported that use of the mobile phone around the convention centre increased by 242% on the first day. AT&T handled 10m minutes of calls on the first day

Threat of the day
"I'm a peaceful demonstrator. If I'm harassed, I'll sue your ass off" - protester's badge

webTitle: Museum claims a lost Da Vinci son

fields.headline: Museum claims a lost Da Vinci son
fields.trailText: Leonardo da Vinci may have had a ne'er-do-well son who was banished to Bologna to keep him out of bad company, the director of a museum dedicated to the Renaissance genius claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Leonardo da Vinci may have had a ne'er-do-well son who was banished to Bologna to keep him out of bad company, the director of a museum dedicated to the Renaissance genius claimed yesterday.

An icon of the gay community, Leonardo certainly had sexual relations with women and could have had an illegitimate son at the age of 17, according to Alessandro Vezzosi, director of the Leonardo da Vinci Ideal museum in Vinci, the artist's birthplace.

A letter from the Bologna nobleman Giovanni Bentivoglio to Lorenzo de' Medici in 1479 refers to a mysterious "Paulo de Leonardo de Vinci from Florence" who was sent away from the Tuscan city for mala vita.

The letter was previously interpreted as referring to an assistant of Leonardo, or perhaps even a boyfriend: the artist and inventor was acquitted on a charge of sodomy in 1476. The structure of the phrase, according to Mr Vezzosi, appears to indicate that the youth was related to the artist.

An unfortunate experience with his own son could have inspired Leonardo's gloomy letter of congratulations to his brother on hearing he had just become a father.

"You have the fortune to have created yourself an energetic enemy, who with all his efforts desires liberty, which he will only get with your death," Leonardo wrote to Domenico around 1506.

webTitle: Artists' luxury squats paint portrait of life on the Seine

fields.headline: Artists' luxury squats paint portrait of life on the Seine
fields.trailText: There are maybe a dozen around the city, and their number is growing: unable to afford the airy 19th-century lofts and studios that have become the preferred homes of upwardly mobile 30-somethings, the impoverished artists of Paris are squatting in some of its finest buildings.
fields.body:
There are maybe a dozen around the city, and their number is growing: unable to afford the airy 19th-century lofts and studios that have become the preferred homes of upwardly mobile 30-somethings, the impoverished artists of Paris are squatting in some of its finest buildings.

"What we're doing is essential," insisted Francesco, 30, a particularly exuberant painter. He, along with some 30 fellow artists of 15 different nationalities, has taken over a magnificent six-storey edifice on the Rue de Rivoli close to the ultra-chic Place des Vosges.

"We have no place to work, and the city has thousands of empty buildings. This place had been unoccupied for 13 years. Besides which, being in a community like this is inspirational, and gives the public a chance watch us."

Suspended from the facade of the building, the property of an offshoot of the debt-ridden Credit Lyonnais bank, is a colourful cloth spider's web knitted from garment swatches. Up the stairs are digitally doctored photographs and paint-daubed posters. The walls are graffiti-covered, the bare rooms draped in cloth and dripping with installations.

"This is an alternative artistic community," proclaimed Kalex, one of the squat's founders. "We are Parisian artists, and we demand the right to be able to live and work in our city. Historically, Paris has always been a home to artists, but to work you need a workshop, to get a workshop you need a state certificate, and to get that you need to know people."

As more and more of the French capital falls prey to creeping gentrification, its traditional Bohemian haunts are being lost. The damage is worst in St Germain-des-Près, where Emporio Armani has taken over the old Drugstore cafe, Dior inhabits the mythical Le Divan bookshop, and Cartier rings and bracelets are on display where once there was a classical-record shop.

Rich young professionals in search of out-of-the-ordinary accommodation have also begun infiltrating Paris' cités des artistes: striking council-owned complexes of low-rent studios with high windows in places such as Montmartre and Montparnasse.

"Even if I could afford £600 or £800 a month for an atelier, no agent would accept me because my income is so precarious," said an artist known as Chauchat.

Standing in front of one of his oeuvres - a bicycle attached by a complicated system of wires and pulleys to a doll that dances when the pedals turn - he said squatters "have to break the law so the law will evolve".

Fernando, 30, a trompe-l'oeil specialist and one of 400 renegade artists who launched the squatters movement by temporarily taking over 15,000 square yards of an abandoned secondary school, agreed. "This whole thing is taking off so successfully, we've started to believe in what was only a dream," he said.

"Once you squat, it's possible to live from and for your art. In places like this, surrounded by like-minded artists, you really develop. Squatting makes art possible for artists, and for people."

At Paris town hall they are not quite so sure. "It may be art, but that's not what most people would call it," sniffed a buildings inspector. "They splash so much paint on the facades you have to sand down the stone to get rid of it, and no sooner have you finished than they've moved in somewhere else. These people need to learn respect for their artistic heritage."

That, says Fernando, is what they said of Monet, Lautrec and van Gogh. "The council?" he said, cryptically. "I hate straight lines. They're so negative."

 Additional reporting by Elodie Ratsimbazafy

fields.headline: To boldly glow
fields.standfirst: Jellyfish genes enlighten molecular biology, writes Claire Cockcroft
fields.trailText: Jellyfish genes enlighten molecular biology, writes Claire Cockcroft
fields.body:
What makes jellyfish glow or give the ocean its sometimes luminous gleam is an eerie emission of light
by living things. This bioluminescence is seen in many species, from fireflies to fungi and sponges to
squid.


Special proteins create these flashlight features which have intrigued humans for centuries. Pliny the
Elder discovered a clam which squirted a light-emitting liquid that made the mouth glow when eaten,
sparking off a trend for glow-in-the-dark banquets in first century Rome.

Today, these proteins are
used by researchers as a molecular lantern, illuminating intricate processes, from nervous system
development to monitoring the movement of tumour cells in living animals.


Bioluminescence is mainly a marine phenomenon, seen in the surface layers of the ocean as a
bluish-green fluorescent glow. Single-celled creatures called dinoflagellates are the main source,
shimmering when disturbed by passing ships, fish or breaking waves. A submarine's wake can stir up
the sea life, creating flashes of light that could potentially betray its position to passing ships,
aircraft or even satellites.


More than 80% of fish and other animals living in the twilight zone of the deep oceans use light to lure
prey, to frighten off attackers or to attract a mate. Certain species of squid use bioluminescent
"searchlights" to find their prey, but they also have small spots of lights all over their body allowing
them to blend into the background sparkles of the water, cunningly camouflaging themselves by
counter-illumination.

Others accommodate bioluminescent bacteria in special organs which they eject
as a luminous cloud when under attack, blinding the predator.
Jellyfish strike fear into many of us, conjuring up painful childhood memories of prodding a strange
blob of jelly on the beach. Deep in the ocean, however, jellyfish are breathtakingly beautiful, like
chandeliers illuminating the ocean. They gracefully move through their watery world by jet propulsion.


These fragile and gelatinous invertebrates are some of the simplest animals, along with corals and sea
anemones, and are 95% water, about 3%salt, and 2% protein.
The jellyfish Aequorea victoria has discrete glowing points around the edge of its umbrella-like
structure. Bundles of about 6,000 to 7,000 special photogenic cells produce its ethereal light.

These
cells are packed with a light-producing protein called aequorin and a colour-shifting secondary protein
that accepts the blue light emitted from aequorin, re-emitting it as green light, hence the name green
fluorescent protein (GFP). This is an exciting era for Aequora: the genes behind the glowing have been
borrowed by molecular biologists and GFP is now the most popular tool used by scientists to shed light
on cellular events.


To understand how a cell works, we need to see the individual "moving parts" in action. This can be
done by labelling cellular components or proteins with tags. GFP has revolutionised cell biology,
providing a method for watching events going on inside cells in real time using time lapse microscopy.
The beauty of GFP is that, unlike other "reporter" genes, it doesn't need additional substrates for it
to work properly.


Scientists have subtly altered the structure of GFP, optimising its properties for imaging purposes.
X-ray crystallography showed that structurally GFP resembles a lantern: the protein folds into a
barrel shape and a single alpha helix runs through the centre of the structure forming the
light-emitting structure called the fluorophore.

The fluorophore absorbs low wavelength light and
emits bright green light by a fluorescence mechanism involving changes in the chemistry of specific
amino acid building blocks. Mutating the fluorophore's genetic sequence produced a brighter, more
stable GFP. Red, cyan and yellow fluorescent versions resulted from mutations that changed the
characteristics of the protein's emission spectra. Multiple proteins can now be watched simultaneously
by tagging each with a differently coloured GFP variant: each component can be seen around the cell
or interacting with each other in glorious technicolour with time lapse photography.


Nature has produced an enormous variety of living things of assorted shapes, sizes and life styles,
but similar mechanisms underlie their development. Certain proteins are known to activate genes
controlling the way an animal's body plan is established. Linking the GFP gene to genes that encode
proteins governing fruit fly development enables researchers to track the movement of these
proteins: when introduced back into an animal, GFP acts like a glowing tag under ultraviolet light.
These fusions show where the protein is located during different developmental stages and allows the
behaviour of cells to be observed.


As a fly's nervous system develops, many thousands of neurones are born, each migrating to a specfic
point and adopting a specific identity. Each neurone then extends an axon, the biological circuitry for
the nervous system, towards other cells. This has been watched by labelling components of axon
outgrowth with GFP.

Specific substances get asymmetrically localised in neuronal cells before they
divide which ensures the generation of new cell types. Different coloured GFP variants have highlighted
the cellular localisation and interplay of three key molecules, called Staufen, Prospero and Miranda,
that are involved in this process.


GFP can also be used as a "reporter" of gene expression. Sequences of DNA next to genes, called
promoters, contain the information about where and when the protein product of the gene should be

fields.bodyText: What makes jellyfish glow or give the ocean its sometimes luminous gleam is an eerie emission of light by living things. This bioluminescence is seen in many species, from fireflies to fungi and sponges to squid. Special proteins create these flashlight features which have intrigued humans for centuries. Pliny the Elder discovered a clam which squirted a light-emitting liquid that made the mouth glow when eaten, sparking off a trend for glow-in-the-dark banquets in first century Rome. Today, these proteins are used by researchers as a molecular lantern, illuminating intricate processes, from nervous system development to monitoring the movement of tumour cells in living animals. Bioluminescence is mainly a marine phenomenon, seen in the surface layers of the ocean as a bluish-green fluorescent glow. Single-celled creatures called dinoflagellates are the main source, shimmering when disturbed by passing ships, fish or breaking waves. A submarine's wake can stir up the sea life, creating flashes of light that could potentially betray its position to passing ships, aircraft or even satellites. More than 80% of fish and other animals living in the twilight zone of the deep oceans use light to lure prey, to frighten off attackers or to attract a mate. Certain species of squid use bioluminescent "searchlights" to find their prey, but they also have small spots of lights all over their body allowing them to blend into the background sparkles of the water, cunningly camouflaging themselves by counter-illumination. Others accommodate bioluminescent bacteria in special organs which they eject as a luminous cloud when under attack, blinding the predator. Jellyfish strike fear into many of us, conjuring up painful childhood memories of prodding a strange blob of jelly on the beach. Deep in the ocean, however, jellyfish are breathtakingly beautiful, like chandeliers illuminating the ocean. They gracefully move through their watery world by jet propulsion. These fragile and gelatinous invertebrates are some of the simplest animals, along with corals and sea anemones, and are 95% water, about 3%salt, and 2% protein. The jellyfish Aequorea victoria has discrete glowing points around the edge of its umbrella-like structure. Bundles of about 6,000 to 7,000 special photogenic cells produce its ethereal light. These cells are packed with a light-producing protein called aequorin and a colour-shifting secondary protein that accepts the blue light emitted from aequorin, re-emitting it as green light, hence the name green fluorescent protein (GFP). This is an exciting era for Aequora: the genes behind the glowing have been borrowed by molecular biologists and GFP is now the most popular tool used by scientists to shed light on cellular events. To understand how a cell works, we need to see the individual "moving parts" in action. This can be done by labelling cellular components or proteins with tags. GFP has revolutionised cell biology, providing a method for watching events going on inside cells in real time using time lapse microscopy. The beauty of GFP is that, unlike other "reporter" genes, it doesn't need additional substrates for it to work properly. Scientists have subtly altered the structure of GFP, optimising its properties for imaging purposes. X-ray crystallography showed that structurally GFP resembles a lantern: the protein folds into a barrel shape and a single alpha helix runs through the centre of the structure forming the light-emitting structure called the fluorophore. The fluorophore absorbs low wavelength light and emits bright green light by a fluorescence mechanism involving changes in the chemistry of specific amino acid building blocks. Mutating the fluorophore's genetic sequence produced a brighter, more stable GFP. Red, cyan and yellow fluorescent versions resulted from mutations that changed the characteristics of the protein's emission spectra. Multiple proteins can now be watched simultaneously by tagging each with a differently coloured GFP variant: each component can be seen around the cell or interacting with each other in glorious technicolour with time lapse photography. Nature has produced an enormous variety of living things of assorted shapes, sizes and life styles, but similar mechanisms underlie their development. Certain proteins are known to activate genes controlling the way an animal's body plan is established. Linking the GFP gene to genes that encode proteins governing fruit fly development enables researchers to track the movement of these proteins: when introduced back into an animal, GFP acts like a glowing tag under ultraviolet light. These fusions show where the protein is located during different developmental stages and allows the behaviour of cells to be observed. As a fly's nervous system develops, many thousands of neurones are born, each migrating to a specfic point and adopting a specific identity. Each neurone then extends an axon, the biological circuitry for the nervous system, towards other cells. This has been watched by labelling components of axon outgrowth with GFP. Specific substances get asymmetrically localised in neuronal cells before they divide which ensures the generation of new cell types. Different coloured GFP variants have highlighted the cellular localisation and interplay of three key molecules, called Staufen, Prospero and Miranda, that are involved in this process. GFP can also be used as a "reporter" of gene expression. Sequences of DNA next to genes, called promoters, contain the information about where and when the protein product of the gene should be made. If the GFP gene is linked to a particular promoter, GFP will be made instead of the normal gene product, revealing where and when the gene of interest is switched on. Scientists at AntiCancer Inc, San Diego, are using GFP as a novel cancer imaging method. Tumour cells labelled with GFP and injected into mice were easily seen, even in soft organs and bones, areas in which tumours are particularly difficult for existing methods like ultra sound and magnetic imaging to pick up. Almost 2000 years ago, Pliny the Elder described the luminous slime of the jellyfish Pulmo marinus, "a walking stick rubbed with the pulmo marinus will light the way like a torch". Quite prophetic in light of GFP's role in scientific discoveries.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers of Riverside writes: Reading Diana Rowntree's obituary of Leslie Martin (August 2), doyen of British post-war architects, prompts me to mention his help and encouragement at the start of my architectural career.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers of Riverside writes: Reading Diana Rowntree's obituary of Leslie Martin (August 2), doyen of British post-war architects, prompts me to mention his help and encouragement at the start of my architectural career.

Following the demise of Team 4 (our partnership with Norman and Wendy Foster) and with no work on the horizon, my partner Su Rogers and I asked Leslie Martin for his advice about whether we should continue to practise architecture. He looked at our work and recommended we hold on for a couple of years, also putting us in touch with the Design Research Unit, who gave us work until we won the Pompidou Competition in Paris.

Audrey Balsdon writes: I was one of the mature students on the first social work course Gerry Smale (obituary, July 28), then a young man, directed at Sussex University, and I have never forgotten him. My fondest memory is of his drawings of Wellington boots: if anyone put forward a particularly crass suggestion at a seminar he would quickly sketch in the boots and no words were needed. Social work has lost a generous, warm and imaginative man.

Brian Parrott writes: I was saddened to read Nick Davies's obituary on Gerry Smale. An inspiration and mentor to many, Gerry gave perceptive and profound feedback, with a laugh, to people like me, now director of social services in Surrey. He kept us in touch with the idealism and convictions of 15-20 years previous, as we sought to balance the values of social work with the compromises of senior management.

TF Evans writes: In your obituary of the great translator Michael Meyer (August 7), you refer briefly to his interest in games. When corresponding with him about his translations some years ago, I mentioned his love of cricket. He replied and claimed to be the only translator of Ibsen and Strindberg who had hit sixes in both the Netherlands and Sweden.

J Stephenson writes: I noted the obituary (August 9) for Lala Amarnath and, as one who saw him play between 1938 and 1939, regretted the fact that no mention was made of his time as professional for Nelson in the Lancashire League. During 1938 and 1939 he enjoyed two highly successful seasons, succeeding Lord Constantine as an outstanding player. I also have his autograph among my souvenirs.

Gina Barney writes: Your obituary of Sir Mark Oliphant (July 18) states "...he was dreaming of giant particle accelerators that might be built... This ambition was never quite fulfilled." But it was! He conceived the idea of a 1.0 gev proton synchrotron at Birmingham University in 1943 and commenced its construction in 1947. I carried out research on it for my PhD from 1962-65; and it continued to serve for a good few years after that.

fields.headline: Louis Nucera
fields.standfirst:
Finding art in the Tour de France
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The novelist Louis Nucera, who has been killed in a cycling accident outside Nice aged 72, was a devotee of the bicycle and of the Tour de France. His novel, Le Roi René (1976), was about René Vietto, the 1930s Tour champion, and in 1987 he wrote an account of his own experiences of cycling the same 4,813 kilometres as the Italian champion Fausto Coppi, the  ciampanissimo who had won the race in 1949.
fields.body:
The novelist Louis Nucera, who has been killed in a cycling accident outside Nice aged 72, was a devotee of the bicycle and of the Tour de France. His novel, Le Roi René (1976), was about René Vietto, the 1930s Tour champion, and in 1987 he wrote an account of his own experiences of cycling the same 4,813 kilometres as the Italian champion Fausto Coppi, the ciampanissimo who had won the race in 1949.

He wrote 17 novels; his first, published in 1970, was prefaced by the writer who became his master, Joseph Kessel. Bicycles aside, he wrote about the poor, immigrants, his family, cats - and about friendship, a favourite theme. Young people, he observed, had nothing to exchange with others, except their mobile phone numbers. He remembered better times.

A sign of Nucera's preferences was the importance of the names that he gave to both cats and bicycles. He aimed to cycle 100 kilometres a day, and knew something of the emotions that the prospect of the long and punishing climb of the "giant of Provence", Mont Ventoux, inspired. As a novelist he expressed those emotions without flinching from dramatic language. Yet Nucera never raced. He claimed that he would come last, or he would be among those identified by commentators as "etcetera, etcetera".

He was born in Nice, the son of poor Italian immigrants. His father, a plumber, died young, while his mother knitted for a living. When he passed his certificat d'études, she embraced him. "Now I know," she said, "that you won't starve to death."

He was soon promoted from odd jobs in a bank and there he met his first writers, Henry Miller and Roger Martin du Gard. In 1959, he became a reporter on the Communist daily, Patriote. Scouring Nice for stories, he demonstrated his real gift, making and keeping friends.

From 1964 to 1973 he worked in Paris as a Philips Records public relations manager. He helped to launch France's rock 'n' roller Johnny Halliday, and started a lasting friendship with Georges Brassens. Thirteen years at a publishers followed.

His writings won him many prizes, including the Grand Prix de l'Académie Française in 1993. But he never forgot his early poverty.

On the day of his death he had left Nice and was heading for open country when, as he turned left, he was knocked down and killed by an overtaking car. In that city everyone was his friend, rich and powerful, poor and lonely.

 Louis Nucera, writer, born July 17 1928; died August 9 2000

fields.headline: Peggy Langley
fields.standfirst: Key member of escape route that rescued hundreds of allied servicemen trapped in occupied Belgium
fields.trailText: Peggy Langley, who has died aged 85, was a member of the second world war's most famous escape route, the 1,500-strong "Comet line" which rescued allied servicemen from German-occupied Belgium. Founded by André de Jongh (Dedé), a young Belgian woman, Comet took airmen shot down over Belgium across the Pyrenees to the British consulate at Bilbao in neutral Spain.
fields.body:
Peggy Langley, who has died aged 85, was a member of the second world war's most famous escape route, the 1,500-strong "Comet line" which rescued allied servicemen from German-occupied Belgium. Founded by André de Jongh (Dedé), a young Belgian woman, Comet took airmen shot down over Belgium across the Pyrenees to the British consulate at Bilbao in neutral Spain.

As was common in the resistance's improvised democracy, Comet was an organisation where hierarchies of status, gender and age were meaningless. Its members were drawn from all backgrounds and ages but few played a more important role than Peggy Langley.

Born Peggy van Lier, in Johannesburg, she was the daughter of a Belgian businessman and a South African mother who returned to Belgium in the 1920s. Peggy was 25 when the Germans arrived. She made contact with Jean Greindl ("Nemo"), whose work running a Brussels-based Swedish Red Cross organisation provided a cover for his resistance activities.

Comet had been hit by a series of arrests in spring 1942. Nemo helped to reorganise it, dividing Belgium into sectors, each with a worker responsible for locating allied airmen.

Peggy was Nemo's indispensable collaborator. Irresistibly energetic and vivacious, she struck her co-workers as someone in perpetual movement - whether on foot, bike, car, or horseback - and always talking. She stood out as much by her ringing voice as her striking red hair - she had Irish blood on her mother's side.

Nemo and Peggy forged papers, organised hiding places and supervised the escapers' escorts to France. Since most of them spoke neither French nor Flemish, this was dangerous and delicate work.

Peggy came close to capture in November 1942 when she and Nemo became worried by the non-appearance of Comet's interrogator Elsie Marèchal, who ensured that escapers were genuine. She had been betrayed by two Germans masqerading as American airmen and Victor Michiels, another Comet member who went to investigate, was shot trying to escape.

When Victor did not return, Peggy went to his family's house - under the pretext that she knew Victor's sister - where she found the Germans waiting for her. She was immediately arrested and interrogated by a "fat, evil, rat-faced SS officer". She stuck to her story that she did not know Victor and disguised her shock at the news of his death.

She had taken the precaution of arming herself with photos showing her posing with German soldiers, and this helped to win over her captors, as did her perfect German. She was released, and returned to Nemo with the disastrous news.

Peggy's near fatal encounter ended her Comet work. She took the route to the Pyrenees and made her way to Seville whence she was transported to Gibraltar in the bilges of a boat carrying oranges.

Comet continued to operate until the end of the war, its history punctuated by further arrests. Nemo died when his prison was bombed by the allies, Dedé was sent to Ravensbruck concentra tion camp and her father was shot.

Peggy did parachute training in the hope of returning to Belgium, but it was not to be. A year after her arrival in Britain she married Jimmy Langley, a Coldstream Guards officer who had lost an arm at Dunkirk and subsequently worked for MI9. After the war, they ran a Suffolk bookshop. They had four sons and a daughter. Jimmy died in 1983.

Peggy was awarded the MBE, the Belgian Croix de Guerre and the Netherlands Resistance Cross. To her efforts and courage, and those of others like her, 800 allied servicemen owed their lives.

 Peggy Langley, resistance worker, born March 1 1915; died July 20 2000

fields.headline: Beside the sea
fields.trailText:
Newton Point, Northumberland
Ahead, the sea sparkled in the sunlight all the way to the horizon. Behind, goldfinches tugged seeds from thistle heads and the warm, blustery wind carried a steady stream of thistledown over our heads and out across the waves.
fields.body:
Newton Point, Northumberland

Ahead, the sea sparkled in the sunlight all the way to the horizon. Behind, goldfinches tugged seeds from thistle heads and the warm, blustery wind carried a steady stream of thistledown over our heads and out across the waves. This uncultivated margin between newly cut hay fields and the rocky foreshore - a broad strip of truly wild land - is a refuge for birds, insects and wild flowers at any time of the year.

In early summer it was a natural rock garden of sea pinks, silverweed, bird's foot trefoil, cowslips and sea plantain. Now, in high summer, they've given way to purple knapweed, hawkweeds, drifts of pink rest harrow and tall spikes of mallow and russet brown dock seeds. There are uncommon plants too, higher up the slope - such as hound's tongue, whose dull purple flowers produce clusters of hooked fruits that have an astonishingly tenacious grip on walkers' socks.

Today a few sea pinks were still in bloom in the crevices just above the rock pools on the upper shore, alongside a patch of late sea campion flowers where a family of pied wagtails hawked for insects.

The Aeshna dragonfly that rattled past my head was hunting insects too, catching seaweed flies. These breed in vast numbers in natural compost heaps of seaweed left by spring tides, hatching in tens of thousands in the August heat, just in time to feed swallows as they congregate along the coastline before migration.

Inland butterflies seem to be having a poor summer but here on the coast scores of meadow browns and common blues danced among the golden yellow grasses as they bent in the breeze. Swarms of metallic green and crimson six-spot burnet moths, recently emerged from papery cocoons on the grass stems, crawled over the knapweed flowers. These burnets are among the most lethargic of moths, never making long flights, merely fluttering from flower to flower.

Just as well for this population, as the next landfall if they were to blow out to sea would be the Dutch coast.

fields.headline: Wheel turns
fields.trailText: When read in context, the line "Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel" from Pope's Epistle to Arbuthnot (How police made Stones drug charges stick, G2, August 15; Corrections, August 16) is not that cruelty to the frail and beautiful is to be deplored, as is so often inferred, but that Sporus (the object of Pope's scorn) is such a contemptible and wretched thing that criticism of him would be as pointless as breaking a butterfly on a wheel.

The Times leader writer of the day would surely have known this and must have been peeved that his sly dig at Mr Jagger has been taken as a rather soppy tribute instead.

University of Southampton

fields.headline: Advice on exam setbacks
fields.trailText: Tim Luckhurst (Scotched myths, August 16) completely misses the point of the fiasco over the issuing of Scottish school exam results.
fields.body:
Tim Luckhurst (Scotched myths, August 16) completely misses the point of the fiasco over the issuing of Scottish school exam results. Teachers have been warning of impending disaster for months, not because they are conservatively opposed to the reformed exams and courses, but because they have worked extremely hard to make them work. If warnings from teachers had been heeded, none of this mess would have happened. But the leadership class in Scottish education - and the bullying and arrogant education minister - seem to believe that reform is only real if it is imposed from above.
Lindsay Paterson
Faculty of education, University of Edinburgh

 Having experienced disappointing A-level grades last year, I would like to offer a few words to all of those who are about to agonise as I did. When my university offer was withdrawn, I was given excellent advice. Instead of resitting French, I was advised to improve it by other means, which I did by au pairing in Brussels for six months. At the end of this spell, I was accepted at my original university to study French in Paris. I start this coming October. A-level results are by no means a reflection of one's worth. So to all of you wondering what to do with your future, see this setback as a challenge rather than a failure.
Christina Soper
London

When my university offer was withdrawn, I was given excellent advice. Instead of resitting French, I was advised to improve it by other means, which I did by au pairing in Brussels for six months. At the end of this spell, I was accepted at my original university to study French in Paris. I start this coming October. A-level results are by no means a reflection of one's worth. So to all of you wondering what to do with your future, see this setback as a challenge rather than a failure. Christina Soper London

fields.headline: ...and the use of animals
fields.trailText: The introduction of strong measures against harassment of people involved with animal research...
fields.body:
The introduction of strong measures against harassment of people involved with animal research (Change of tack on animal militants, August 15) has implications not only for research organisations and their staff but for everyone who wants to see the advent of new medicines and other treatments to help people with life-threatening diseases and debilitating medical conditions.

The UK has traditionally been a strong innovator in medical science and animal research is an essential part of this. If UK medical researchers, the organisations they work for and shareholders in medical science companies are not safeguarded from harassment by animal activists, the UK cannot expect to retain its position at the leading edge of medicine.
Dr Jeff Kipling
Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry

 All medical discoveries of the past century are the result of trial-and-error using human patients. For example, following hundreds of successful heart transplants on animals, the first human patient died. Over the following year, a hundred more human heart transplants were performed and not a single patient survived. It took another 10 years of trial-and- error before the difficulties were overcome.

Professor George Radda's claim (Letters, August 12) that experiments on genetically engineered mice may produce "cures" for human diseases is fantasy. Professor Richard Klausner, head of the National Cancer Institute in the US, admits: "We have cured mice of cancer for decades, but it simply didn't work in humans."
MA Thompson
Hucknall, Notts

fields.headline: Bombs and burgers
fields.trailText: You appear to believe we can have pain-free war (Leader, August 15). Did you really think it possible to rain high explosives on Kosovo for 98 days without killing anyone? Instead of more accurate bombing, how about a foreign policy that averts the need for bombs?
fields.body:
You appear to believe we can have pain-free war (Leader, August 15). Did you really think it possible to rain high explosives on Kosovo for 98 days without killing anyone? Instead of more accurate bombing, how about a foreign policy that averts the need for bombs?
Christopher Wrigley
Chorleywood, Herts

 Forget the self-satisfaction at exposing Nato dishonesty in doctoring Kosovo bombing figures. It is high time for the Guardian apologised for its part in promoting an illegal, immoral and stupid war.
Bruce Kent
London

 Your correspondents on British aid to Indian flood victims (Letters, August 15) seem to have conveniently forgotten that the Indian government has recently acquired nuclear missiles. How much did that little lot cost?
RP Johnson
Leigh-on-Sea, Essex

 As a part-time employee of McDonald's, I'd have to work for 15 minutes to afford a quarter-pounder (Letters, August 18) - in which time the McDonald's standard of service dictates I serve 15 customers. But I would never dream of buying one.
Wendy Moir
Hatton, Aberdeenshire

 How much of the cost of a quarter-pounder gets back to the producers?
Peter Fridlington
Lincoln

 One way to allay public concern over air safety (Concorde grounded, August 16) would be to manufacture aircraft out of whatever it is they use to make the indestructible black-box flight recorders.
Jeremy Kay
London

 Jack Hill (Letters, August 16) asks who ate the Mars Bar afterwards. I always assumed that it was consumed during.
Ian Parsons
Bradford

webTitle: Figuring out who benefits from the social fund

fields.headline: Figuring out who benefits from the social fund
fields.trailText: The social fund provides a vital safety net for the poorest and most vulnerable. We have already improved it and will continue to do so where appropriate.
fields.body:
Malcolm Dean's article criticising the government's record on the social fund (Losing out, August 16) was prompted by spurious Liberal Democrat claims of a 32-fold increase in the proportion of loan applications rejected in one year.

In fact there was a 5% increase. What Dean chose not to mention was the 9% increase in successful budgeting loan applications last year and the 15% increase in expenditure on budgeting loans overall, to nearly £400m. He also omitted to point out the 6% rise in the average award - up from £368 to £389. The social fund helped 82,000 more people last year - another statistic mysteriously omitted from the article.

The new budgeting loan system is fairer and less in trusive. Why should people on benefit be required to specify the use a budgeting loan will be put to, and have a social fund decision-maker decide whether they actually need the specified items or not? Under the new scheme, they don't have to.

The social fund provides a vital safety net for the poorest and most vulnerable. We have already improved it and will continue to do so where appropriate. The Tories are committed to slashing the budget by £90m, effectively destroying it.
Angela Eagle MP
Minister for social security

 The Student Loans Company offers every student 75% of an interest-free loan of up to nearly £5,000. The entitlement increases with regional living costs and need, with the worst-off students entitled to 100%, every year.

The social fund, by contrast, is a cash-limited fund, denying assistance to those judged least able to pay. If social fund applicants eke out their meagre incomes for longer, applying once others have already succumbed, refusal is more likely - regardless of "merit" or need. Students are expected to make repayments, equivalent to 9% of earnings, only when their incomes exceed £10,000. And when the "worst" happens, they can negotiate bank overdrafts.

In October, shops, bars and restaurants will be replete with banners urging me to demand student rights, ie my 10-20% discounts on books, CDs, cinema tickets etc. Demand equality. Don't force fraud.
Jennifer Gibb
Glasgow

 Inability to repay is now one of a very small number of possible reasons for refusal of social fund loans, so it is unsurprising that it is more common.

Applications have risen because the process is easier and quicker. In my experience, working in advice agencies in central Manchester, most claimants prefer the new system.

The old single payments system, which I used to exploit unmercifully, was very complicated and expensive to run and encouraged local social security officers to make intrusive enquiries into the personal affairs of claimants, as does any means-tested system. It also fostered the division between the deserving and the undeserving poor.
Martin Rathfelder
Socialist Health Association
